As for the Empire, I’m here for the 17.4 million to strike back.  75 years ago, my forefathers fought and died on European soil fighting fascism. Today, we are here to liberate the United Kingdom from the European Union. For the past three years, despite paying GBP 1 billion a month for membership, we have been treated with nothing but contempt, and today it got worse. As for the so-called level playing field, I’d hate to play football against you, Mr Barnier, as the match would be rigged. Brexit has shown that the European Union does not believe in democracy. Today, we are expected to vote to call Brexit a regrettable event. Well, let me put it into language you understand: ‘je ne regrette rien’. We are leaving the European Union and we have no regrets.  (Applause)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, in time historians might describe Brexit as the incredible sulk by the self-styled Incredible Hulk and his allies, who want to leave the European Union, come hell or high water, on 31 October, regardless of the consequences for people, for prosperity or for peace on the island of Ireland. For that reason, we are so grateful in Ireland for the solidarity of the EU26, articulated so well by President Juncker and Mr Barnier here this morning. Mr Juncker said that they are standing in solidarity with the most affected states and showing unity of purpose. It couldn’t be stronger or clearer. Mr Barnier also outlined very clearly the necessity for the backstop.  There is another consequence of Brexit, and that is that after the Good Friday Agreement, the relationship between Ireland and the United Kingdom grew and became friendlier, culminating with the Queen’s visit to Ireland in Croke Park a few years ago. That now has been replaced, unfortunately, by tension and suspicion. I hope, however, that if the United Kingdom asks for an extension of Article 50, and I’m encouraged by what I heard here today, it will be granted. If only, number one, to give Mr Johnson the time to come forward with the abundance of solutions he told our Prime Minister he had for the backstop, and maybe also to give time to the good people of Great Britain to take back control from the Brexit buccaneers who want to leave, regardless of deal or no deal.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: – Madam President, being a British as well as a German citizen, Brexit is quite an emotional topic for me, as for many others I guess, and the most emotional part is obviously the backstop. What is hardly ever mentioned though is that the backstop is only a temporary solution until a final agreement is signed. So why is it such a problem? It is because there is a lack of mutual trust and we see that today very clearly. Some British people fear that they will be bound to the EU forever and, at the same time, the EU wants guarantees that there will be no hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, and that is exactly the point. It is not only about the UK. It is also about Ireland and we have every right to discuss this here because Ireland is going to stay in the European Union.  So what can we do? Exactly the opposite of what some politicians in Britain and here in this House are doing, which is to become more and more aggressive and to use war metaphors – and I say this explicitly as a German and British citizen. We will stay neighbours anyway and we should stay good neighbours, in peace.  (Applause)

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Madam President, I would like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker and Michel Barnier for being before our Parliament, a Parliament that has the privilege of hearing you and debating Brexit, without anyone thinking of suspending it. Our Parliament will take responsibility. We will never accept harm to the island of Ireland, either by a wall or by the return of violence. We will never accept to damage the integrity and solidity of the European Union. We will never compromise on peace, on the rights of citizens, or on the interests of the European Union. Our Parliament knows how to say what it does not want. He also knows how to say what he wants. Our attitude has always been and remains dictated by the friendship and respect we have for the British people, but we do not yet know what the British government wants. We do not know, for example, whether the UK will ask for a further postponement of Brexit and whether it has a valid reason to do so. The British government does not tell us when, how or where it wants to leave the European Union. This situation cannot last. We need to know whether the UK respects us as much as we respect it, and respecting ourselves involves telling each other the truth.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Madam President, yesterday I heard Mr Barnier speak about a fragile peace. He talked about meeting women in Ireland who cross the border every day for work. They said to him ‘We don’t want it to start up again.’ I appeal to Mr Farage, and indeed to Mr Johnson, visit the border, hear their stories, they are heartfelt and they are real. In Northern Ireland the tensions are always present. Violence is never far away. My Irish colleagues Clare Bailey and Vincent Martin have first-hand experience of this. They proposed a confirmatory vote for those who live in Northern Ireland: let the UK exit the backstop whenever it wants but first put a question to the people of Northern Ireland – best of both worlds in a free-trade area or the UK only? Let them decide. The poet Seamus Heaney once wrote ‘Believe that a further shore is reachable from here. Believe in miracles …’. Like Heaney, we have to believe in miracles, but we must not lose hope that a solution can be found.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Mr Cuffe, and I approve of your choice of poet. I have quoted him in this Chair.

name: Antonio Maria RINALDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when I hear my fellow Members in this House, I understand that the greatest concern is to call for a repeat of the referendum in the United Kingdom, perhaps as long as the result is welcome. Democracy works in a different way. Moreover, when Mrs Ursula von der Leyen was elected by only nine votes, no one asked for a repeat, even though half of this Parliament did not agree. I would simply like to point out that the United Kingdom is a net buyer of goods and services from the Eu ropean Union. What does it mean to penalise the UNITED Kingdom? After that, who are we going to sell our cars to, who are we going to sell our food and machinery to?  So let us try to reach agreement, but above all let us try to come together in a proactive way. When we wanted to support the banking system there were meetings even at night and a solution was immediately found. Why do we not want to find a solution vis-à-vis the United Kingdom? I propose to all colleagues... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, the increasingly clear prospect of Britain leaving the Union without a deal, the so-called "hard Brexit", threatens the interests of all. For Europe, this development of the situation would mean difficult import-export of goods towards the UK, and in the UK itself economic uncertainty and a threat to peace in Northern Ireland. The UK will leave the European Union but will not leave Europe. The country will remain one of nato's largest economic partners and a secure ally. The security partnership is particularly important for those of us who will remain in the Union. It is necessary to find a solution to the problem of the border with Ireland, which satisfies the current objections of the United Kingdom on the matter.  European Union leaders need to understand that, as it is, the decision on the Irish border proposed by Mr Barnier would threaten the constitutional integrity of the United Kingdom and be unacceptable to our British partners. We can expect a swift and effective solution to the crisis surrounding Britain's exit from the Union only after agreement has been reached on this issue. Otherwise, we will contribute to the risk not only of Europe's economic development, but also of its strength. In addition, we can lose the trust of one of our most important partners.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: – Madam President, for Spain Brexit is a transitional state which does not augur well. In our country, the region of Gibraltar faces a probably catastrophic scenario. The Case of Brexit threatens the Gibraltar-Spain border; today an open injury passing more than 28,000 people daily, between 13,000 and 15,000 cross-border workers, for which we do not have a reliable contingency plan, agreed and financed. We do not yet know how we will prevent their work permits from being negatively modified, that their remuneration and pensions do not decrease, or that the health care to which they are entitled does not deteriorate. If the UK abruptly leaves the European Union, there will be queues of more than four hours at the border, the supply of food and medicine, the supply of businesses, imports and exports and the influx of tourists will slow down. The path of roses Johnson fantasized about has already become an impassable mudslide, with a parliament gagged and millions of people in the stagnant. I hope you let them choose freely, but if you leave, do so by taking on your responsibilities. Stop playing poker with people's lives.

name: Lance FORMAN
text: – Madam President, this is my first speech in this august Chamber, and hopefully my last. As I entered this building for the first time I saw a huge billboard with a quotation about free and fair elections. But I ask you all, what is the point of free and fair elections if the result is dishonoured? What is the point of free and fair elections if the losers refuse to accept defeat? What is the point of free and fair elections if freedom and fairness is sacrificed, because the elite think that they know best? The EU holds itself out as the torch bearer of global democracy, giving hope to oppressed people, but what is the point when it resents the democratic vote of its own people? In a few weeks, our Prime Minister Boris Johnson, my friend, may be forced to ask for an extension to the Brexit negotiation deadline. If the EU truly believes in democracy, it has to reject that request, even if it doesn’t like the outcome. If you believe in democracy you have to stand with the British people. Our exit is long overdue.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, behind the outbursts of voice this morning, there are very concrete realities and very concrete risks for the future of our countries. The British people have made the choice to leave the European Union and this choice must be respected, but our dialogue this morning will be of no use only if it is to comment on British political life. It is first of all for us, as you have recalled, Mr Negotiator, to remain vigilant and focused on the essential: the protection of the interests of all citizens. If the UK leaves without a deal, we will all become more vulnerable to security threats, and more fragile in our defence capabilities. Cooperation with our British neighbours is an essential element for our intelligence forces, police forces and armed forces. Tomorrow, we may find ourselves less effective together to deal with the terrorist threat or to protect our strategic interests. Our economy, too, would be hard hit in an already difficult environment and I would like to draw your attention, in particular, to the significant cost of an unsealed exit for countries close to the British Isles. You will allow me to quote France, in particular, which would manage the burden of managing a restored land border with Great Britain in the event of a no deal. In this economic disaster, we must mention one sector in particular, that of fishing, because the closure of British waters would be a double punishment that we and our British friends would inflict on each other. In short, thousands of people look at us and expect one thing from us. Let's be responsible. With the eyes of a new elected official, I am surprised by the turn our debates take. We are not here to play a game again or to start a referendum decided by the voters, but to prepare an agreement and we are counting on you, dear Michel, to continue working in this direction.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, in the midst of the uncertainty over the UK's exit options and the misunderstanding raised by the British Prime Minister's behaviour, the European Parliament's position is timely.  Through the resolution, our message to the British political class and citizens is particularly clear. The Europeans favour an orderly exit, which guarantees civil peace in Ireland, which respects the rights of EU citizens residing in the UK and those of British citizens living in the EU, an orderly exit in accordance with European rules and in accordance with the financial commitments of the divorce. Our message is also clear on an extension of the time frame to which we would resolve if the elections were to take place. Now we look forward to the British Prime Minister making intelligible proposals and taking responsibility. And since I am talking about a Prime Minister taking responsibility, I would like to have a saddened thought about someone whom we read that he has been suffering silently for three years and wonders every day about the meaning of all this, David Cameron, who, for tactical reasons, has unleashed this chaos that is not in line with the great British democratic tradition.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, more than 150 000 Spaniards live in the UK and, in turn, 300 000 Brits live in Spain. For all those citizens, what Mr Farage called a clean break Brexit is a very, very dirty Brexit indeed. Their situation is truly dramatic.  Just last week, I was in the UK talking to Spanish citizens. Their concern has to do with the so-called ‘settled’ status, which is anything but settled. It is just a PDF number they get on their email that actually confers no rights if Mr Johnson and Mr Farage proceed with their no—deal charades. We need to put ourselves in the skin of those citizens who, after possibly decades living in the UK, have no certainty about whether their lives there can continue. The EU is doing what it must to protect its citizens. The UK is not. We must stand with these proposals, and we must avoid a no—deal Brexit that would be catastrophic for all European citizens.  (Applause)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, let’s be honest. A lot of people are tired; a lot of people are exhausted. They want to move on. They think that, if we do not grant the extension, then we can go about other business and we can actually get rid of all this drag that we have been seeing in the last month and in the last years. But, let us make no mistake. If we do not grant this extension and if there is a no—deal Brexit, none of this nightmare would be over. The question of the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland would not be solved, the budgetary questions would not be solved, and the question of the EU and UK citizens and what their future is going to be would not be solved. So now is not the moment for short—sightedness. Now is the moment for solidarity with the hundreds of thousands of British citizens who are marching in the streets. They are calling on us and counting on us to grant this extension in order to give them time to get out of this deadlock and find a solution to this mess that we are in.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I think you get the prize for sticking exactly to your time. Well done!

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Listening to this debate, I ask myself: what conclusion can be drawn from it? What should we prepare for? The conclusion is as follows: we should prepare for the worst-case scenario, namely the lack of agreement. Supposedly no one wants it, but it's probably a scenario that awaits us. I wanted to emphasise only one thing: responsibility, responsibility for this historic moment and for this catastrophe, the size of which we cannot yet predict, will fall on both sides. And I hope that Jean-Claude Juncker and Mr Barnier, our chief negotiator, are also aware of this. I believe that negotiations should be resumed and conducted as soon as possible in order to avoid the consequences that threaten us. And postponing Brexit indefinitely also leads nowhere, to even more chaos and legal uncertainty, so I ask you to take appropriate action.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, it is evident that we didn’t want the exit of the United Kingdom and, even if we regret it, we fully respect the choice of British people. All the negotiations were carried out in a true spirit of cooperation and good faith, finding the best solutions for both sides. All this time, very much due to the stolidity, serenity and true British phlegm of Michel Barnier, we have shown goodwill, good faith and respect.   If any European politician or leader has not respected, on any occasion, the British position or institutions, that is regrettable. Please read our lips: we are open to consider your proposals, if you present them. We are open to an extension, if that is justified. You can believe us; we want to make your life easier, but we expect reciprocity. It is time to urge Prime Minister Johnson. It is unfortunate that you decided to turn to American superheroes to express the inclination of the British Government when you have much better sources of inspiration in modern and popular British literature. Mr Johnson, do you really believe that what we need here now are the hard skills of the Incredible Hulk? Wouldn’t the skills of the very British, much smarter and magical Harry Potter serve you better, Mr Johnson? (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Ben HABIB
text: blue-card question. – For three years we’ve heard that the EU is a rules-based system. Mr Rangel mentioned the preparedness of the EU to negotiate with us a new form of withdrawal agreement, perhaps some alteration to the backstop. But I just want to remind this Chamber that, by its own volition, clause 12 of the agreement which gives effect to the extension until 31 October prohibits any opening of the Withdrawal Agreement and any further renegotiation of that agreement. So how is it that this rules-based system can take that approach?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am not going to ask you to even answer that because the question came after the 30 seconds. The rest was a statement.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, the United Kingdom will be plunged into chaos if there is a hard Brexit born, let us remember, of the lies of irresponsible political leaders who deceived their citizens and which have led the current Government to violate the pillars of its own democracy, closing the British Parliament. In the face of this historic counter-feeling, which will greatly harm all European citizens, and especially the British, the position of the Spanish socialist delegation is clear and forceful, in line with the motion for a resolution which we are going to vote on today: 'No' to a hard Brexit. "Yes" at an orderly exit, based on the Withdrawal Agreement sealed by the Twenty-seven. A non-negotiable agreement that guarantees, above all, the safeguarding of the rights and the protection of our citizens. An agreement that preserves peace in Ireland through the backstop to prevent the restoration of a physical border with Northern Ireland and to ensure the integrity of the Union's internal market. Ladies and gentlemen, time is pressing. That is why I appeal to the responsibility and sense of state of the British Government to straighten the helm. We're still on time. There may be a reverse. (The chairperson withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Nicola BEER
text: – Madam President, the scenario of a no-deal Brexit is real. Among the relevant political groups of this House we all agree on the catastrophic consequences of a hard Brexit, in particular for the citizens of Ireland and the British overseas territories, not forgetting, of course, the United Kingdom itself. The work on contingency measures is in full swing and I particularly appreciate the Commission’s recent proposals to provide support to small and medium-sized enterprises. This should be done comprehensively. But, above all, I sincerely congratulate our colleagues in the British Parliament on their determination to put their Prime Minister in his place. This move gives hope – hope for an orderly withdrawal agreement or even for a second chance for them to remain as a part of the European Union. We all, together, should take this chance, and God save the United Kingdom. (Applause)

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the possibility of the United Kingdom leaving without a deal is no longer to be ruled out. From 1 November, the consequences for European agriculture and fisheries will be considerable. However, they are very poorly evaluated. What is certain is that the beef, dairy and wine and spirits sectors will be the most severely affected. Brexit is likely to be an unprecedented crisis, and we are moving forward in the fog and without a compass. Irish beef producers are on the brink, as mr Flanagan noted earlier. Agriculture Commissioner Phil Hogan is well aware of this. It has already weighed in to extract 50 million euros from the agricultural budget in 2020 to cushion this shock. Mr. Hogan's concerns are legitimate. The European Commission must therefore urgently present to this Parliament a comprehensive project to support all European farmers affected by Brexit.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, in less than a month and a half there will be a Brexit. This fact is known, and even those who do not want Brexit should accept it. A number of Members in this Chamber are advocating direct democracy. I stress that I'm not one of them. The referendum is its purest means, and if we reach for it, its outcome must be respected. The European Commission and the Council should use the remaining time to find an agreement to prevent this so-called hard Brexit. This will harm not only the United Kingdom, but also the remaining states of the European Union, their citizens – our citizens and businesses. For an agreement to be concluded, both sides must agree to it. It is clear that the United Kingdom does not agree with the current proposal. This agreement must therefore be amended. I think it's dangerous to keep insisting on something that doesn't work.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Madam President, as you know, the reason I went into politics was called foot-and-mouth disease, an animal disease which, as they do, does not stop at borders and which touched my country, the Netherlands, yours, Ireland and also France and the United Kingdom at the beginning of this century. Hundreds of thousands, even millions, of farm animals were killed on account of a disease against which they could have been easily vaccinated, and the outcry that this created in rural areas was not heard in London because the British Government at the time did not want to change the so-called non-vaccination policy. So it was this House which represented the interests of both Europeans and British in order to change that policy, and which worked together with places like Northumberland and the Scottish Borders. Fast-forward 20 years, and the constructive, pro-European Tories I worked with at the time have been purged from their party by people who can’t even be bothered to attend this full debate. Westminster is closed for business and it is once more this Parliament that is representing the interests of both British and European citizens. And, like a majority – a majority – of British citizens, this House doesn’t want a no-deal Brexit either. But let me also be very clear: we will not accept access into our European market for products with lax financial oversight, in the case of the financial sector, or low environmental standards and low animal-health standards. And if you want to know why, go and ask the farmers in Friesland and Northumberland alike. (Applause)

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, membership or not, the British remain among us and we live together. We are the representatives of citizens from the different Member States, we take this seriously and we cooperate with our British colleagues here deeply and in a warm way. Parliamentarianism needs to be protected. It is the core of democracy. In Parliament, different ideas meet and then we look at a way forward. In a western democracy, governments represent the will of the majority of the parliament.  In the UK, a law designed to stop a no-deal Brexit passed in both Houses of the UK Parliament. So, in principle, we should not worry, but now it seems that Prime Minister Johnson is trying to take control away from his parliament, to take control away from the British. The new UK leadership is still flirting with the idea of a no-deal Brexit and they appear to have become more hard line. The EU should remain calm, principled, united and reasonable. We cannot decide on behalf of the Brits, but we will give them time if they want to clear this mess up.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I will not repeat what has been said. I think the vast majority of us do not want Brexit. Some still hope that it may not happen at all. But I fear the British Prime Minister is ready to throw the UK overboard. Leave without a deal. Nothing worse could have happened. The Commission must therefore continue to prepare for this scenario as well. But not only that. The Commission and the Member States must have an emergency plan for European business. Don't let him fall along with Brexit. We must insist on the rights of the more than three million EU citizens who now live on the islands in great existential uncertainty. He doesn't know what Kind of Britain he'll wake up to on November 1. Britain's Brexit policy is reminiscent of the search for a unicorn. They don't pay anything. Deadlines change, appeals agreed, deals with approved. Time is running out very quickly, and it is no wonder that the EU is running out of patience.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in this debate, I would like to draw attention to the three most important negative consequences of britain leaving without a deal. Firstly, uncertainty about the rights of EU citizens living in the UK. In the agreement, they were guaranteed at the same level as they are today. There is likely to be around EUR 50 billion in further EU budgets, which the UK has agreed to pay as commitments for the period 2019-2020, as well as part of the commitments after 2020. Trade problems with the UK. The European Union has a huge surplus in this trade. In 2017, it was around £100 billion. The absence of an agreement means that it will have to be conducted on the basis of WTO rules, i.e. the introduction of customs duties, import quotas or other non-tariff restrictions. It seems that, for at least three reasons, the Union should also seek to ensure that the Uk's exit is, however, on the basis of a negotiated agreement with a revised political declaration, which will include gestures of goodwill addressed to the United Kingdom.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I guess everything important about Brexit has been said. The position of the EU 27, the Council, Parliament and the Commission is clear and transparent and stable. Still, we should not miss the opportunity to reach an agreement – an agreement that will reduce the cost of Brexit for all Europeans. By this I mean also Europeans from the UK as well as from the continent. If an extension would increase the chance of such a result, we should grant it. Still, I guess there are things that we should learn from our friends from London that can make our society better and avoid the crisis that is ongoing in London.  First of all, I believe that politicians should sometimes admit that personal interest and power – even victory in elections – are less important than the future of the country and society.  Second, I believe – and this is not just for politicians – we should talk to each other more, at least in situations where our views are not so different. We should construct bridges rather than build walls. Last but not least, we should promote a culture that prefers the facts and truth over lies. This is very important. We should, together with civil society, schools, experts and other parts of society, make sure that the current alarming trend where lies are rewarded over the truth will not continue and will be changed, and that the biggest liars will not become presidents or prime ministers.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I do not question the right of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union, but I draw attention to something like political responsibility for the fate of Europe. And this political responsibility for the fate of Europe is guided by the European Commission, Parliament and the Council. That is, we defend our citizens (I want to say that almost one million Poles live in the British Isles), we protect our industry, trade, transport, our economic interests. This lack of accountability, on the other hand, is a characteristic of the UK Government. I have the impression that the British Government thinks that peace or war in Ireland is our duty, our problem, that this is not a British problem. The British people want to keep their benefits, but they don't want to share responsibility. We do not have constructive draft solutions. After Brexit, life will go on. The basic thing is trust. And try, british government, to inspire such trust with us, because without this trust there will be no good solution.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, three years after the referendum, British citizens are sending us a strong signal that Mr Nigel Farage is not the voice of British society. Every day, they are expressing vocal opposition to Brexit, and the presence of so many pro-European British MEPs in this Parliament is the real proof of the fact. A change is much needed now, because Brexit continues to be pursued for Tory advantage, but without a plan on how to deliver it.  By insisting that the backstop be removed from the Withdrawal Agreement, but without proposing a working solution, the UK Government refuses to secure an orderly withdrawal. Families, children, students and all our citizens want to have certainty. More than three million non-British EU citizens – of whom a quarter of a million are from my home country of Bulgaria – have been living in legal limbo, but also in frustration, anxiety and disappointment, since the referendum. As we all see, Brexit is a bad idea and it should be stopped.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, much has already been said, but one thing is clear, and that Brexit presents us with a major challenge. A no deal puts 1.2 million jobs at risk in the European Union and for Belgium alone an estimate points to a job loss of 42,000, of which 28,000 in Flanders. SMEs in particular will be struggling. We all notice that the British Government no longer sees a way out of their self-chosen Brexit. And now that the unpredictability is greater than ever, we must prepare Europe for a no deal in the interests of businesses and Europeans. On 4 September, the European Commission made a number of proposals on the Globalisation Fund and the Solidarity Fund to free up money for this. But it is very important that small and medium-sized enterprises can also benefit from this. Point 14 of the motion for a resolution which is before us and which I fully endorse set out is very clearly defined and calls for this Parliament to make financial support for small and medium-sized enterprises possible quickly in the event of a no deal, while assuming that it can be averted in the coming days and weeks.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Dear Chairman, it has been three years since the Brexit referendum. I believe the majority in this House were surprised by the result because they wanted a different result. But there has been support for those who have been seeing an on-call culprit for domestic conflicts for a long time in Brussels. But even after three years since the referendum, the UK is not ready to take responsibility for Brexit or the responsibility for giving it up. Negotiations concluded, congratulations to Mr Barnier on the work done, the European Union has established its positions. On the other side of the Channel, there are completely different opportunities, political chaos and uncertainty, in a country that has largely struck the groundwork for the parliamentary system and democratic decision-making, in a country whose Parliament is suspended today. Today, it is difficult to distinguish there what is a meaningful strategy and what is only a political bluff on the run from responsibility. One thing is certain: whatever happens with Brexit, the result must not jeopardise the cohesion of the European Union that we have successfully achieved on this issue.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, European citizens are in the core DNA of this Parliament and it is our essential duty to protect them whenever we can. This Parliament has always supported the united EU approach to dealing with Brexit and its negative consequences for the lives of Europeans, and I am glad that the proposed parliamentary declaration maintains the emphasis on the unity of the EU27.  However, I do feel it is even more important to maintain the unified European approach to Brexit especially now, in order to protect citizens from all EU Member States, smaller and larger, who are residing in Britain. In particular, we have to be strongly united in our insistence that the UK Government exert the utmost effort to offer the settled status to all qualified EU citizens without any unnecessary technical hurdles and political delays.  At the same time, we in the EU must be united in facing the potential consequences of a hard Brexit for the rights of all European citizens in the UK. However much we strive to avoid a hard Brexit, we must be ready to face it together in unity for the sake of equal protection of all EU citizens, should we be confronted with a worst-case scenario of the UK’s departure from the Union.  Let’s remember that the unity of the EU27 has been at the core of our successful negotiations with London and we must, therefore, reinforce it in the run-up to the most difficult decisions on Brexit.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For three years, The Brexit hardliners have had no plan for how to leave the European Union. We warn here in this House that a no-deal will affect everyone. In labour law, the European Union guarantees equality between men and women, workers' rights, maternity protection, part-time work, parental leave and trade union rights. With a hard Brexit, that guarantee will disappear. Women in the UK will be among the biggest losers in the no-deal. They are not as mobile as men, they are more likely to be in social occupations, they are more likely to be employed in health, in commerce, and they are more likely to receive social benefits for themselves and their family members. Therefore, as long as we can extend a hand, we should do so. An outstretched hand is always better than the cynical, self-destructive come-what-may-come mentality.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, I think the Brexit thriller has something in common with the Grexit thriller in 2015 and Boris Johnson, although completely different from a political point of view, has things in common in his tactics with Alexis Tsipras. They both put partisan interest above the national interest. Both for a time pretended to negotiate while, in fact, going back and forth to the capitals. They both pretended that they were not interested in the consequences of their thies and that they had no sense of risk. But in his honour, Tsipras made the last, at least, moment a 180-degree turn, being pushed by us, pushed by the harsh reality and aided by President Juncker. Unfortunately, I do not think Mr Johnson will follow Mr Tsipras's good example and I do not think he will improve his policy. I therefore believe that we must monitor the British Parliament, the British people and the British youth and send them the message that we are with them.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! Thanks for that. Britain wants to leave the EU. I personally think that is a real pity, but it is the British decision and, of course, we must respect that. But it's both too bad - indeed it's almost inexcusable - if that withdrawal is to take place in a way where it's going to be a hard Brexit. It will have huge consequences for an incredible number of people on both sides of the channel. It's going to cost jobs, it's going to affect families and students, it's going to go beyond our research. I urge that we can give it a bit more time so we can find a solution to brexit so that it doesn't have to be a hard Brexit, but that we can deal with it in a way that doesn't impact our citizens and our business community. I shall therefore vote in favour of the resolution which means that we are calling for a little more time to be negotiated. Let's not have a hard Brexit, it's not for anyone' s benefit. Thanks.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for There is much to be said about Brexit, but I will confine myself to two points. My first point concerns trade relations. Britain is Sweden's fifth largest trading partner and this trade naturally creates jobs and prosperity throughout Europe. But in 43 days and about 13 and a half hours, we risk having a hard Brexit and this would, of course, hit jobs and reduce our prosperity. Furthermore, I am pleased that there are wordings in the resolution that the deadline can be extended. At the same time, it is good that there are conditions for this extension, but I think we should interpret the extension conditions as generously as possible when we receive a request from the British. Ideally, I see the British remaining in the Union, but whatever relationship the EU and the UK will have in the future, I will fight for trade relations to be as good as possible.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The situation in the UK is serious. In a few weeks' time, Brexit could mean that britain will actually crash out of the EU. A No-Deal Brexit will seriously damage both British and European interests, but also my Swedish interests. We know the consequences. For both people and businesses, the consequences of a hard Brexit will be very great. In my country, for example, we have 100,000 Swedes who are in the UK to work or study and who are worried about their future every day. For all Britons it is also a very uncertain future. The European Parliament resolution is very balanced and it emphasises the important demands that we have made in the past for an exit. The agreement is there and with openness to the political declaration, we can safeguard our future. I would urge Boris Johnson: take the responsibility that you do when you are in a government! Look to the best in the country!

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, I would like to underline a lot of things that have been said by colleagues this morning, but I would like to add mention of one dimension to a no—deal Brexit when it comes to foreign policy. Michel Barnier was referring to the political declaration and, yes, in the political declaration the EU and the UK have agreed on a broad future relationship with a free-trade area, police and judicial cooperation, and close cooperation on foreign policy, external security and defence. Following a no—deal Brexit, the United Kingdom could no longer collaborate in existing and future projects of the European Defence Agency or in military projects under Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO). Moreover, it would be difficult for UK defence companies to participate in projects under the European Defence Fund. These are additional arguments, dear colleagues from the far right, why it is so important to avoid a no-deal under all circumstances. I would like to welcome this motion for a resolution and I would like to thank our colleagues in the Brexit Steering Group for once again doing a great job. (Applause)

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Madam President, let’s be clear about where the blame for this mess lies. You start with impossible promises, saying we can keep the existing trade relationship with Europe, but rip up the rulebook. You then say we can negotiate from a position of strength despite leaving the world’s largest economic bloc. You then decry all opponents of this fantasy as traitors, and you move on to say the British people voted for medicine and food shortages. They did not. The country I love is better than Johnson, it’s better than them. Mr Barnier, you wish to move on, we all wish to move on, and I know many of my colleagues are fed up with this debacle. I get it, I understand it. But let’s not pretend that the Withdrawal Agreement would be sustainable without public sign—off. The British people need to put the reality of Brexit up against remaining in the European Union. Give us the time and give us the options. That’s the only sustainable way forward.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, I’d like to start by congratulating Mr Barnier for the professional way in which he has conducted these negotiations. The authors of Brexit said that they would be cutting themselves off from a corpse. We’ve proven to be a very lively corpse. Well done! It looks to me like a deal is within reach. The point at which British red lines and our red lines are coinciding is the wish for no hard border in Ireland, and therefore the solution is for there to be a Northern Ireland-only backstop by whatever name. I understand that we would be willing to go along with that, so a deal depends on whether or not the British political process can accede to that. I hope it does. The Brexiteers, the English nationalists, cheer for a no-deal Brexit. Your own government says it will be a disaster. I only have one statement for Mr Farage and his accomplices: if you get your way, and the British Government proves to be correct in its assessment of a no deal Brexit, don’t blame us for the consequences. I support the motion.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, almost 70 years ago we Europeans decided to establish our political union, and we did so because we knew this was the best way to preserve peace in Europe and also to tackle transnational challenges that now are very obvious to us, like climate change. Unfortunately, in 2016, in the Brexit referendum, a narrow majority in the UK voted for leave. At the time it was said that this was an existential crisis of the European Union. But now, three years afterwards we see that the existential crisis indeed is in the United Kingdom. The Union is as strong as ever, as others have said before me, and now the question is: is Boris Johnson ready to fulfil the legal obligation deriving from the bill approved in the House of Commons?  We certainly hope so, because a no—deal Brexit will be catastrophic.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, what many forget and others choose to ignore is that beneath the soundbites and the strong—man politics, there are real people, women and men, families, whose livelihoods and business – and indeed very safety – are at risk, as well as the peace on which these livelihoods are built.  This European Union, this democracy, has been clear from day one that it is determined to do all it can, deal or no deal, to avoid the need for a border and to protect the peace process. Remember, an international treaty underpins this peace process, and co—guarantors. We can never forget that. We know that any additional ideas put forward by the UK will be strongly welcomed and examined by the European Commission. However, this European Parliament will not give its consent to any withdrawal agreement that does not contain the safeguards outlined in the backstop. To date, the backstop is the only solution on the table that avoids any physical infrastructure. As the great Mr John Hume, a former office holder both of this parliament and Westminster, once said: ‘when people are divided, the only solution is agreement.’

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, we all know that Britain's departure is a weakening for the EU and also a weakening for the UK. I do not understand how Mr Farage can claim that the United Kingdom will be stronger, that it will be advantageous for him. Yes, perhaps vis-à-vis small European countries, but it will certainly not be in a more favourable position vis-à-vis the United States, China or Russia. It won't, the United Kingdom will be weaker. I am therefore very sorry about this approach. And I am sure that the citizens, when they decided in the referendum, did not decide for this chaos, for a disorderly exit, which means enormous uncertainty. And if Britain does leave without a deal, then it will still have to negotiate a new agreement to meet the conditions that are essential, i.e. the financial settlement, to resolve the position of the millions of EU citizens who are in Britain. So leaving without a deal is a disaster for both sides.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, under the Johnson premiership we are witnessing the decline of decency in the age of populism. Johnson is a most disreputable Prime Minister, and an embarrassment both to his party and to country. A misogynist, a homophobe, an Islamophobe, a dangerous clown – a dangerous clown chosen by less than 2% of our population. He plays fast and loose with people’s lives. His no—deal Brexit threatens shortages of food and life—saving drugs, threatens peaceful coexistence. Yes, Brexit will cost lives, as well as livelihoods – and it already has.  We have a government policy decided by an unelected advisor, Dominic Cummings, who is a man in contempt of our parliament. Is this taking back control? We have a government that is eroding trust in our institutions, from the civil servants to the courts, judges, our democratic foundations ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Bill NEWTON DUNN
text: – Madam President, I have a question for Commissioner Barnier. I’m not sure if he’s got an opportunity to reply in this debate, but quite simply: if there is no deal, is it correct to say that exchange of information between Europol, our policing centre, and all UK police forces, would stop, and therefore that the opportunities for organised crime in the UK would be much, much greater?

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: – Madam President, I want to start by apologising for the behaviour of a small minority of my compatriots, both in this Chamber and in my country. They do not represent the decent, polite and pro-European majority of my people.  (Applause from certain quarters) Brexit is a mess created entirely by leavers because they’ve never been able to agree on what type of Brexit they wanted. It’s a mess that has laid bare the broken nature of UK politics. We need a people’s vote so that the British people can finally choose between one clear leave option and remain, which is by far the best deal for us. We therefore need more time. No deal, crashing out, cannot be an option. It would be an act of catastrophic self-harm. So I urge colleagues to do everything possible, whatever their role, to help us avoid such an outcome. Just as we in the UK are doing on the streets...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, I wanted to warn of attempts to present the European Union as a unit which is guarded by savonarolas like Mr Verhofstadt, because that could frighten others that we are still comfortable in the European Union and want to reform it. We want to reform it, we want it to evolve, but we want to be inside. Of course, if we hear the tone of some and the lack of respect for the will of the British, which has already been expressed and must be respected, it is a little scary. That's why I think it's important that an agreement be reached. It is true that it is going to be difficult, but there has to be a goodwill effort, because we are going to have to coexist with the British, who are a fundamental piece of Western defense, of the Western world, and with them we will have to share many things, not only the market, not only trade, not only defense, but the future. Let's not break so many spears right now. Coexistence and respect are important.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, the British have spoken in a referendum on Brexit and therefore this Parliament has no right to exert pressure or give opinions on the outcome of that referendum.  This Parliament has an obligation to respect that result, because it is about respect for democracy that we are talking about. And the interventions that do not go in this direction are not a good contribution to being able to have a friendly and negotiated solution to Brexit.  However, it is not an obligation or from our point of law of this Parliament to be associated with the british Prime Minister's irresponsibility in wanting to provoke an exit without agreement which calls into question the Good Friday Agreement - which, it should be recalled, is a peace agreement - and calls into question the rights of European immigrants in the United Kingdom and British immigrants in the European Union.  These rights must be defended and the European institutions, starting with the European Parliament, have a responsibility to defend all these citizens even with a no-deal exit.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the importance of the negative consequences that Brexit will have for both sides in many areas has been mentioned. I would like to dwell on the fisheries relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom, which the lead negotiator, Mr Barnier, is so well aware of. If Finally Brexit takes place without the withdrawal agreement entering into force and the planned transition, we must minimise the damage to the fishing fleet in UK waters. I would like you, through the contingency measures we take over and over, to secure access, to maintain access to these waters, at least on a temporary basis, while negotiating agreements on the future relationship between each other. Yes, I know they don't like it, but we do. And here I'm going to stop for a moment. I would like to stress that one of the objectives of the European Union must be to reach an agreement that maintains that reciprocal access between waters and to fishery resources. This agreement would have advantages for fishermen and would also allow ... (The chairperson withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: James WELLS
text: – Madam President, the defence of any country and the means to conduct that defence are a central attribute of sovereignty and are the first responsibility of any government. I am therefore very concerned that the May government collaborated with the Commission – after the UK voted to leave – to lock Britain’s defence and intelligence capabilities into the various EU structures. That is intended to subordinate Britain’s intelligence and defence capabilities under the control of an unaccountable Commission. This is crystal clear in the political declaration, Clauses 104 to 106, which is an integral part of the binding law of the Withdrawal Agreement under Article 184.  I am extremely concerned that UK MPs have failed by a dereliction of their duty to understand this threat, and I would therefore urge our MPs in the UK in the strongest terms to reject any attempt to bring back this awful deal and deliver a clean Brexit.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: –Madam President, this week we saw the British Prime Minister hide from British citizens in Luxembourg, who will be acutely affected by his bombast and ego. He’s hiding from parliamentary debate in Westminster. So it’s reassuring that European democracy is alive and well in this House, with all views expressed, those that I agree with and those that I don’t agree with. There are those who campaigned for a deal in 2016 – the best and quickest deal in history – who today are arguing for a so-called clean-break Brexit. There is no such thing. There will be nothing clean in the economic and social devastation this would bring, from the north-east of England to the Falkland Islands. Nothing clean for citizens’ rights, which should be ring-fenced now to protect people; and there will be nothing clean in the complete chaos in our health service and elsewhere. Those people have no mandate and the British public should decide what happens next with Brexit. (Applause)

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Chief Negotiator. Mr President, I can be brief, but nevertheless take a minute to thank you, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of President Juncker and on behalf of the entire negotiating team that I have had the honour of leading for the past three years. This debate is important. It is, we understand everyone, with our different opinions, sometimes, as a moment of truth. Three years after the referendum, we are in a moment of truth in this negotiation. This is a serious moment, when we must remain extremely calm and respectful of each other. I will continue to work like this. I would, however, like to thank you for your interventions. We have listened carefully to all those who have spoken, in particular parliamentarians from Ireland and Northern Ireland, on the most serious issue, the one where there are the most risks, as I said earlier, caused by Brexit and then the issue of citizens and the issue on which we will never compromise. , the integrity of the single market and the four freedoms that go together. Thank you for your interventions. I have also listened to all those who have spoken the other way. There is an accusation that I want to answer so that things are clear once again. I say this to Mr Zanni who is not here, Mr Farage, Mr Madison and others: no one is trying to circumvent the choice of a majority of British citizens to leave the Union. No one. No one is trying to steal Brexit. No one is trying to keep the UK against their will in the European Union, the customs union or the single market. It's your responsibility to leave. We regret it, it has been said dozens of times, many of us regret this choice - I have never seen the added value - but we respect it. It is necessary that things be clear and the mandate set out for me by the European Council with Parliament, and that I assume, on behalf of the Commission, with the confidence of President Juncker and soon that of Ursula von der Leyen, is to reach an agreement. But it requires two things, ladies and gentlemen. First, to tell the truth - here in Parliament, and to the citizens - about the consequences of Brexit. You have to tell the truth. You were talking about respect for British citizens: Both British citizens and other European citizens have a right to the truth about the consequences of Brexit. All the consequences, which are much more serious, much more numerous than you will say. You owe that truth and you will be held to account. After Brexit, you will be accountable to the citizens, as we will have to account for. So we are preparing to tell this truth, as we have always said, about the consequences of a Brexit with a deal - to which we are working - and, of course, with more serious consequences, of a Brexit without a deal. Nevertheless, I am responding in particular to the question of Mr Newton Dunn, as for others, we have prepared the hypothesis of a Brexit without agreement, including on issues of security and cooperation with Europol. Obviously the no deal is not a destination, it is a temporary state and then we will have to resume the discussion to build a partnership. So I have been working for three years with this first requirement: to tell, always and to everyone, the truth. The second requirement is very simple: it is to find legal solutions. Because we make a treaty, we do not make a speech, we do not make a statement, we make a treaty. We need to find serious legal answers to all the questions caused by the separation that you have chosen, which is Brexit, both in Ireland and in all other areas, fisheries and many others, that is and find concrete and operational solutions. Not intentions, nor wishes, but concrete and operational solutions. That is what we expect from Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his team: alternative proposals, as President Juncker has said, so that if we challenge the backstop or other issues, we can answer the questions that Brexit causes. This is the second requirement I work with. We are ready to continue day and night, no one should doubt our availability. As far as I am concerned, as long as I am trusted, I will continue to work on behalf of the Union, with this responsibility, sincerity and determination.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, in spite of all the current uncertainty on the UK side, we have to remain open to new ideas, should they lead to a breakthrough consistent with our principles. Achieving an orderly withdrawal of the UK has to remain our priority until the very last moment, given the negative consequences of a hard Brexit. Until then, we have to continue our preparation for all eventualities, including through targeted measures at EU level, in order to reduce the potential impact on citizens and businesses. However, we must also be ready to consider the extension of the Article 50 period if we receive a duly motivated request from the UK Government. May I remind you that patience is a virtue. We will count on your cooperation at all the stages of these processes. Thank you very much for your opinions and remarks and for your attention.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received two motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, September 18, 2019. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Attila ARA-KOVÁCS
text: Writing. Today's debate on the state of Brexit has shown that those who are driven not by emotion but by deliberate and conscious decisions will be better off avoiding the conflict caused by Brexit. Union leaders are sticking to that, while the Brexit Party is only making a loud noise. It has also become clear that Britain's departure will weaken the far right in the European Parliament in a terrible way, and its return is not small. All this means two clear defeats for Viktor Orban at the same time. On the one hand, it is losing many allies by leaving the Brexiteers. The opportunity that made Fidesz so determined at the beginning of the year is that it will be unable to "transform" the union into a club of loose far-right nation-state governments like Matteo Salvini and Marine Le Pen. At the same time, it is suspected that, in exchange for retaining membership of the European People's Party, Orban will be forced to stand behind the EU's Brexit policy. That hasn't been so clear for a very long time. What does that mean? That he betrayed Salvini in the spring, and now he's betraying the Brexiteers in the fall. This is a difficult situation and a prospect for Fidesz, which had dreamed months earlier that its leader, Viktor Orban, would soon become a key figure in EU policy.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – I supported and voted in favour of this resolution on Brexit. At the heart of my preoccupations and at the heart of all politicians’ responsibilities both in the UK and in Europe there should be the rights and lives of citizens that will be affected by Brexit: whether a no—deal Brexit or a Brexit with a deal. Politicians should be keep this as priority number one. This resolution recalls that safeguarding the rights and life choices, including the employment status and social entitlements, of EU citizens resident in the UK and British citizens resident in the EU27 remains its first priority and that all endeavours should be undertaken to try to ensure that those citizens are not affected by the UK’s withdrawal from the EU. It encourages the UK and the EU27 to adopt measures that provide legal certainty for EU citizens resident in the UK and British citizens resident in the EU27, and recalls its position that the EU27 should pursue a consistent and generous approach in protecting the rights of British citizens resident in the Member States.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – From your speech, Honourable President of the Commission, it does not seem that more progress has been made since the appointment of the new Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and has provided more clarity on the details of the withdrawal. As the UK leaves the European Union, the situation remains extremely tense and uncertain as the UK leaves the European Union. I fully agree with you that the ongoing situation for more than two years is putting a lot of strain on business and our citizens. The European Union is indeed demonstrating great solidarity and is working very hard to ensure that Brexit has the least negative impact on both the UK and the European Union itself, but we are missing out on the United Kingdom's side. The Commission has done a great deal of work on brexit proposals. I myself am the rapporteur for the European Globalisation Fund, which will be ready to provide assistance to EU citizens who have lost their jobs as a result of Brexit. I very much hope that, in very little time, a rational solution is possible and that we will avoid the withdrawal of the United Kingdom without a treaty.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – Brexit is an unprecedented and regrettable event, which unfortunately, due to a sequence of wrong decisions by the UK Government, is turning into a negative epoch for the British political system. However, as a Socialist I must prioritise the needs of the millions of EU citizens working and studying in the UK, whose rights and well—being this Parliament is duty—bound to protect, with or without a deal. In this light and despite the fact that politically the ball is in the UK Government’s court, I firmly believe that our intentions and efforts should be directed to break the deadlock and not allow a no—deal Brexit. We ought to provide legal certainties to our people instead of leaving our businesses importing/exporting to UK with questions on customs and our expats with unresolved status, whilst inducing the risks of a hard Irish border. If this Parliament intends to follow reason in this case, especially following the UK Parliament’s Act on 9th September 2019, an extension of talks is the reasonable path we ought to take to safeguard the well—being of millions of persons along with the smooth continuation of European enterprises’ operations.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – I agree with the Council's statement, which is clear and firm on Brexit. Clara was also the position of the Commission and Parliament. The European institutions did not want Brexit and, even more so, they do not want a messy exit. We are all also European citizens, in addition to the national citizenship we have. We have a responsibility to represent the interest of citizens. That is why I call on the Commission, the designated Brexit negotiator and the Council to ensure the protection of European citizens living in the UK, as well as UK citizens living in EU countries. The integrity of the internal market must be ensured.  The UK must sign a trade agreement with the EU that will have to comply with EU product conditions and standards. The responsibility for the negative effects on the citizens of the United Kingdom, and we must say it clearly and explicitly to the citizens, lies with those politicians who have manipulated with misleading information, saying that the UK will have free access to the market, that they will remain with the same rights, but will win because they will no longer contribute to the EU budget. As a Romanian, I know that Romania has considerable trade and they will suffer. The EU loses an important EU member, but is obliged to comply with the Treaty.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: in writing – Many think it would be better for everyone if the UK remained in the EU, but if a British government based on the results of a free referendum wants to bring Brexit to an end, then we must respect that will democratically. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that our citizens working and studying in the British Isles are least affected by this Brexit. We must ensure that the functioning of the single market is not disrupted and that London fulfils its financial obligations to the Union. We can sympathise with those who want to reverse Brexit, but we cannot force the UK to withdraw its request to leave the Union. Britain is and will remain an important partner and ally of the European Union after it leaves. Brexit is no tragedy, even if it is a sad epoch in the history of our European Union. Please, let us not be intimidated by catastrophic scenarios about food or medicine shortages. A managed Brexit can be a good start to good relations. As was the case, albeit in a different context, in the case of the division of the former Czechoslovakia, when after the split the two new countries achieved the best possible relations. Today, however, we do not even know if and under what conditions Brexit will happen, and therefore we must be prepared for all possible scenarios, including a hard Brexit.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: In writing. It is now three years since the British voted to leave the EU. And for months the government has been asking to set back this fateful date. We are not immune to a further postponement. At one point, "enough is enough." Brexit uncertainty is plunging Europeans and Britons into total darkness. All sectors of activity but also citizens suffer from this situation. The fishing sector will be particularly affected by Brexit. And I'm not just talking about fishermen. I am also talking about these women and men who cut fish in the morning in our auctions. These fishing grounds, these processors and all these trades that live off fishing. The whole industry will be affected. Entire territories will be impacted. Access to British waters for mainland fishermen and access to European waters for British fishermen are rights and customs that go back to times that no one here can claim to know and that Brexit cannot destroy! There is an urgent need to take action and to give opportunities to fisheries, as they do to all of Europe.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Eighty years since the start of WWII, which devastated our continent, we once again allowed the obscure forces of populism and extreme nationalism to return to our societies. How quickly we forgot the post-war state of Europe and what the totalitarian regimes and violence brought us. From Bulgaria to the Netherlands, from the North to the South of Europe extremist and xenophobic political forces want to demolish our shared home and we need to fight every day for democracy, freedom and tolerance in Europe. Therefore, I completely support the proposal to commemorate 23 August as the European Day of Remembrance for the victims of totalitarian regimes at both EU and governmental level. It is our duty to raise the younger generation’s awareness of these issues by including the history and analysis of the consequences of totalitarian regimes in the textbooks of all schools in the EU. The memories of Europe’s tragic past must be kept alive. Only then can we teach our children not to repeat the mistakes of the past

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing – Any Member State may leave the EU. It is enough to activate Article 50 of the EU Treaty in a constitutional manner and a two-year preparation period follows. However, the problem is that the Member States are so strongly economically intertwined at the heart of the functioning of the EU that leaving the EU should be the result of a mature reflection by responsible politicians, who will first consider all the pros and cons of this step. Greenland, for example, as an autonomous part of Denmark, left the European Communities in 1985 after a referendum. It didn't match his fishing policy settings. No one was in trouble at the time, and Greenland had a number of agreements with the EU, and relations are working smoothly. A hard Brexit would weaken both Britain and the EU. However, the EU seems to be more. Several banks and insurance houses have already announced that they would move their headquarters from London to Frankfurt or elsewhere to the EU. Britain would lose access to European markets and also to the workforce. From a security point of view, it would no longer be able to participate in common European defence projects and would also lose access to projects such as the Energy Union or the Digital Single Market. Although President Trump has indicated that he wants to give Britain a favourable trade deal, it will hardly be based on the principle of equality or with as many benefits as EU membership.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Union (EU) has maintained a negotiating strategy of respect for the British people and their decisions, while safeguarding the interests of European citizens in the United Kingdom and remaining united in the definition of a fair exit agreement that is a factor of stability and reference.  The resolution signed by the largest political groups, currently under consideration and approval in this Parliament, highlights the virtualities of the exit agreement signed between the parties, in particular with regard to the steps to be taken and the transitional rules, to ensure an orderly exit of the United Kingdom from the EU, which does not make a good political, economic and social relationship between the parties impossible. The safeguards to be adopted in the event of exit without agreement and the circumstances which could justify further an extension of the period of application of Article 50 are also defined.  As an MEP and as a citizen I would like the UK to remain in the EU, but I respect the sovereign will of its people. In this context, I will do everything i can to guarantee, with or without agreement, the rights of European citizens and businesses, and so I see myself in the resolution under discussion in today's plenary session.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: John HOWARTH
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, first I would thank the shadow rapporteurs and the secretariat for their work on this file. I will be brief but it’s important that these points are put on the record. This draft amending budget No 2 is somewhat different to the norm. It is in fact the final element of the 2019 budget settlement, negotiated last December in the second conciliation between Parliament and the Member States in Council.  The agreement with the Council was that the final element would be presented as an amending budget during 2019, so today we complete that agreement by reinforcing two programmes which, more than any others, reflect in their outcomes the economies of scale and added value of the Union budget, Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020. The heavily oversubscribed student programme will receive an additional EUR 20 million and Horizon will receive EUR 80 million, which will fund research into technologies that will help address the climate emergency. This investment budget reflects the truth that our collective endeavours as a Union enable us to achieve more than any Member State in or out of the Union would achieve alone. I thank the House for its indulgence and recommend your support.  (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments pending explanations of vote)

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Mr President, I voted against on the British resolution because it’s a divorce and I think that we should keep in mind the future relationship, which should not result in a conflict. We are trying to force the British Parliament into consenting to the agreement which has already been rejected three times. I remember when we had a divorce in Czechoslovakia. To have a successful divorce, there must be a kind of generosity. If we had professed the same kind of a generosity as the European Parliament has done, the Czechoslovak split would have resulted in a conflict or even a war. Is that something that we are really seeking?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am from the same country as my colleague Alexander Vondra, yet I voted in favour of this resolution. Precisely because I respect the resolution of the British Parliament, which says that the United Kingdom must not leave without a deal. That is why I believe that the European Parliament has reacted correctly by proposing a possible postponement in the event that no agreement is concluded. We are not usuding our agreement to great Britain, it is an agreement signed by their Prime Minister. Great Britain can make amendments to this agreement, it can negotiate change, but it has not tabled any change. The European Parliament is showing great patience and willingness, just as the negotiator, Michel Barnier, is willing to change this agreement if the United Kingdom proposes any changes.

name: Luisa PORRITT
text: – Mr President, I have voted in support of this resolution today, not because I want to see the Withdrawal Agreement implemented, since any form of Brexit would be damaging and regrettable for all, but because the text acknowledges an extension is possible in order to avoid no-deal and for the UK to hold a democratic event, such as a referendum or general election, as well as to revoke Article 50 outright.  I want to thank the pro-Europeans across this House, who continue to show solidarity with us in the face of the dangerous nationalist populist drive begun by a man in that part of the Chamber, who only turns up here to stamp his feet and collect his allowance. The same desire to put personal ambition over our common and national interests unfortunately now emanates from Number 10 Downing Street. However, there is also a strong, and growing, pro-European movement happening in the UK. It is indeed, perhaps, now the strongest in Europe, as Guy Verhofstadt has previously said. To my pro-European colleagues, who make up the majority in this House, I say we must continue to work together to defeat the forces of nationalism and populism and not let them win.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Mr President, I voted against Mr Verhofstadt’s empire resolution. I believe in a clean -break Brexit. Why do I believe that? 58 % of people in the East Midlands voted to leave. 62 % in coastal communities like Folkestone and Hythe voted to leave. 17.4 million people in the UK – the democratic majority – voted to leave. For the past three hours here, in the European Parliament, I’ve listened to all sorts of MEPs telling those people they didn’t know what they were doing. Telling those people that they have to listen to the EU and only when they agree with this institution can they even begin to have some sense of democracy. Mr Barnier made it absolutely clear that, whatever the backstop deal may or may not be, there will be no escape from the Customs Union for the 17.4 million people who voted to leave. British democracy must be respected. It’s time to leave. It’s time for a clean-break Brexit.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Mr President, I supported the resolution today because it recognises the prospect of Britain revoking Article 50 to stop Brexit. I believe that this will happen, because Boris Johnson has no majority in the UK Parliament. That is why he has tried to shut Parliament down and is blocking a people’s vote on the specific Withdrawal Agreement. The 2016 referendum was vague and with much misinformation: lies about money and lies that Turkey would join this European Union. I see no Turkish MEPs here. Boris Johnson said it would be easy and make us better off. He no longer pretends that is true.  The 2016 decision is old and stale. Britain in 2019 is a different place, and young people want the European Union. No one voted for food or medicine shortages, for blocked ports or motorways, which our government admits are real risks. We can do so much better than Brexit, we are a great country and we will put this behind us.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Mr President, today I voted in favour of Parliament’s Brexit motion. I don’t like May’s deal and I don’t like Brexit – I hate it – but any deal should go in front of the people. It’s their future, but Boris is playing with it for his own party’s sake. What voters want is for Brexit to stop. My party, of Jo Swinson and the Liberal Democrats, are committed to the EU and its citizens. When we become the Government, we will revoke Article⁰50 to stop Brexit altogether. Our aim is to stay inside the European Union. This motion recognises our responsibility to Brexit’s citizens. They chose to build lives somewhere else, as is their right. Their lives have been in turmoil. EU governments must now all work to sort this out quickly. Citizenship is a right. We are setting up another Windrush scandal and it must not happen. I and the Lib Dems are – and always will be – committed to doing what is best for the UK and the EU. We need time to vote on the deal or to choose to stay with all the benefits of full membership.

name: Barbara Ann GIBSON
text: – Mr President, I voted in support of this resolution and urged Parliament’s support. I would like to make clear that I do not support any Brexit deal. Whether deal or no-deal, I believe with all my heart that any Brexit is bad for the UK and for the European Union, and I will continue to campaign to stop Brexit. But this motion is important because it specifically recognises that the UK Parliament enacted a law to require the Prime Minister to ask for an extension, and it supports an extension being granted to avoid a no-deal exit, hold an election or referendum, or revoke Brexit altogether.  Boris Johnson is not acting in the interests of UK citizens. He has shut down Parliament. He states that he will break the law to bring about Brexit, no matter the consequences. He is acting as a dictator and we need time to defeat him through the democratic process.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, well, this wasn’t the plan, was it? Instead of sunlit uplands, the best we are offered is survival. Instead of the easiest trade deal in history, we face negotiating from the weakest position possible, of no deal at all. Instead of the restoration of the sovereignty that we never in fact lost, we face the harsh reality of a powerful neighbour making rules in which we will have no say but which market reality will dictate that we have little option but to follow.
