Entire industries sacrificed, market shares squandered, world leadership trashed, the rights and freedoms of every British citizen diminished: that’s the reality of this Brexit. Not at all what was said on the tin! What on earth has been won? Britain outside the European Union will discover soon enough that national sovereignty in the modern world has serious limitations. We hear a lot about democracy, but without accountability democracy withers. Take your false promises and your reality back to the British people and let them decide the reality of Brexit. (Aplause)

name: Michael HEAVER
text: – Mr President, dear oh dear, well, after that delusional guff, let me reassure everyone in the Chamber that Nigel Farage does indeed still speak for the pro—Brexit majority in my country. And, as for this resolution, dear oh dear, a ‘regrettable event’ is what you’re calling Brexit. Well, maybe for you, with the UK cash cow out the door, but the British people clearly don’t agree with you. Look around: the biggest party in this Chamber, the Brexiteers, we’re standing up and we’re making sure that the pro—Leave majority are represented. As for the Withdrawal Agreement being fair and balanced: as they say in my country, you must be having a laugh. We’ve seen straight through it. The Brexit Party is highlighting why it’s wrong for our country, why it’s the worst deal in history and we are fighting hard now for a clean-break Brexit. And you need to face up to the fact that, in our country, support for no-deal is rising. We’ve got the establishment on the run. We beat you in 2016 and we’ll do it again. The Brexit Party is here to stay and we will leave the European Union. (Applause)

name: Lucy NETHSINGHA
text: – Mr President, first, I would like to thank this wonderful democratic institution for your support for the UK and your patience in backing a further extension of Article 50. A no-deal Brexit would be utterly terrifying for many UK and EU citizens. The risks are highest for the most vulnerable. One such group are those living in the UK who depend upon medicines imported from Europe. There are large numbers of people whose health depends on the smooth and reliable importation of medicines which have a short shelf-life and require refrigeration. No one can guarantee that these medicines will be able to get through in the transport chaos that would follow a no-deal Brexit. That any government is even contemplating putting such vulnerable citizens deliberately at risk is a truly shocking situation. It is the need to prevent this risk that has led Members from across the House of Commons and in this House bitterly to oppose a no-deal Brexit. There is no mandate for a no-deal Brexit and no one voted to deny themselves or their neighbours crucial medicines. The risks of a no-deal Brexit are very real but, in the longer term, any Brexit deal puts the UK citizens in a worse position.

name: Martin Edward DAUBNEY
text: – Mr President, first of all like I’d like to say it’s wonderful to see a few of the British MEPs turning up for the vote earlier. Where were they for the entire debate? They were probably in the bar having croissants. The rest of it has been a blizzard of lies, smears, half-truths and blatant misrepresentations. And, as for the ludicrous assumption that Britain operates under a dictator, dictators don’t offer general elections, do they? (Cheers from certain quarters) And when they do offer general elections you do not accept them because you know that Corbyn and Labour will be obliterated across the Midlands, North and Wales, especially in Ashfield where I intend to stand and help destroy Jeremy Corbyn and the ruthless mess he’s left, where he has abandoned the working classes. Seventy percent of people in Ashfield, my local constituency, voted to leave. Corbyn doesn’t care about them, this House doesn’t care about the British voice. This Parliament does not understand the British people. It does not represent the British people and it will not stop 17.4 million voices from being heard. We’re leaving. Auf Wiedersehen. Bye. Au revoir. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, let me say it as it is, because the wording of this resolution in places is mealy-mouthed. On the issue of citizens’ rights and the protection of EU nationals in the UK, that is not just a cause of concern. The treatment of those people has been a total disgrace and it brings shame on my country, the country that I love, the country equally loved by those EU nationals who have made their homes, set up businesses, worked in our public services and paid taxes in the UK for decades. They deserve better than this shambolic ‘settled status’ scheme. So my message to those EU nationals in the UK who I’m proud to represent in the East Midlands, and to friends from across the other Member States here, is: my country is better than this. Those EU nationals deserve better than this.

name: Jane BROPHY
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this resolution but I do not want Brexit at all. One of the most crucial points in this resolution for me, as a UK health professional for over two decades, concerns the employment status and social entitlements of EU and UK citizens. The ability of staff from the EU to work for the UK health service – the NHS – remains severely threatened by Brexit. Three years ago, 11% of staff employed by the NHS were from other EU Member States. That figure has now halved to just over 5.5%. This huge reduction in numbers is due to people being fearful about the right to remain in the UK if Brexit were to happen, and uncertainty about social entitlements in the event of a no—deal Brexit. So, this resolution is welcome. It will offer assurance to EU workers living and working in the UK that their rights will remain the number one priority in the EU.

name: Judith BUNTING
text: – Mr President, this is the hardest vote that I have ever cast. I wholeheartedly welcome Parliament’s commitment to an extension of Article 50, but any withdrawal agreement must go back to the British people. In a referendum, if it was put to the people now with the option to remain, I am confident that we would now win the vote to stop Brexit. Why? Because this time, young people will come out to vote. Youngsters in Britain are angry. Around three-quarters of kids who were too young to vote back in 2016 and have now reached that voting age, say that they back remain. So, wherever you come from, other Europeans, please go back to your leaders and ask them in Council to support any bid for an extension. Please give British youngsters a chance to decide their own future.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Mr President, I’d like to explain why I voted in favour of a resolution which supports the Brexit agreement already negotiated between the UK and the EU, but remains stuck in the UK Parliament. It is because this resolution also keeps open the possibility of the UK reviewing its position through a people’s vote, or indeed a change of government. It does this by supporting a further extension of Article 50 for the UK to consider its position. A no—deal Brexit would be a disaster for the British farming industry and for British farmers. Ninety—seven percent of our lamb exports are to the EU27, and we also export considerable levels of beef, cereals and other foodstuffs. Losing this marketplace would not be in the interest of my constituents. My first duty, therefore, is to prevent a no—deal Brexit. Then, to go on to secure continued UK membership of the European Union.

name: Chris DAVIES
text: – Mr President, I don’t want a managed Brexit: I want to stop Brexit. In this House we stand for European values that I regard also as British and liberal values. We stand for an economy that benefits all. We stand for environmental measures that protect all. I don’t want my country to be shut out of the rooms where decisions about the future of our continent will be made. I don’t want my country to run away from the issues facing our continent. I want us to be at the heart of the European Union. I want us to be a leader, not a leaver. My view is simple and blunt: bollocks to Brexit! (Hubbub)

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – Mr President, as the Brexit deadline looms over our heads, concerns and risks of having a disorderly no-deal exit of the UK are becoming a sad and lousy reality. No agreement would be a recipe for disaster – a catastrophe that should be avoided. Unfortunately, the uncertainties and political instabilities are growing by the hour. Our first priority in this situation remains to safeguard the rights and choices of the EU citizens resident in the UK and the British citizens resident in the EU. A hard Brexit would economically be highly damaging to business, threatening thousands of jobs, both in the UK and in the Union.  Our second priority must be to assist business and workers to ensure that burdens and costs are kept at a minimum. Finally, the highly damaging implications that a no-deal exit would have for the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland should be kept to a minimum. Working together to undertake all reasonable efforts and engage in constructive dialogue to avoid a no-deal scenario must always come before petty party politics.

name: Dinesh DHAMIJA
text: – Mr President, as a businessman, I cannot understand why any entrepreneur would want to give up a market of 512 million people for a 65 million market. The low-hanging fruit is so great with 500 million people, with seasonality and everything else. As the founder of eBookers.com, I saw my sales go up to a billion dollars in five years, and the reason is that we had a market of 300 million people. None of my competitors who were just selling to 60 million people in the UK could keep up. What will most entrepreneurs do if we Brexit? Open an office in Dublin or Amsterdam or Frankfurt or Paris and move jobs to these cities. Talk about shooting ourselves in the foot!

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Mr President, Mr Patten over there clearly doesn’t understand that 62% of voters is not the same as 62% of people – lying once again.  As we saw in the Windrush scandal, our government knows a thing or two about cruelly splitting families and this is exactly what they plan to do again. Europe is a family of nations and peoples and allowing the Tories to wrench us out of this family will cause untold harm, both to the UK and to our European friends and partners. Just as Brexit will divide the European family of nations, I fear it will be the death knell of the British family of nations.  Born in England, raised in Scotland, I consider myself a child of two nations, of two unions: British and European. Our United Kingdom is 218 years old and Johnson, Farage and their braying lackeys are about to sabotage it. These saboteurs have betrayed the people of Northern Ireland and ridden roughshod over the rights of Scotland and I have a warning for them – the English have tried many times to infringe the rights of Scotland and we risk seeing a generation of William Wallaces if Johnson is allowed to continue.

name: Sheila RITCHIE
text: – Mr President, I voted for this. On 2 December, the Belfast Agreement – the last peace agreement made inside Europe – will have its 20th birthday. It’s guaranteed by this European Union. Saturday is International Peace Day. I fear for that peace if we are thrown out as a consequence of the lies, self interest and distortion of the Leave campaign and the ever absent Nigel Farage – a man who simply doesn’t care.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to comment on the vote that has already taken place. I respect, of course, the decision of the British people in the context of Brexit, but at the same time I am glad that this resolution, which is why I also supported it, allows brexit to be postponed if, of course, the United Kingdom decides to do so. It is also necessary to respect the decision reached by the European Court of Justice that the activation of Article 50 can be unilaterally withdrawn. It is important to me that we protect the rights of EU citizens living in the British Isles and, of course, we do not want any hard border that threatens peaceful coexistence on the island of Ireland. These are about two limits, which this resolution also contains, and I was therefore happy to support them. On the other hand, to what colleagues on the left of the spectrum are saying here, from the Brexit Party: I want to remind them that they only won their seats because of the European electoral system, because according to national rules almost no one, any Brexit Party MEMBER, would be elected.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí mé an-sásta leis an díospóireacht a bhí againn anseo ar maidin maidir leis an Ríocht Aontaithe ag fágáil an Aontais. Thaispeáin na Feisirí go dtuigeann siad cad atá i gceist leis, go dtuigeann siad an tábhacht a bhaineann leis an gcúlstad mar a mhínigh an tUasal Barnier dóibh é, agus go dtuigeann siad an tábhacht a bhaineann le Comhaontú Aoine an Chéasta agus go gcaithfimid é sin a chosaint. Agus an vóta a bhí anseo againn ó chianaibh - 544 i bhfabhar, 126 i gcoinne - is móramh mór é sin.  Freisin, bhí mé an-sásta gur éist na Feisirí liom agus go bhfuil siad sásta síneadh ama a thabhairt don Phríomh-Aire, Boris Johnson, má lorgaíonn sé é sin. Dá bhrí sin, ní fhéadfaimis níos mó a dhéanamh ag an tráth seo. Is féidir a rá gur lá maith é don Aontas - drochlá, b’fhéidir, don Bhreatimeacht - agus is maith sin.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, they may not have intended to, but colleagues in this House have just made an orderly Brexit with a deal much less likely. The UK has accepted in the Withdrawal Agreement a number of disagreeable and difficult concessions – a continuing role for the ECJ, asymmetric arbitration mechanism, a GBP 39 billion bill that no international tribunal would uphold. The only thing which it wouldn’t accept is replacing a status that has an exit mechanism, i.e. EU membership, with one that doesn’t, i.e. the backstop, and by insisting on that point in this declaration, this House has made it almost impossible to see a way that the two sides could have orderly and amicable withdrawal resolutions.  I have to say, this idea that we’re suffering a Brexit crisis is based on something that you all fail to notice – that Brexit hasn’t happened! What we’re seeing is the opposite of the Brexit crisis. We’re seeing an un-Brexit crisis. We’re seeing a crisis caused by the refusal of our opposition parliamentarians to do what they promised when they sought election. There will be a reckoning for them when the election comes. I just hope that the legitimacy and authority of our parliamentary institutions isn’t collateral damage.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Dear President, I am very sorry that British politicians are competing with Brexit. Brexit has become an asset, not a target, and that's bad. No one here is going to win, and it seems as if everyone, except for the exceptions, is trying to make the damage as small as possible.  It is easy to extend the withdrawal date, but only if justified, in the case of a specific reason, such as an election, a referendum or the time needed to ratify the agreement. Moreover, with all this process, we must also be aware that every step must be done to protect our interests, our citizens, our values. On The Island, they are working hard to glue the black dot to European politicians. But you should actually stick it to yourself. And if there is a no-deal exit, they will be the only ones who will have to answer to their citizens.

name: Irina VON WIESE
text: – Mr President, when I moved to the UK from Germany over 20 years ago, I came to a global Britain that welcomed me with open arms. Britain’s EU membership has afforded me rights and guarantees and allowed me to build a life in the country I love. But today three million EU citizens in the UK face a climate of fear and uncertainty. Boris Johnson promised that they would not be disadvantaged by Brexit. He has broken this promise like so many others. The settlement scheme is not fit for purpose. It has been marred with technical problems and has left many, particularly the most vulnerable, unable to prove their eligibility. We must have a system that is easy to use, a system whereby people can simply register – not one where they have to find dozens of documents dating back many years – otherwise we risk another Windrush scandal on a much greater scale. This is why I voted for the resolution. But let’s face the fact: the only way to guarantee citizens’ rights in Britain is to stop Brexit.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 162) on the fight against cancer (2019/2818(RSP)). I would like to inform Members that for this debate there is no catch-the-eye procedure and that no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, representatives of the Council, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. More than 40% of Europeans, including the people in this Chamber, will develop cancer in their lives. We all know the feeling that comes with it: helplessness, you don't want to see it. You listen to the doctors, you reject reality, and you still know that every second cancer patient will die from it. You feel powerless. These are the feelings behind this existential question of 'cancer', and that is why this question is our question, our political question at European level. Three out of four Europeans have called for the fight against cancer to become a top issue in Europe, according to surveys. We in the European People's Party, we want precisely this: to meet this demand of europeans. European researchers have already shown us what medical progress can achieve. Breast cancer, for example, now cures eight out of ten patients. Together with 15 leading cancer researchers, from Finland to Portugal, from France to Romania, we, as the EPP – and I also have a leading candidate – presented a master plan this spring that can make Europe more effective in the fight against cancer. Why Europe? Ladies and gentlemen, cancer is quite complex and occurs in countless forms. For example, in children, 40 000 cases of extremely rare cancers are diagnosed every year. In this area, if we work together, Europe can achieve much more scientific success if we cooperate and cooperate simply because of the sheer scale of the cases and the data behind them. 18 000 oncologists, 15 000 hospitals, 107 cancer research institutes in Europe, 179 universities dealing with it. If we succeed in tying this data together, if we succeed in developing a common plan in the fight against cancer, then we will be more successful. Professor Angelika Eggert of the Charité in Berlin, for example, wrote to me: With an ambitious European approach, we can successfully cure nine out of ten children's cancer patients in ten years. Professor Thierry Philip, from Paris, added: "In the combination of prevention and early detection, with the help of personalized medicine, we could simply double the survival rates of patients with malignant tumours. That is feasible, and we must address it now.  What concrete action should be done? We need a common cancer prevention strategy first. Let's avoid cancer together in the first place! Secondly, we must finally bring together all our existing national cancer databases, create a European digital data centre for these cancer files, so that we can fight cancer earlier. We need a common early detection strategy: let us successfully cure cancer in time! Fourthly, we must not leave anyone behind. Especially in Central and Eastern European countries, cancer patients are now 30% less likely to be cured than in Western European countries. This state of affairs is unacceptable in Europe, and that is why modern forms of telemedicine can raise a great deal in standards in Central and Eastern Europe. Last but not least, let us also remember the relatives affected by these cancer cases. A cancer patient initiative that takes into consideration the concerns of relatives should be our common goal. It is important for us as the European People's Party to start now. We have been given a new mandate by the citizens of Europe, and now it is up to us to make progress. That is why we in the European People's Party are not just asking for the debate to take place today; not only do we request that we need further priorities in this master plan, based on the work done by the Commission to date, but we in the European People's Party also want there to be a special committee of the European Parliament in the future to deal with this cancer strategy as a committee. It's our concern - we want to take it up.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it’s an honour to address this Assembly today to discuss the fight against cancer as part of this topical debate. It comes at the right point in time. Recently published research shows that cancer is already on course to become the leading cause of death in most EU countries, as mortality due to cardiovascular diseases is decreasing. The same research shows that for cancer the high mortality is not mainly related to risk factors but might be correlated to access to healthcare.  As we know, cancer is a disease that more often strikes older people. We Europeans who live longer than in other parts of the world are therefore more prone to get cancer. So how do we tackle the increasing challenge that cancer poses to our societies? Do we resign in the face of fate or do we fight back? I think we have chosen as the EU to fight back.  The Finnish Presidency firmly believes that the EU needs to put people at the centre of policymaking. We propose to start by embracing a new concept, the ‘economy of well-being’. The economy of well-being is a holistic, multi-sectoral approach that highlights the need to invest in people and their health. We think health and access to healthcare are fundamental for well-being and see health as an investment. We propose to invest in prevention and health promotion. All EU citizens should have the possibility to lead a healthy life and acquire good health habits as those are cornerstones in the prevention of cancer: They should also have equal access to healthcare, which is one of the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights and supports the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. With such high goals set, there is a need for close collaboration between different institutions, stakeholders and sectors. More specifically, in the EU there seems to be agreement that cancer should be a priority. That requires action through different means such as research, access to treatment, and screening. In April this year, Parliament and the Council provisionally agreed to include a cancer mission in the future Horizon Europe, the next research and innovation framework programme. More research will allow us to better understand cancer, put in place better prevention and diagnostic methods, and allow for better treatment options, as well as allowing Member States to better tailor public health interventions. Many of you have on several occasions asked the Commission for strong actions against cancer in general, but also for actions targeted against specific types of cancer. You notably established a cancer group. Political groups have taken action and you have adopted resolutions asking the Commission and the Member States to intensify their efforts to fight cancer. On the Council side, Member States are also very concerned about cancer. The Council dedicated several sets of conclusions, as well as a Council recommendation on cancer screening, to this important challenge.  At Member State level, action was taken to strengthen the means of healthcare systems to face this challenge. The Commission has also reacted to our calls and cancer is one of the main priorities in the incoming Commission. The European plan to fight cancer that we expect the Commission to propose should have strong links to the Horizon Europe cancer mission.  We welcome efforts aiming at strengthening EU cooperation on cancer prevention. In our view, it is important that Member States learn from each other and that good practices are disseminated and promoted. This would contribute to ensuring that all EU citizens are given equal opportunities to lead a healthy life with minimal risk of developing cancer.  We are looking forward to the new plan to be proposed by the Commission. We count on the Commission to involve Member States, wherever appropriate, in the development of that plan. We also stand ready to cooperate with Parliament in raising awareness on cancer as one of the main killers in Europe. Thank you very much for this discussion and for your attention.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is probably my last speech before this Chamber, so allow me to be a little bit personal. Anyway, I believe I have full legitimacy to get personal when speaking about cancer. I know first—hand the emotional and physical consequences of this disease, having lost three beloved brothers. I know how it feels when you are face to face with a diagnosis and you know it is too late. Therefore, let me be clear. If we want to get serious about beating cancer, we need to start putting our money into the remedies that cannot be prescribed only by a doctor or health commissioner. It is a political question. I agree with you, Mr Weber: these remedies are in the hands of those who make policies on risk factors and determinants – commercial, social and political determinants – which facilitate risk factors. These remedies are in our own hands as well, when we smoke, eat junk food or abuse alcohol. And it is about the economy of well-being – I agree with Madam Minister. In 2014, when I took up my position as Commissioner for Health and Food Safety, I announced that one of my major priorities was the promotion and protection of health and the prevention of diseases. I preached for this but the paradigm shift is yet to come. However, we have worked hard and we have achieved some tangible results. Tobacco consumption fell, through legislation and anti—smoking campaigns. European Union legislation on chemicals, pesticides and exposure to carcinogens, including at work, was upgraded. We have spread the word on prevention, particularly thanks to the improvement of the European Code Against Cancer. The European Cancer Information System (ECIS) is now up and running and accessible – it monitors geographic patterns and cancer trends – along with national cancer plans to be adopted. In recent years we have seen continuous improvement in the coverage and quality of national screening programmes for breast, cervical, and colorectal cancer. As you know, October is a month dedicated to breast cancer and I have my ribbon especially for that occasion. Better vaccination coverage will impact on infections and cancers caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and hepatitis B. In this context, I am proud to inform you that last week the Commission, together with the World Health Organisation (WHO), organised the first global vaccination summit, where immunisation against HPV was placed high on the agenda. Also, since March 2017, we have established 24 European reference networks, of which four are dealing specifically with rare and complex cancers, especially in children. This is across the European Union. We took a major step forward in terms of alcohol nutrition labelling and finally came to a consensus. I have cooperated fully with the European Cancer Organisation to help increase awareness. The new Regulations on Medical Devices entered into force on 25 May 2017. Furthermore, we have taken the ambitious decision to evaluate jointly the EU Orphan Regulation and the EU Regulation on Medicines for Children because cancer treatment for children is a very challenging issue. This work is not finished: we will continue to add to it. I wish I could have done more, as we are facing important societal challenges, such as an aging population with multimorbidity. There is a growing cost of non-communicable diseases and new treatments, and unfortunately we are still only spending about three percent of our resources on prevention. This is a drop in the ocean. We need to increase this amount and make sure that what we spend is spent effectively. One way to achieve this is by sharing best practices between Member States. The European Union Steering Group on Health Promotion, Disease Prevention and Management of Non—Communicable Diseases is very valuable in this respect as it identifies Member States’ priorities and highlights best practices that can be transferred, scaled up and implemented with European Union support. The Commission’s Best Practice Portal has proved to be a powerful tool as it picks up top-quality practices that can be adapted and reproduced across Europe. The interactive EU Health Policy Platform also helps civil society, including patients’ organisations and health professionals, to promote debate about public health concerns and especially concerns related to cancer. We also deliver the State of Health in the EU cycle that will help Member States to create better health care policies for those who suffer from cancer. Communicating risks to citizens and enabling healthy choices are vital parts of any prevention strategy. We have put a lot of effort, including in relation to healthy food, into the common agricultural policy, and so on. Technological and scientific developments offer immense potential when it comes to cancer prevention, treatment and care. For example, we can expect a future where we will have much more precise treatments based upon the genomic signature of the patient. I am very glad that we have already started the European ‘1+ Million Genomes’ Initiative. Investment in research and innovation has been a long-standing priority for the Commission. Through its Framework Programme for Research, the Commission has invested some EUR 2.8 billion since 2007 on prevention, diagnostics, therapeutics, cost—effectiveness and the quality of life of patients and cancer survivors. From 2021 onwards, Horizon Europe will promote open science and maximize the potential for innovation. In the proposal for Horizon Europe, the Commission has introduced the mission approach, which would help to build coalitions to address the most pressing global European challenges including cancer. One of the first mission areas identified for Horizon Europe is action on cancer to mobilise a broad spectrum of stakeholders, including citizens, patients and all those who care for them. I also believe that the work that began with the European reference networks for rare diseases can pave the way to a better ecosystem for patients, with big data, artificial intelligence, universities and industry working together building big ecosystems, or maybe some health ‘collider’, especially addressing cancer. I will be more than happy to see that in the future. I want to say a few words on an ongoing initiative that plays a key role in the discussions about innovation. The Commission’s proposal for a regulation to strengthen European Union cooperation on health technology assessment (HTL) aims to facilitate access to innovative health technology, and access to treatment is a major issue today. The proposal has already passed the European Parliament scrutiny process. I count on your continued support to make this initiative a success and I would like the Finnish Presidency to finalise the work on this issue. All these are important steps in the right direction, but it is essential that this progress, this innovation and these developments reach the patients who need them the most. I am pleased to see that the Commissioner—designate’s mission letter focuses on ways to help ensure that Europe has a supply of affordable medicines to meet its needs. I am also delighted that the Commission’s new President-elect has included the Europe’s Beating Cancer Plan in her political priorities. This is a very important message. Cancer is a relentless disease. Let’s not give up. I thank this House for its support during my time in office. I also seize the opportunity to encourage the Council of the European Union and all the institutions to renew our common determination and political will in the fight against cancer, as was done back in the 1990s when François Mitterrand gave impetus to the Europe against Cancer initiative and it helped us very much for a long time. We must continue to work together to prevent cancer, promote health and improve treatment and care. I look forward to hearing your views. (Applause)

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Every year, more than nine million people die from cancer worldwide. Each European country, depending on its wealth, spends several tens of billions of euros to fight this disease. Can we therefore say that we have won with this greatest killer of the 21st century? Definitely not. Can we do more? Definitely yes. As part of European solidarity, let us join forces, create a European plan for the effective treatment of cancer. Let us create a European cancer prevention strategy and a European strategy for early detection of cancer. Let's give a new impetus to oncology research. Let us create a European partnership programme based on the cooperation of academic centres and specialised hospitals. Let's work together to exchange best practices and experiences from clinical trials. Let us give equal opportunities to the patient in the east and west of Europe. Cancer has no borders or nationalities. Today I ask you, fellow Parliamentarians, to decide bipartisanly to set up a special committee to fight cancer. It's up to us. The president of the political groups, it is up to you to make this request. You have the opportunity to do so in Article 207 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. Finally, I am sure that cancer patients can count on us and we MEPs will not let them down.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, we know that cancer is currently the second leading cause of death in the European Union and that in 2018 there were 3 million new diagnoses. Cancer thus has a major impact on health systems, but also on the European economy. 30 to 50% of these cases could be avoided by reducing risk factors and implementing evidence-based preventive strategies. The current investment of the European Union is insufficient to achieve the objectives we set ourselves. Investment in primary and primary prevention needs to be increased through policies that favour better lifestyles and healthy environments, as well as early detection of cancer. For this it is essential to support scientific research with robust studies, such as cohort studies, so that we can base our decisions on the best possible scientific evidence.

name: Véronique TRILLET-LENOIR
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, who has been practising as an oncologist for 40 years, I thank you very much for proposing this debate. The 4 million people affected in Europe need a European cancer plan. We need the European scale to ensure access to the most innovative medicines, without out of stock and at their fair price. We need the European scale to mobilise more research teams, thanks to the ambitious resources of the Horizon Europe cancer mission. We need the European scale to maintain networks of rare cancers and in particular paediatric cancers, which still kill 6,000 children a year. Cancer is a disease of the body, but it is also a disease of social injustice. Because we are unequal in the face of prevention, unequally protected against environmental carcinogens, unequally informed of the risky behaviours of smoking, poor diet and lack of physical activity. We are unevenly armed against misinformation about the vaccine that protects against cervical cancers. From one country to another in Europe, we are unequal in the face of rapid access to quality care. Finally, in the phase following the disease, we are unequal in our ability to return to work and a harmonious social and emotional life. That is why, Madam President, to want a European plan to fight cancer is of course to reduce the leading cause of death in Europe, but it is also to initiate the reduction of inequalities and thus move towards a more inclusive and just Europe of health.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, ladies and gentlemen, one in three Europeans has cancer in their lifetime. Every year, about 1.3 million people die of cancer in the European Union. These numbers are dramatic and they will increase. We are facing an explosion of chronic diseases and some experts predict that the number of cancer cases in Europe will double by 2035. So it's really an emergency and a priority. This means that the new European plan to fight cancer is expected: prevention - you mentioned this, Commissioner -, diagnosis, treatment, support and palliative care... We can and must improve things in every stage of the disease, that is obvious. But cancer is also an often multifactorial disease, which can take many faces. A European code against cancer has been in place since 1987 and since 2014 it has included twelve common-sense recommendations. It has been said: do not smoke, exercise, prefer a healthy diet, watch out for the sun, watch out for radon. Despite all these recommendations, cancers are still on the rise. What for? Maybe because we are not looking in the right direction. You really have to dare a multifactorial action plan. A plan that would say stop women's night work, which increases the risk of developing breast cancer by 30%. a plan that would ban the use of pesticides to prevent farmers and farm workers from being among those with the highest rates of prostate cancer. An exit plan, Commissioner, of endocrine disruptors and substances of concern to protect the health of consumers and reduce their overall exposure to these chemical residues that are piling up in our organs. A plan to get out of the air pollution we breathe and that makes us sick. We really need to increase prevention. Of course, there is access to medicines for all. Of course, we have to deal with the drug shortage that is emerging. But you have to be hyper-bold and innovative precisely to fight cancer.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I was very disappointed by Mrs von der Leyen's programme, which, although medical, like me, did not mention any commitment on issues such as the revision of the pharmaceutical package, the fate of the HTA and the directive on cross-border care. Yet the polar star of us doctors should be the well-being of our citizens. I hope at least that your announcement on the fight against cancer will be followed up. It is a challenge on which the life expectancy of so many people depends and requires the utmost commitment to prevention, diagnostics and treatment. I would like to draw attention today to an issue involving a quarter of cancer patients in Europe: rare cancers. I am thinking, for example, of rare cancers from paediatric age, so medical knowledge is recent and little shared and diagnosis is complicated. The means to meet this challenge exist in Europe. The IARC has recently issued recommendations to Member States. On behalf of Italian citizens and patients, I would like to ask the Commission to implement these recommendations as soon as possible and on behalf of the government of my country to implement them and to make the ERN networks operational. If we're going to save lives, let's get busy!

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The World Health Organization warns that cancer is the second leading cause of death worldwide, especially lung and breast cancer. Last year, cancer led to 9 million 600 000 deaths worldwide, which means that one in six deaths is caused by cancer. Despite the fact that the European Union, including the European Parliament, has taken a number of counter-measures to combat cancer in the Member States, we are still facing insufficient financial and logistical measures. And especially now that ten Member States of the European Union, including my country, are taking part in the European Week for the Prevention of Head and Neck Cancer, I would like to call on the European Council and the European Commission to strengthen the negotiating position of the Member States in order to guarantee the availability of affordable medicines throughout the European Union, including in particular cancer medicines. Not only as a Member of the European Parliament, but also as a doctor by training, I believe that patients in the European Union should have equal access to the latest therapies regardless of their place of birth, because in the face of illness, we can all become patients whose challenge is to fight the disease.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, I would like to start by saying that I very much welcome the fact that both the new President of the Commission and the PPE faction have made the fight against cancer one of the priorities for the new period in their programme. Unfortunately, especially with the President, it is not clear at what level she wants to combat this large-scale problem. Let us be honest, the current Commission has been very contradictory in its approach to the fight against cancer. On the one hand, it proclaimed the importance of prevention and, on the other hand, ostentatiously and unlawfully ignored its obligation to regulate the use of so-called endocrine disruptors, which are one of the reasons why cancer is currently so widespread in all its forms in society. The culmination of this effort by the European Commission was the re-authorization of glyphosate, which was protested by both the lay and professional medical public. Early recognition and screening of the population that the new president wants to strengthen are certainly commendable activities. However, if we do not start addressing the causes that are in the substances we receive in food and water, little will change and we will just pour resources that could help doctors, patient organisations, patients, into the throats of pharmaceutical companies and insurance companies. For my part, I see greater potential in strengthening work with patients and their families, because not only cancer patients suffer, but also their surroundings, family and friends. I therefore hope that not only all of us here, but above all the European Commission, will finally take action.

name: David BULL
text: – Madam President, being given a diagnosis of cancer is a truly life—changing event. It creates a climate of fear and uncertainty. I know that as a medical doctor and because my father, Richard, died of prostate cancer. However, thankfully due to earlier diagnosis, prompt intervention, dedicated specialists and advances in pharmaceutical medicines, the prognosis for many has now improved. However, opportunists have purposely created a climate of fear in the United Kingdom. Patients are now being told that if Britain leaves without a deal, then there will be a significant shortage of cancer medicines, which will profoundly affect their clinical outcomes. So it is vital that we work together to reassure people that this is not the case. In my capacity as a medical doctor, I have spoken to people in the pharmaceutical industry. It is now very clear there has been a huge amount of no—deal planning and workarounds are now in place, such as batch testing and mutual recognition of standards. Three separate pharmaceutical companies based in France have also told me that the UK remains an extremely important trading partner and they will ensure that trade continues as today. It is worth remembering we import 37 million packs of medicine a month from the EU, and we export 45 million packs, so trade is reciprocal. I want to close by saying I hope everyone here in the European Parliament will join me in supporting everyone touched by cancer, ensuring that we cooperate. I’m sure that you will also agree with me that playing political games with people’s lives is never acceptable.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, I am pleased that today this item came on the agenda at the very beginning of this session, which means that this will be one of our priorities. I believe there are no political differences here and that Brexit should have nothing to do with this theme today. What I'm saying is, we've also heard from more speakers, that unfortunately cancer has become one of the leading causes of mortality in the European Union, and especially in central and eastern European countries that have a smaller gross social product and I think we need to get that right. So, when we talk about equality, then equality also applies to this area: there must be equal access to medicines for every patient, regardless of the country from which it comes, and therefore I commend the work of the current Commission and I hope that the new Commission will continue, as announced by our new President in her priorities, to take into account this, to invest a lot of money in research. It is very important to invest in research, and, as I said, to provide all patients with equal access, especially today with smart medicines. When it comes to plastic, lifestyle, pesticides, of course we need to make a balance here too and I am confident that we will do so in the future. So, I expect that the new Commission will also take into account this aspect, that we will adopt a new European plan, a masterplan, to fight cancer. I had a whole series of conferences in the last term, fight and win all over Croatia and here in Brussels. I believe that, regardless of my future portfolio, I will also be able to contribute within the Commission to this fight against cancer because it is the struggle of all of us, independently left, right, middle, and I thank Mr. Weber for leading this through his campaign and for putting this point as the main debate on the agenda of this Parliament today.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, cancer is a terrible disease that causes a great deal of suffering and sorrow. In Europe, one in ten people who get cancer gets this disease through work. The Commissioner has already pointed out that in the last five years we have introduced three packages of limit values on carcinogens. In Europe, diesel vapour has been recognised as a carcinogen for the first time. I'm pretty proud of that, to be honest. But of course our ambition must not stop here. I think we should raise the bar. I think we should fight to make sure that no one gets cancer because of the work. That is why I call on the Commissioner and his successor to make stricter standards for all harmful substances that cause cancer. Because, let's face it, getting sick from your work is no longer of this time!

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, I would like to ask you for a few seconds of latitude on my speaking time to thank the Commissioner, who is going to other horizons, as he has told us. It has been a pleasure, Mr Andriukaitis, to work with you over the past five years to move Europe forward together in health. You may remember that three years ago I was speaking to you in plenary to read you the e-mail from Mrs Heinen, a mother, like thousands of other mothers in Europe, of a child with cancer. She called for more courage to fight this scourge, the disease that kills the most children in Europe. Parliament, in the process, unanimously adopted my resolution to develop paediatric medicines, and in particular demanded that they be subject to a specific evaluation. For half of them, in fact, we limit ourselves to dividing the doses of adult drugs! Therefore, the evaluation of the paediatric drug regulations is expected to be evaluated this year, and there is an emergency. Did you know that since 2006, only six new treatments for childhood cancers have been introduced. My question is simple, Commissioner: what are we going to say to Mrs Heinen and the thousands of parents in Europe? What has been taken in terms of research, innovation, paediatric needs and side effects, survival in young people? Have we made progress and how do we ensure that these lessons will be poured into Mrs von der Leyen's anti-cancer plan?

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, as cancer is the second leading cause of death in Europe, there is a need to accelerate research, knowing that the daily causes of cancer are multiplying, whether environmental or psychological, and that cancers are increasingly multifactorial. Therefore, research, whether preventive or curative, already behind schedule, must constantly adapt to these new aspects and strengthen cooperation both in Europe and internationally. However, this assumes that the powerful pharmaceutical lobby, which generates a very large share of its turnover in oncology, is very much controlled. The molecules already discovered must be quickly put on the market at prices accessible to all. We need to strengthen, as we have just mentioned, research in paediatric oncology, which has stalled in Europe. Alternative and complementary therapies, such as cell therapy or phage therapy, should be paved. But we must also break down all the commercial taboos that are causing, in particular, criminal stock outages currently in Europe. At this price, European cooperation will be effective.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I agree with the latter' demand that we should, however, have tighter control over the pharmaceutical lobby, which is really taking a rich toll on human tragedies. Indeed, you are quoting a number of figures here, which are appalling, because behind each of these figures is human life, the life of a man who learns that he is suffering from cancer, very often incurably. In 2015, one million three hundred thousand people in the European Union died of cancer, which is more than a quarter of the total number of deaths. Malignant neoplasm is diagnosed annually in 35 thousand children. Every year, 6,000 children die. Often the parents of these children beech, ask for money to treat their sick children. So we need comprehensive measures that will allow us to fight cancer effectively. This should be accompanied by legislative solutions and cooperation in cross-border research and knowledge transfer should be proposed at Union level in order to better exploit the intellectual potential of researchers in all Member States. We can reduce morbidity and mortality rates by exchanging good practices, promoting health-promoting behaviour and, above all, improving the quality of medical training.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every year 1,300,000 Europeans lose their lives to cancer, which represents 26% of all deaths. I want to dwell on breast cancer, which has the highest mortality in women of any other form of cancer worldwide. In 2018 alone in Europe we had 522,000 new cases and 138,000 deaths. But if diagnosed in time, it's 100% recyclable. That is why we are pushing for it to be at the top of the health agenda of all Member States, to be at the forefront of prevention and information policies and actions, with awareness-raising campaigns and with education programmes. We must ensure that patients have universal access to all treatment protocols. We must overcome prejudices and social taboos so that information and preventive control become a matter for all women! I am particularly pleased that the Commissioner-proposed Commissioner from Cyprus, Mrs Kyriakidou, is well aware of the problem and is determined to create the first European strategy to tackle cancer.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The issue of cancer is a very personal issue for many, and so it is for me. Some time ago I lost one of my best friends to cancer at the age of just 46. This is also one of the reasons why I have been working with Manfred Weber and many others for a long time to get us to take more care of this issue. Two years ago, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats committed ourselves to making our contribution so that it is possible that in 20 years' time no one will die of cancer. We cannot do this alone; the Member States also have a great responsibility, but under the principle of subsidiarity, many things are possible. For example, we can ensure that the data is better connected. We have many cancer registries, but they do not fit together. In this way, we cannot help patients in the best possible way. We need more European cooperation in this. We need more research. And here I appeal to the Council: the horizon reduction plans are the opposite of what we can use. But I would also like to refer to the British colleague from the Brexit party, who has unfortunately now left the Chamber. The experts, such as the British Medical Association, say there is a problem with medical care in Brexit and, in particular, in the event of a hard Brexit. This cannot be ignored. The Brexit party behaves like someone who sets fire and then insults those who say it is burning and that you have to extinguish it. They play with the lives of patients; They must be aware of this, and we will say so.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Madam President, I welcome this debate in the House and welcome the launch of the new Commissioner for Health's admission to put the fight against cancer at the top of priorities. Prevention is the cornerstone of the fight against cancer. We must advance health education, i.e. clearly inform our citizens about risk factors, but also legislate. We are seeing, for example, that, in the fight against tobacco, new products, such as vapers, can give a false picture of benignity, and I believe that our legislative framework is not currently prepared. In terms of promoting research for diagnosis and treatment through Horizon 2020, here I wanted to emphasize the importance of supporting those initiatives that work on the innovation of liquid biopsy, which is one of the alternatives that can help an early and rapid diagnosis. Ladies and gentlemen, despite all your efforts, people in Europe will continue to die from cancer. Therefore, we must not forget the family dimension of this disease, take care of the caregiver — I am a nurse — and, of course, the importance of guaranteeing these patients a decent possibility of death.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: – Madam President, research and innovation are essential if we are to win the battle for cancer. And it is precisely in this area that this Parliament can play a key role. Because it is this Parliament that can demand, for example, that the Horizon Europe programme contain sufficient funds for our researchers to work. We also need better coordination between research centres, hospitals, patients and businesses, so that new medicines can be developed, and that they reach the market in the shortest possible time and leave no one behind. And it is here, too, that we have to legislate to allow the application of new technologies, such as the use of artificial intelligence in patient data, that is, making sure that their rights will be scrupulously respected. In short, I wanted to give a message to the public that, from the European institutions, we are going to work together to make sure that researchers are going to have all the resources to fight this terrible disease.

name: Luisa REGIMENTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate we are debating today is of particular importance to the health of all Europeans and requires a strong response and cohesive action between the groups. In fact, it is scientifically proven that the onshooting of cancer diseases depends to a large extent on the direct correlation between the environment, nutrition and man. As a result, we can no longer ignore the devastating effects of the substances present in the food and air we breathe. Only with a substantive, not only formal, battle to protect the environment can we tackle the fight against cancer, as well as providing tireless support for research into targeted therapies, such as biological drugs, the use of which has been shown to be effective and less toxic than chemotherapy drugs sometimes used inadequately, as I have often seen in my experience as a doctor. We have been given the task of protecting them and guaranteeing their fundamental right to health.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, according to data, enormous inequalities in access to the best available diagnosis and treatment for young cancer patients lead to differences in survival of up to 20%. This affects mostly children and adolescents in the central and eastern Europe region. Sadly it is my country, Slovakia, that, according to the WHO, has the second highest mortality results in Europe, with 259 people per 100 000 inhabitants affected.  We have tremendous problems with early diagnosis, quality therapy and specialist comprehensive care for small patients, as well as extremely long waiting periods for oncological surgeries and lack of post-treatment care. Therefore I call on the Commission and Member States to facilitate access to the best possible diagnostic and treatment modalities for all young cancer patients within the European Union. And last but not least, I kindly ask all my colleagues to support awareness about childhood cancer by wearing the gold ribbon that I sent to you all last week.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President, Europe faces many challenges for all known, such as Brexit, but thousands of European citizens face a terrible reality that has less media impact but great importance: cancer, which plagues Europe. We've all suffered cancer closely. The reality of the figures is incontestable: 1.4 million Europeans will lose their lives this year to cancer; 40% of European citizens will face cancer at some point in our lives. Despite this harsh reality, there are reasons for hope. Cancer mortality is down 10%. Between 30% and 50% of cancers are avoidable. How? Transforming our habits of life, of our children, of all. We must promote a healthy diet, take care of the air we breathe. We must move away from sedentaryism and smoking. But we must also take care of the mental health of our society: stress, depression, anxiety. In short, the fast pace of our lives. To achieve all these objectives we must have a European approach, improve partnerships, improve prevention and early detection, increase investment in research, equity in access to treatments in all corners of Europe and improve the humanization of patient care to be holistic and cover from the medical side to social assistance to patients. Cancer has many faces and we have to take care of all of them. This is the aim of the cancer control plan led by the European People's Party, a plan that will help defeat the disease, which will fill thousands of Europeans with life and hope. We therefore call on the von der Leyen presidency to fight cancer and to be one of the high priorities of this Commission.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, it’s my honour in this debate to mention my constituent Jacci Woodcock, who has been diagnosed with breast cancer, but is also the inspiration and the driving force behind the Dying to Work campaign which is seeking to secure stronger legal rights and protections in the workplace for people with a terminal illness.  Working with her trade union, the GMB, now with the Trades Union Congress, and now with the European Trade Union Confederation (ETUC) and the European Cancer Patient Coalition (ECPC), we are now pushing the Commission as part of any European cancer plan to include specific protections to support people with terminal illness to stay in the workplace, to continue to have the dignity of employment for as long as they can and as long as they so wish. So I press the Commission to take action on that point and I encourage MEPs from across the House to support the Dying to Work campaign group here in Parliament which I launched during the last mandate.

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I fully support Mrs Ursula von der Leyen's initiative to launch a European plan against cancer. But I am convinced that we can and must go further. Let's take a concrete example: cervical cancer is one of the most deadly forms of cancer in the world in women. More than 300,000 women die each year, 90% of them in developing countries. However, through screening and vaccination, we have the means to save them. So, consistent with the sustainable development goals, consistent with the global call of WHO Director-General Dr Tedros, in line with our values and commitments for global health, Commissioner, Madam Minister, we must include an 'external action' component in this European plan, because we cannot accept women dying from a disease that can be prevented and treated , neither in Europe nor in the world.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I spoke at the last Environment Committee on Europe's shortage of medicines. This intervention remained unanswered and I wanted to come back to it. The summer has seen new drug shortages in France. The relocation of our products causes delays in the delivery of products. In addition, laboratories are reluctant to manufacture enough for France, which is considered unprofitable. It's a real scandal. As of June, 2,318 drugs were in stress. In ten years, the number of ruptures has increased 20-fold and almost one in four French people has been confronted with it. At European level, this shortage is worrying: 80% of active ingredients are manufactured outside Europe, up from 20% 30 years ago. So there's an emergency. A cancer patient cannot have his treatment delayed because some pharmaceutical groups are only concerned about cost-effectiveness. Care must be accessible to all. There is an urgent need to explore ways to relocate drug production and develop strategic reserves.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are celebrating The European Week for The Prevention of Head and Neck Cancer, so we are dealing with a problem that affects millions of people in Europe in due course. Parliament should support the efforts of all Member States to ensure that every Citizen of the Community has equal access to state-of-the-art cancer treatments. There should never be any shortage of funds for specialized treatment, as well as prevention. In Poland, a national cancer strategy has entered into force, involving a number of activities, including early detection and diagnosis, treatment of cancer. The exchange of experience at the level of doctors and researchers gathered under this and other Member States' programmes should be actively supported by the European institutions. Together, let us ensure that a person who learns of his or her illness does not feel that he or she is sentenced, but has the chance to help quickly and professionally in both richer and poorer regions of the Union. Let us work together to provide the Member States of the European Union with tools to facilitate the improvement of the quality of national cancer programmes in order to be more effective. I ask you, we are aware that life has the same value in all the countries of our Community, and that is what we should all take care of.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Mr President, in the field of health, cancer is perhaps one of the most important challenges in Europe. A master plan against cancer - and that is our ambition - must focus on a multitude of factors. Europe must be in the cockpit in terms of research and the development of new technologies. I am thinking of artificial intelligence and medical 3D printing, but also of the correlation between environmental factors and epigenetics. Our plan must still be such a technical and innovative feat, yet it will not mean anything if we do not put the patient first. Putting the patient first means ensuring access to affordable medicines. This will have to be discussed with the pharma sector. We don't want two-speed health care. Putting the patient first means closing the prevention gap. And, Commissioner, you are right to say that we need to do more on prevention, but we all know that a healthy lifestyle and healthy eating are still the more expensive way of life. Betting on the patient and placing them at the heart of the country also means that, in addition to the right attention to very young children, we should not forget the AYAs, the group of young people and young adults who are facing cancer. They end up on a rollercoaster and have to ask themselves existential questions at an age that should actually be carefree. This is why I am in this House. These are the European values I want to defend: solidarity, tolerance and reliability for those who are on the wrongs of life.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! The fight against cancer is now one of the most important battles in the field of health policy. Throughout hospitals in Europe, doctors, patients, nurses and relatives struggle every day to save lives and also help those patients who have had cancer to have a better life after they are fully treated. It's incredibly important. But we also need to do more and we need to do more at European level, because we can actually do something. We need more resources for research, we need to do much more for prevention, and here in particular I think the European level is important. For example, we can ensure that the exposure of carcinogens is reduced and we must be able to ban dangerous substances more quickly. We must also become significantly better at learning from each other's good experiences. Today, more and more people survive cancer. And that is why it is also important that we learn, for example in relation to subsequent rehabilitation. We need to do much more together, because together we can actually take a proper step forward in the fight against cancer. It's important.

name: Judith BUNTING
text: – Madam President, what makes cancer so dangerous is that it is such a complex disease. Tumours that come under the same umbrella are often quite different. There are many different kinds of breast cancer, but they’re still called breast cancer. Hodgkin’s lymphoma attacks young lives, not old, and it is 95% curable, which is wonderful. But other cancers are still an automatic death sentence. In addition, genetic instability means that tumours go through an evolutionary process which means they can quickly become resistant to treatments that were working. But we know that one in three cancers might be curable, so we need to do more.  Advancements in genomic research are allowing research on tumour mutations to move quickly. Further studies in epigenetics are allowing researchers to look deeper, beyond DNA, and to combine the medical data with critical information about the kind of external and environmental factors that have been mentioned here today.  We must seize the opportunities created by these advancements in biomedicine, bioinformatics, big data and artificial intelligence to help us in this fight. So I call on Ursula van der Leyen to make the fight against cancer an absolute priority of the next Commission, in scientific research as well as in the medical area.

name: Annalisa TARDINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, cancer is the leading cause of death in an increasing number of European countries, and there are over 48 thousand new cases every year for breast cancer in Italy alone. Despite the considerable progress made through research, prevention is still the only effective weapon we have to overcome cancer. We have heard President von der Leyen's plans and we are now waiting for the facts. Europe must continue to promote the development of collaboration between specialised and excellent networks to improve the quality of diagnosis, treatment services and facilitate multidisciplinary cooperation. Above all, however, coordination between the Member States must be intensified, because there are still too many differences in access to screening and treatment, both between the different States and sometimes between the region and region of a single country. Action must also be taken on the causes of the disease: in Sicily, in the industrial centres of Gela, Milazzo and Priolo, scientific data are in fact well above the level of alarm and are thresholds that we can no longer accept. We must also invest in the training of health workers and set up a centre in every urban area not only for prevention and information but also for the psychological support of those affected by the disease. In addition to research, in fact, the central role must be played by the humanization of care.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the fight against cancer requires continuous financial investments, not only in healthcare, but also in scientific research and the educational system. Some European countries, including Croatia, are finding it increasingly difficult to keep up with the most developed countries. The cost of new medicines and diagnostic methods is steadily increasing, not accompanied by economic growth and rising living standards, which of course makes them less accessible. According to the latest data, Croatia is 10th in cancer mortality, and in the European Union only neighbouring Hungary is worse than our country. In Croatia, 344 people per 100,000 people died of cancer in 2016, while the European average is 262 people and the US average is 164. This data it is sufficiently about the need for more investment that will not be possible without strengthening the entrepreneurial climate and the private sector and cuts in some other parts of the swelled public sector.

name: Nathalie COLIN-OESTERLÉ
text: Madam President, according to the latest forecasts, cancer will kill 1,400,000 people in Europe in 2019. Each of us is concerned with this major priority cause, the fight against cancer. We therefore need a major European plan to strengthen and pool the resources dedicated to research and innovation. We also need to harmonize public health policies because together we will work effectively and move forward on cancer research and control.  In this regard, I would like to raise the issue of supply and shortage of medicines in different Member States. These shortages include certain drugs for the treatment of severe diseases such as cancers. The causes of these shortages need to be known and analysed. We must also make all stakeholders accountable, harmonize regulations at European level and facilitate the delivery of medicines between Member States. Access to care for all European citizens must be guaranteed, with genuine transparency in the availability of treatment within the European Union. Finally, of course, we must ensure a viable economic space for companies and laboratories, which is essential to maintain investment in research and innovation in Europe. At the same time, these actors must play the game, in the public interest.  Today, 60% of essential drug components are manufactured outside Europe, China or India to reduce labour costs and take advantage of less stringent regulations. However, the offshoring of production is a source of increased shortages when these drugs are not in compliance with the health rules of the country where they are to be marketed. It is therefore at European level that we must act on this great global cause. It is up to us to provide European answers.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Sinjura President, llum xtaqt niffoka b'mod partikolari fuq it-tfal għaliex kull każ ta' kanảer fit-tfal huwa ta' qsim ta' qalb. Imma fil-pajjiżi tal-Unjoni Ewropea, il-kanảer huwa l-aktar marda li qed tikkawża mwiet fost it-tfal tagħna. Issa, minkejja l-iżviluppi pożittivi li saru b'mod ġenerali, sfortunatament ftit li xejn sar progress biex ma jintilfux ħajjiet f'każijiet li jkunu aktar diffiảli biex tittratta. U dan id-distakk tant huwa kbir li għad għandna differenza ta' għoxrin fil-mija fir-rati ta' min jirnexxielu jegħleb il-marda bejn il-pajjiżi differenti tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Għalhekk li neħtieġu koperazzjoni Ewropea fuq ir-riảerka u l-innovazzjoni fil-qasam tas-saħħa; programm Ewropew li jista' jgħin pjattaformi ta' riảerka internazzjonali li jistgħu jwasslu għal trasformazzjonijiet kbar. U jekk marda hija meqjusa rari f'pajjiż wieħed, jista' jkollha ả-ảans ferm akbar biex tkun indirizzata kif suppost fuq il-livell Ewropew biex ma nkomplux nitilfu aktar persuni u aktar tfal għalxejn.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The issue of cancer also concerns me personally because I lost my wife to cancer five years ago. I think everyone in the room can tell similar stories about it from their environment, so there will be no doubt about the urgency of cancer research. However, the questions are whether we will solve cancer by getting the programmes at EU level, or whether it would not be used to improve the framework conditions under which research institutions and the pharmaceutical industry operate. The opposite of good is always well-intentioned, and it can also be a good thing if, through research facilitation, tax privileges, decentralized research institutions and companies that do research make it easier to work. The differences in life expectancy between the younger and older EU countries need not necessarily be adjusted through bureaucratic work, but, for example, if we take care to prevent so many young doctors from going to the West from Eastern European countries. So there are often alternatives to even more central programmes and to even more central initiatives – as well-intentioned as they are. Despite all the agreement on the urgency of cancer research, I would like to point out that there is no alternative to central projects of medical research.

name: Liudas MAŽYLIS
text: – Madam President, in the face of illness and loss of life, a simple question is raised: why did it happen? If the Europe-wide measures are still insufficient, then why? The European Union started its action on cancer in 1985. Since then, we’ve spent billions on research, but how do we assess the results? The EU’s aim was to reduce cancer incidence by 15 % by 2020. Unfortunately, this will not be the case. Systemic analysis has to be done to find out why.  I am sure that combating cancer is an important political priority of the President-elect of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen. I hope the work of the new Commission will start on the critical assessment of previous efforts in such spheres as detecting environmental influences, other risk factors, screening and enabling more effective and earlier diagnosis.  I hope that comprehensive plans on action on cancer will be drafted. As the early detection and prevention programmes are crucially important, we particularly stress the need for a harmonised cancer information system.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, I want to begin first of all by thanking the Commissioner for his passionate work in the area of health and well-being, and those of us who have worked with you, Commissioner, know that to be absolutely true, right to the end.  This debate is very timely and it’s been quite sad in many respects to listen to colleagues who have spoken of their own experience of a loved one that has died from cancer. It’s timely because on Saturday of this week, I will be speaking at a conference in my own constituency organised by the North East Cancer Research and Education Trust (Necret), and this is the sixth annual gathering, giving information and support to families and individuals who are undergoing cancer treatment. This Necret, as it is called, is involved in fundraising and supporting the unit in the local hospital so that they will have the necessary facilities and equipment to treat people.  I think when it comes to cancer we know that many Member States run checks, breast checks, checks for colon cancer, for cervical cancer, and we need to make sure that best practice prevails in all Member States. And the beauty of the European Union is that we can compare one with the other and help each other to raise the standards. But I want to mention, as I started with, this day on Saturday, this North East Cancer Research and Education Trust which my neighbour and friend Elizabeth Summersby, who is an Advanced Nurse Practitioner in the Oncology Unit in Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital, is the heart and soul of and to really salute those people who look after those who suffer from cancer and go beyond what they’re required to do and work to make sure that their lives are made better and that they’re looked after well.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened with great interest to these discussions. I am grateful for your valuable insights and engagement. I am very happy to hear so many of you using the words solidarity, fairness, justice and social equality. These are important remedies for all of us. Also, prevention is better than cure, and it will be good to know that we need to do more at EU level and it will be good to see more pan-European flags and fewer national flags in this room because we need solidarity, unity and understanding.  I would like to thank Ms Ries and Ms McGuinness for their kind words. The pleasure was mine. As I mentioned, we are evaluating the Orphan Regulation and the EU Regulation on Medicines for Children. We are aiming for publication at the beginning of 2020. Mr González mentioned e—cigarettes and vaping. We see this story in the United States. I remember our discussions when we discussed issues about tobacco product directives and we proposed to regulate e—cigarettes much more strongly. Now we see evidence and of course it is clear that these products are a threat to citizens’ health. We will need to work on it.  I have heard the words endocrine disruptors, pesticides and carcinogens. These are all part of the solution and I am happy to see them in both the mission letters for the Health and the Environment Commissioners. This means that the next Commission will do more in this field. Finally, even the Brexit Party seems to understand the damage that can be done to patients if we do not fight disease together, uniting our forces, which means that Brexit really creates damage. Thank you very much indeed for understanding. Don’t leave your patients in limbo! There was a comment on breast cancer. The European Breast Cancer Guidelines and a Quality Assurance Scheme for Breast Cancer Services are part of a European initiative.
