This initiative is person-centred and provides various recommendations, and of course genomic and epigenomic research, as Ms Bunting mentioned, is indeed very important. I am a medical doctor and I could not agree more. As I mentioned in my introduction, we are working on 1+ Million Genomes and of course we need to do more. Europe is committed to implementing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. This includes reducing premature mortality from chronic diseases such as cancer by one third by 2030. To do that we need prevention measures which are common to all the EU countries. They can impact on individual citizens and society in a way that isolated national initiatives could not achieve. Many cancers are challenging the medical community with their complexity and many cancers are rare diseases for which pooling data at EU level has a clear benefit and the European Reference Network now shows very positive results. This is a good way and we are going in the right direction.  I believe that the EU is best placed to disseminate knowledge and to identify and scale up best practices across Member States. The proposal for new cancer plans for the EU, as envisaged by the new President, Ursula von der Leyen, offers a major opportunity to take the next big step forward towards beating cancer in Europe. Therefore, I have no doubt that the Commission will continue its efforts in cancer prevention and control, of course assessing the situation based on what was done by the previous Commission. I am very happy to hear that we have a lot of like—minded friends around. Together our work will benefit patients, their families and health services across Europe and that is a worthy goal.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude, I wish to thank the honourable Members for this very useful and timely debate on fighting cancer. Cancer is a tragedy at a personal level: a fight you could lose in spite of your own strong will and the best help of professionals. In this fight against cancer, as politicians and as institutions of the EU, we should use all the EU tools available. Let me reiterate that the Finnish Presidency stands ready to cooperate with the European Parliament to raise awareness of the challenges that cancer represents for Europe and for Europeans. Our own initiative, the concept of the economy of well-being, is something which also delivers in the fight against cancer. It is important to support research. From that point of view, the provisional agreement on including a cancer mission in the future Horizon Europe is essential and the Presidency firmly supports that. So thank you again for this very important discussion and thank you for your engagement.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: in writing. – Cancer is the second leading cause of mortality in Europe after cardiovascular diseases. Each year, more than 3 million people are diagnosed with cancer. Cancer does not discriminate ... it affects any gender, young or old alike. Much has been achieved in health policy at EU level, but not enough! There is an urgent need to reduce inequalities for fast, safe and affordable access to surgery, radiotherapy and medicines. Cross-border collaboration is a key issue to ensure increased access to innovative treatment for cancer patients, regardless of where they reside. We have to promote survivorship programmes as an essential part of cancer care at all levels. It is essential to promote healthy lifestyles and reduce exposure to risk factors, in order to prevent as many cancers as possible. We need a European plan to beat cancer together in order to reduce health gaps in the prevention and control areas between and within EU Member States and to increase the benefits for cancer patients and their families!

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. The fight to defeat cancer must be a priority for the new Commission.  To date, cancer is still the second leading cause of death in the world after cardiovascular disease, but the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) - who's Cancer Research Agency - estimates that cancer will become the leading cause of death in the world in the coming years. Even in Europe, where life expectancy is increasing, this trend is evident. Advances in science have allowed new treatments and new treatments and, thanks to the proliferation of prevention campaigns, we are achieving better and better results, especially in pediatrics: today we come to treat one in two patients. But that is not enough: we must and can do more! The fight against cancer is a scourge that unites all European citizens, against which we must join forces and resources. Research programmes need to be financially supported in order to identify the causes of the disease in its various forms, and it is also necessary to invest in prevention, with the aim of reducing the number of people who fall ill, providing increasingly effective treatment and improving the quality of life of the sick.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Every year in the European Union, 1.5 million of our citizens lose their lives due to cancer, and in many EU countries cancer has become the first cause of death. I think each of us had to be confronted with this terrible disease – if not directly, among our loved ones. Despite the action taken so far, including at European level, the statistics are increasingly frightening, so there is no doubt that we need to do more and act more effectively.  I therefore believe that the fight against cancer should become one of the European Commission's priorities, and in the war on cancer, we must act in parallel on many fronts – both at the level of increased prevention, early detection, better diagnosis and treatment.  It is also unacceptable that the chances of recovery now depend on where they live – citizens from Western Europe and large urban centres are about 30% more likely to be cured than those from eastern Europe or rural regions. I believe that the launch of the European General Plan in the fight against cancer will help us to break down these negative trends and make cancer a fully curable disease.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The statistics on cancer incidence and mortality in Europe are alarming. Every year, two million cities disappear from the face of the Earth due to cancer. Coordinated action and cooperation between Member States is therefore needed to develop a common European plan to combat cancer.  Studies show that between 30 and 50% of all cancer cases can be avoided. That is why it is so important to implement a comprehensive EU policy aimed primarily at raising public awareness, reducing exposure to cancer risk factors, promoting preventive research and ensuring that people have access to the information and support they need to lead a healthy lifestyle.  Another issue is to close the gap between Member States in terms of access to modern medicines. There are many problems, e.g. reimbursing old medicines means that there is a lack of money for newer ones. In addition, statistics show that some Member States' expenditure on research and cancer drugs remains very low. Meanwhile, it is estimated that losses due to premature death from cancer in only one year are incomparably higher. This means that in many cases, spending on innovative cancer drugs is only a quarter of the amount that the economy loses every year as a result of the premature death of cancer patients. These examples show that Europe urgently needs an effective plan that will step up its efforts to fight cancer in the short term.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The future Framework Programme for Research and Innovation must translate into concrete facts the major objective of the health field, namely the fight against cancer and, in particular, against paediatric cancer. In Europe, paediatric cancer is the leading cause of infant death, with more than 35,000 new cases annually and more than 6,000 deaths per year.  The European Parliament must take concrete steps to combat paediatric cancer by adopting legislative changes that encourage the faster and more efficient discovery and production of innovative medicines accessible to patients and by allocating considerable financial resources to support paediatric cancer research.  The fight against this disease cannot be won without the EP combating patients' unequal access to the best possible treatment and medical expertise or without focusing on supporting cross-border research. Today we have about half a million cancer survivors, and this number can also be increased by involving the European Parliament without hesitation.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – One in four Poles dies from cancer. "Poland is a sick country", warns the District Medical Chamber in Warsaw. Cancer is a challenge for all European societies. However, some countries lag behind the European average. After the Holy Cross province, the greatest incidence of cancer concerns my electoral region – Lower Silesia. The projected increase in the incidence reaches up to 10%. The cancer incidence in Poland reaches 45% and deviates from the EU average. Cancer treatment in Poland is in a state of collapse. I watch it up close because I'm just battling breast cancer. Specialists emphasize that every stage of patient care requires improvement: both prevention, diagnostics at the level of doctors of first contact, availability of tests, out-of-doctor care during treatment, as well as the availability of appropriate medications. Prevention in the form of education in the field of healthy lifestyles is also important. Poland needs support at the level of doctors' education, expanding the offer of research, building a network of treatment facilities across the country, so that as many patients as possible can take them at home, without completely abandoning their working lives and family. I am pleased with Ursula von der Leyen's announcement on a European cancer plan. The EP should support programmes aimed at increasing funding for the fight against cancer as well as new regulations to support patients at every stage of treatment.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: in writing. – Cancer is one of the main causes of suffering and death in Europe. In recent decades, however, important scientific advances have occurred with regard to the ability to cure a significant part of neoplastic diseases and the possibility of treating the majority of patients, minimizing the impact of cancer and promoting the improvement of quality of life and survival time.  At the same time, treatments were made available to relieve suffering and recognition of the importance of palliative care was generalised, allowing those who are affected by more aggressive and extreme forms of cancer to live the disease with dignity. In view of the impact of the disease and the increased possibilities for response, European citizens have reason to expect more from the European Union.  There are three priorities that must be pursued. Firstly, combating the preventable causes of cancer, at the head of which tobacco smoke continues to appear. Then, the creation of a system that facilitates access for all to the most modern and effective treatments. Finally, support for research at all levels allows us to learn more and fight this pathology better.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – As a cancer survivor (up to now), I support all measures that can be taken from a political perspective which help to fight the disease in all its forms. The allocation of more research and more quality care for all patients is obviously a priority. But beyond this, I agree that two other goals should be actively pursued on a European basis. One is raising awareness across the population concerning the incidence of cancer, how it arises, how to watch for it. More and more educational programmes are needed which carry out this task in well—designed formats to ensure they communicate knowledge, not fright. The second goal is to promote ever—wider screening programmes, firstly for population strata that stand the highest risk, but also wider. All data show that such programmes, by identifying the disease when it is in an early stage, are succeeding to cut down mortality rates. There are NGOs active on a European basis to promote these aims. The European Commission would be wise if in its anti—cancer initiatives it reserve a substantive role for such NGOs, for they have a good outreach.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Mr President, today we are talking about a very important topic for our citizens. As current morbidity rates in the European Union show, one in three men and one in four women can develop cancer in the first 75 years of life. Cancer is the second most common cause of death in the European Union. Every year, more than 1.5 million people die from cancer. We are facing a great challenge and we need to be more supportive of the fight against this disease. On the one hand, by promoting research and cooperation, we can ensure that cancer patients are effectively treated across the EU. On the other hand, we expect the number of new cancer cases to decrease by 15% by increasing awareness of cancer prevention. We need a comprehensive strategy that will not only cover treatment and medical activities. We also need preventive action, including education, research and research. We should also remember that cancer treatment is often associated with a number of health side effects and that, in addition to improving the effectiveness of the therapy, more attention should be paid to how it affects patients' quality of life. We need to increase investment in the fight against cancer if we are to successfully stop this plague of our time.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the presentation of the Council's position on the draft general budget for the financial year 2020 (2019/2710 (RSP).

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, I’m honoured to present the Council’s position on the draft budget of the European Union for the financial year 2020. I would like to start by underlining that this Council position was adopted with the overwhelming support of the Member States. After careful reflection and analysis, the Council proposes for next year a budget of EUR 167 billion in commitment appropriations. This is an increase of 0.6% compared to the budget voted in 2019. In the Council’s view, next year’s budget is about continuity. Next year is the last year of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014—2020, the year when many important European programmes will gradually come to their completion.  The Council wants the EU budget to continue to focus on our common priorities: strengthening the European economy, boosting its competitiveness, ensuring sufficient funding for migration and the protection of our external borders, and tackling environmental challenges and climate change. In these turbulent times we are fully aware of our responsibility as a budgetary authority. Europe has to fight battles on many fronts to safeguard its achievements and competitiveness. With the Union, we are faced with no lesser challenges: the complex discussion on the UK’s withdrawal, defining clear priorities for the next programming period, as well as ensuring this year’s smooth institutional transition, which will have a direct impact on our work in the autumn.  In this overall context, we must remember that the budget is not just about numbers and figures. It is a powerful tool that sets the direction in which EU policies will evolve. That is why we must ensure that it is focused on European added value and delivers tangible results for our citizens. At the same time, as co—legislator, we need to be very careful how EU taxpayers’ contributions are spent. That is why the Council acted, as always, with prudence and financial discipline in full consciousness of the budgetary constraints we face. We need to have sufficient leeway to meet the yet—unknown challenges and risks that await us next year.  Now let me go into more detail on the Council position. The Council proposes an adjustment of the commitment appropriations as presented by the Commission in a draft budget for 2020 of EUR 1.5 billion. This is not a cut in the budget but a reduction in the increase. Compared to 2019, the EU budget will increase by EUR 1 billion. On payments, no significant adjustments were considered necessary or appropriate. The Council continues to support the reinforcement of the programmes under the competitiveness for growth and jobs sub—heading, which will receive EUR 24 billion or +2.72% compared to this year. In addition, the resources dedicated to economic, social and territorial cohesion will increase by 2.23% in 2020, totalling EUR 58.5 billion. In the field of migration and security, the EU budget will continue to support Member States and the EU measures that were put in place in the last few years. Additional resources are foreseen for Frontex, the European Border and Coast Guard Agency – more than 30% compared to this year – in order to set up the standing corps of 10 000 border guards by 2027. I would like to stress the fact that a great number of key programmes across all headings have been accepted at the level of the Commission’s draft budget. Those are Europe’s satellite navigation systems, EGNOS and Galileo, the energy strand of the Connecting Europe Facility, the European defence industrial development programme, the large infrastructure projects, Copernicus and ITER, Erasmus Plus – which I know is one of the programmes we all cherish most – The LIFE Programme for the Environment and Climate Action, the Union Civil Protection Mechanism, and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, for example.  I also want to underline the Council position on some specific issues. First, the Council rejects the proposal from the Commission to use Article 15.3 of the Financial Regulation. Moreover, the Council has also chosen to transfer in the reserve a certain amount of appropriations in the area of migration in order for the budgetary authority to be able to tailor its response to the actual needs on the ground in the coming year.  As regards administration expenditure, the Council’s approach is based on prudent budgeting and follows the line applied in Member States’ national civil services. Following a thorough assessment of real and justified needs in each institution and per budget line, the Council has reduced this heading by EUR 55 million. In addition, in a statement attached to the Council’s position, we have asked the Commission, like last year, to take into account the level of assigned revenues in heading 5 in view of our negotiations in November.  Let me conclude by saying that today’s debate, in my view, will mark the beginning of a series of constructive and open exchanges, which will allow us to reach a balanced and meaningful compromise. Without deviating from our common goals, we will have to prioritise and demonstrate our strong commitment to Europe. I am convinced we will be able to find a common position with an equally acceptable outcome within the agreed timeframe.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. With the council's position and today's deliberations, we remain on schedule. All those responsible – Parliament, the Council, the Commission – are concerned about getting the 2020 budget adopted in a difficult time by mid-November, thus providing clarity for programmes, projects and people for next year. We in the Commission assume that we too will be able to maintain continuity and that my possible successor, Commissioner Johannes Hahn, will be able to carry out the task here as a service provider for you as of 1 November. In addition to the normal issues and questions, there is the extraordinary and open development of the Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union. If there is an exit, an exit at the end of October and there is no regulation, then next year we will have a gap that we will have to talk about in a collegial way here in due regard. We still assume that the Kingdom will accept all the rights and obligations of the budgetary framework, which runs until the end of 2020, in the last year of the budget framework for the 2020 budget. Just think ahead: if there is no agreement and the kingdom were to leave automatically, without an extension, then a net gap of around EUR 11 billion will be created next year. And since the European Union, unlike all the other institutions – Member States, regions, municipalities – has a comprehensive debt ban, we would have to close the gap together immediately. The Commission would then make a proposal for this before the conciliation phase, which begins at the end of October. This could be that the eleven billion are being made through cuts. It could be that the eleven billion are comprehensively paid through higher deposits. Presumably, a balance between justifiable cuts that do us no great harm and slightly higher deposits will be the wise way. We will come back to this in three weeks if necessary. We consider it important that the Council and Parliament and the Commission share the priorities in principle: employment, stabilisation of growth, strengthening our competitiveness, innovation, the possible measures for climate protection at European level, which, in addition to emission reduction paths, also mean investment, in addition to standard setting, and strengthening our internal and external security. For some successful programmes, the Council shares the Commission's proposal: Erasmus+, Copernicus and other infrastructure projects; on the project on industrial development in the field of defence, we see ourselves very well in the Council proposal and in the Council's position. We are concerned about some of the cuts, and I will also want to talk to you in depth in the discussions about the concerns or the damage that cuts would cause. For many, many years we have been talking about 30% of our GDP for research, at 20%. Horizon 2020 is only part of the research investment, but an important part because in the digital age we do the best European research in many areas. That is why we consider the 4100 million cut to be unjustifiable. And I believe that the Council is also difficult to represent in public, because they are concrete examples. We would have to cut key technologies of the future by 200% for key technologies of the future, such as nano, micro, laser, and biotech – in areas where we can no longer follow America and China sufficiently. Is this really wise, I ask. On the subject of artificial intelligence, on technologies for the digitisation of the European economy, significant cuts would have to be made, or 1180 million less for the European Research Council. In concrete terms, this means that 800 research projects are cancelled and are not being carried out, even though we cannot co-finance an excessive number of meaningful research projects, because our resources are limited. We believe that there are also good reasons for every euro at European level in health research, in the digital transformation of health and care, in the development of artificial intelligence in health care. We have joint undertakings in the field of transport research, and they are now to be cut by 800%: Shift2Rail, Single European Sky, Air Traffic Management Research and others. And this would in part lead to us simply having to end programmes and projects. We should talk about this openly in the coming weeks. All projects make sense – better European than in 28 fragmented silos – and all projects would be at risk if the cuts had to be implemented as proposed by the Council. Connecting Europe, the cross-border Infrastructure: 2000million cuts. In concrete terms, this means that we will not be able to tackle some projects next year, including Safe Action – Austria, Finland, France, Germany, the Netherlands. Here we want to introduce the free emergency call service e-call. This would have to be eliminated. Or the Seine-Schelde project, a waterway project to connect the French inland waterway network with the Belgian, Dutch and German – a viable alternative to road and freight transport by road. Or the Eastern Baltic Hub – improving port connectivity and hinterland connections to Hamina-Kotka port in the Scan-Med corridor. And it is clear that if we do not tackle these programmes that do not implement projects, this will not be a saving – we will start a year later – but a postponement, a shift in meaningful investment. I will fight for every project in the Council and I ask both budgetary authorities – the Council and Parliament – to end up with these good arguments. In the case of CEF, as I said, these are measures for competitiveness and environmentally friendly transport, and I believe that everything would be a game-changer if it can be started next year. The same applies to COSME measures for small and medium-sized enterprises. The cuts would mean that Europe will not be able to become a point of contact and a support partner for many start-ups and small businesses. The cut of 25 million in the fight against cross-border organised crime, terrorism and cybercrime – here we have good arguments to avoid supporting the cuts, and the citizens are behind us on the issues. Europe and the world - heading four: a reduction of 2000 million is proposed; 70 relate to development aid cooperation and 50 to humanitarian aid. Even now, if we take it quite honestly, Europe is not doing enough to live up to its obligations to its neighbours and to the world. We must do more to ensure that human dignity is created in these regions – in the Sahel, Maghreb and Sub-Saharan Regions – so that disaster relief can be provided. With the cuts, Europe will not be the partner for human dignity and civil protection in many areas. The agencies are proposing cuts – Frontex, the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training, the Medicines Agency, the Office for Asylum. The cuts mean that our service is getting worse. Here, too, I would like to tell you the concerns here openly and then come back to them in the deliberations. And despite the difficult time with the kingdom's departure, we should do everything we can to avoid increasing the rituals that we always perform. With the goodwill of all three parties, an agreement should actually be possible within a few days before the end of the conciliation phase. As the Commission, we want to do everything we can to achieve this. In difficult times, good governance for a budget would send a clear message that Europe is capable of action and wants to remain a service provider for our fellow citizens.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I warmly welcome you, Minister and the Presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by thanking my shadow rapporteurs, for those with whom I have already been able to speak intensively in person, but also for those who are willing to accompany me again tomorrow through the whole budget and over the course of the next few weeks, so that we as a Parliament can give as a whole as possible and clearly in one direction also an answer to the Council decision. , what this looks like from Parliament's point of view. First of all, Commissioner, I would like to thank you most warmly for simply not wanting to repeat what the Commissioner has just said. I couldn't put it more accurately. It is not a question of a traditional division of roles, that we, Parliament, simply want a lot and that the Council is cutting back in principle, but that the Council has set itself future issues, which it sees as priorities, but then gives exactly the opposite answer in its response in the context of finances.  If we want to focus on the fact that we want to focus on climate issues, on issues of digitisation, artificial intelligence, cancer prevention, the fight against cancer, the fight against serious diseases and the like, if we want to focus on this, then the answer cannot really be: we will then cut the Commission's proposal. Then there should at least be support for the Commission's proposal. When I see that you are making more than 50% of the cuts in science and research in area 1a, which accounts for 15% of the EU budget, i find that incomprehensible to me, given the priorities you have set yourself. If we want to be at the forefront, if we want not only to be a role model, but also to show that we can bring jobs and climate together in a meaningful way, economic competitiveness, and at the same time provide answers to climate issues, then innovation and research are the answer, then the focus in this area is the answer. You say that you still have 0.6% increase in the whole budget; That is not even inflation, to be honest, that is actually minus, if I am quite honest now – nothing comes out of it. In terms of innovation and research, there is actually a nominal increase, but when I see the projects that are under way, I can do almost nothing new. Those who submit projects to us – and excellently prepared, very well then analysed and evaluated, have the best evidence – there are areas where we have to reject 90%, 93%, simply because there is no money. These are areas that are promising for the future – nanotechnologies are addressed, biotechnologies, futures and emerging technologies – these are a wide range of areas. That is why I have a plea to you: let us, as rapporteurs, not run up to the last day and be proud that you are not actually talking to us about the content! I am prepared, as the Commissioner said, to resolve as much as possible with you in advance, not because we are stubborn, but because we believe that we want more for the future of the European Union and what is European Added Value, in the area of climate, in the field of development aid, in the area of future technologies; and, Commissioner, we will go much further than this last year, because last year we no longer need the huge administrative margins – we do not want to spend more on this, all right. But i am also a compliment to the Commission: it has complied with the restrictions, and I have to say soberly: I would like to see a Member State that is as cautious administratively as we are in the European Union when it comes to administrative expenditure. Dear advice, please give us answers, talk to us on the content! We can't try to manage everything on the last night, we should talk to each other beforehand.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, when we started negotiating the current financial framework, back in 2011, the truth is that the situation we were in was totally different. We were talking about fighting climate change and it was a priority, but we didn't have that sense of urgency. We didn't even know we were going to have to deal with a refugee crisis, nor the final impact that the economic crisis was going to have on our lives, nor did Brexit exist, for example. So the situation has changed a lot. But we launched, for example, a Youth Guarantee to fight unemployment. We pledge to invest 20%, to spend 20% of the budget in the fight against climate change. We even accepted a budget lower than what this Parliament wanted, always with a commitment to implement it 100 per cent, and it was a commitment from this Parliament, the Commission and also the Council. So, actually, what we're asking for, or what we have left by 2020, is simply to comply with what we're committed to at the time. And it can be done. It can be done because we have enough room for the youth unemployment programme to be back in the budget by 2020. It can be done because we have funds available to further increase Erasmus scholarships. Because we have — and they have been said a lot here and detailed by Commissioner Oettinger - excellent research projects for which we are only looking forward to more money to be able to carry them forward. We need to continue to help countries that continue to receive refugees financially, and of course we have not only the possibility, but also the obligation to at least fulfil that 20% in the fight against climate change, 20% that is already obviously out of hand. That is why it is so important that we be ambitious in the 2020 draft budget and, above all, because it has to serve as a transition for the next financial framework. Because if we want to make a leap on the social pillar, on environmental policy, if we don't want to miss the digitalisation train or if we want to make a fair transition so that the usual ones don't pay, we have to start now. We just had a debate about cancer; everyone has demanded more funds from the European budget. We have to keep it. And it is also that the President-elect, Mrs von der Leyen, in her speech to this House made a kind of priority roadmap for the next five years, and the budget we approve by 2020 is going to be decisive in knowing whether or not we are on the right track. And it will depend on us whether there are resources or not so that all these policies can be put in place. From us, Parliament, but also from the Council. And what does the Council propose? Well, he proposes, as always, more cuts. It doesn't matter the commitments, the emergencies, the needs; it doesn't matter that the situation has changed radically: in the end we only have cuts. Cuts that go against policies, which go against their own discourse and commitments, and that even go against sound financial management, because they even refuse to provide necessary resources to institutions that have to implement those policies— which have to implement them, that have to control them — or institutions that defend citizens' rights : Court of Justice, Court of Auditors, the Ombudsman or the Committee of the Regions or the Economic and Social Committee. And I'm done, President. Not only will we not fulfil what we have promised, but we will also miss the opportunity to prepare the European Union to lead the global change that this world needs.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Chairman of the BUDG Commission. Mr President, earlier this year, in March, the previous Parliament adopted the guidelines for the 2020 budget. It also listed the priorities and framed the 2020 budget as a bridge to the future Europe. Four major emphasis: investing in innovation, sustainable development, the protection of citizens and security. Parliament also pointed out the special role of the new budget. 2020 is the last year of the current programming period and the negotiations for the 2020 budget coincide with the start of the talks on the new MFK. We believe that a strong, responsible and forward-looking budget 2020 will facilitate an agreement and transition to the next MFK. It is crucial for Parliament to make full use of the existing flexibility and other provisions of the MFK Regulation and the Financial Regulation. In the light of the foregoing, the Committee on Budgets has discussed the Council's position on the 2020 budget, raising a number of concerns, which have also been raised by previous speakers, but which I would like to reiterate because they are so important. For example, the Council claims to rely on absorption capacity and implementation rates to reduce expenditure on some programmes. But in many cases the pruning seems rather arbitrary and unsubstantiated. What about, for example, the proposed cuts in Horizon 2020 and Cosme? It is also noteworthy that the 2020 budget proposed by the Council contradicts what the Finnish Presidency is prioritising. I am thinking of digitisation, innovation, technological development, integration of climate policy in all sectors and special attention to the improvement of the digital skills of young people. We don't really find much of this. This automatically brings me to the next point. Now that both Parliament and the Commission have been renewed, I think it would be an excellent opportunity to give a new impetus to cooperation between the institutions during the negotiations of the forthcoming budget talks and the talks on the next MFK. I am convinced that there is scope to improve the quality of meetings between the two budgetary authorities and the Commission. I think this starts by listening better to each other and formulating arguments better. I would also like to say that it is not very productive that agreements concluded afterwards are interpreted differently by different parties, whether or not willfully. Finally, all the institutions work together with a single objective, which is to deliver a qualitative, financially sound budget for Europe and its citizens.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: We now come to the representatives of the political groups. I shall now be much stricter in respecting speaking time, and I would ask for your understanding. That is only fair, even to those who come later.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, dear Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, this is indeed the last budget of the 2020 multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020. It would be rocking time. It would be time for the Council to learn from the past and learn lessons. Do not forget that this multiannual financial framework was guided by the Europe 2020 strategy where the Council, the Commission, Parliament and the Member States have committed themselves to objectives. Now the climate objective will not be respected. The objective of combating poverty will not be respected. The objective of research and innovation will not be respected. And what does the Council do? It cuts research, cuts climate programmes, does not help small and medium-sized enterprises and also cuts the programmes allocated to them.  Do you think it is right to cut something that is important to the competitiveness of the European Union? Cut the research programme, Horizon 2020, by EUR 413 million? The Council is against its own proclamations and does not even respect the legislation it adopts and agrees with, where Parliament has also been involved. So you do not accept that Article 15(3), which means that what has not been used may be used, does not even agree to respect that article?  Not implementing the multiannual financial framework, not having the financial resources for solidarity, for migration, for competitiveness, is a huge cost that we cannot accept.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: On behalf of the Group of President, ladies and gentlemen, on Monday we began our work with a minute's silence to pay tribute to all those who had died in Spain as a result of the dramatic rains. In Europe too, now, climate change is causing thousands of families every year who are crying and have had their lives shattered. On Monday, we were all very moved. But beyond emotion, the question is whether we are able to take action. If we want to avoid climate chaos, we know what needs to be done: we must isolate all our homes, all our factories, we must develop public transport, renewables, change our agricultural model. To finance this gigantic project, the European Court of Auditors says that it takes 1,100 billion euros a year. Private and public sectors combined, we need to find 1,100 billion euros each year, the European Court of Auditors tells us. Alas! The budget proposed to us today only increases the climate budget by $0.6 billion. When inflation is taken into account, the climate budget is down by 1.3%. I find it sinister to say, but the climate budget will fall by 1.3%. At least the message is clear: the Amazon that burns, we don't care. The future of our children, we don't care. But our children will be on the streets on Saturday and will ask us to act forcefully for the common good. But the money is there, if you like. The European Central Bank has just announced that it will create 240 billion euros in one year. 240 billion euros. We all know how many houses could be isolated, how many jobs could be created in all our territories, with EUR 240 billion in one year. And we all know that in the last four years, 90% of the money created by the European Central Bank has gone to speculation. Can someone explain to me today why we are not putting all of that $240 billion into isolating our homes, transforming our agriculture, investing in renewables and creating millions of jobs in all of our territories? Who can explain it to me? Who can explain to these children why this $240 billion will not be used for the common good? We are facing an unprecedented crisis, a new crisis by its magnitude, by its gravity. We must, please, provide new answers. That's why we really need to strengthen our ambition. Eider said, the Social Democratic Group refuses all the cuts made by the Council. There is no consistency in these cuts. The Social Democratic Group wants to use all available means to strengthen our action. There is about $3.4 billion to strengthen our efforts for integration, for youth employment, for welcoming refugees, for the climate. All of this is important, but it will be quite insufficient. That is why, beyond this 3.4 billion, the Social Democratic Group will only vote on the budget if we have guarantees from the Commission and the Council to move very quickly on new resources. It is not enough, for example, to say that we want a climate bank. Everyone now agrees with the climate bank. All right, that was one of the demands of our group. But we have to say how much billions of equity we put in so that, in all our territories, we know that money is really going to come in to create jobs. Similarly, if new resources can be found and air flying is limited, the kerosene tax exemption must be ended. All of these resources will be ready to feed the next multi-year budget. My friends, it's time to declare war on climate change, it's time to stop the small steps. It's the only war that won't cause any casualties and will prevent millions of deaths. It is the only war that will bring people together and it is up to Europe to declare war. The nerve of war is money, and the Socialist Group wants a budget that meets these challenges.

name: Clotilde ARMAND
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President, ladies and gentle representatives of the European Commission, today we are discussing the budget allocated for 2020, the last year of the multiannual financial framework started in 2014. Before the start of a new financial framework, it is necessary to take stock of European commitments, the effectiveness of budgetary action, to mark as a newly elected parliament the guidelines that we want for the next seven years. I want to use all the financial margins that we have to demonstrate that Europe has a strategy in areas of interest to European citizens.  It is time to understand the concerns of the Europeans who have chosen us and to signal that we can offer a vision of society. Europeans are increasingly concerned with protecting the environment and expect further action in this regard. In this direction, we must engage the European economy, but always be careful to keep the economy competitive, to prepare the energy transition, and to the criteria for allocating funds.  We cannot accept an urgent action and, at the same time, limit programmes mainly to a criterion of excellence. Projects that have, for example, in Romania, the criterion of excellence may be counted on their fingers. However, in terms of the environment, there are great emergencies in Romania. We have an economic fracture in the middle of the continent, coupled with an ecological fracture that we need to correct. It is important for the prosperity of the whole of Europe. We need to build financial devices responsibly, generating continental balance and not risking new imbalances.  I insist on this occasion to strengthen the technical assistance budget lines, which have proven their effectiveness, for which we have tabled amendments. We must note that the expertise is mostly located in the big European centres, that we have a brain drain phenomenon from east to west, and we must make up for the inability to implement projects in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe at European level. There are high expectations of us: the institution of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I propose, as I mentioned in an amendment, that we provide reasonable financial means for this institution to become operational as early as next year. Let us not create a structure without giving it enough strength to act.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Forest fires, hurricanes and floods – the climate crisis is destroying our livelihoods. It destroys the livelihoods of many young people who, we think, rightly take to the streets on Friday sit on strike for the climate. But it also destroys the livelihoods of many farmers, for example in southern Europe, whose livelihoods are being destroyed. And that is why we believe that we are all in the same boat and that we urgently need to do more. That is why we are not discussing the budget here about boring figures, but about the future of our continent. We are talking about the budget about how we can invest together in our future.  We Greens want to stop the climate crisis and fight poverty, and we want to give everyone in the European Union a perspective. For us, this also means, for example, standing up for the many young unemployed people in Spain, Italy and Greece who have still not found work and where the crisis is still unwell. We Greens believe that we need a real Green New Deal, with investments in climate protection and against youth unemployment. While Merkel, Macron and others have called for more investment and more joint European investment in the European election campaign, they are now doing the opposite: they are proposing cuts in climate protection, in youth unemployment, but also in research. That cannot be true! We Greens are therefore asking for 3.5 billion more to be taken as a first step in order to invest in climate. We are asking for EUR 350 million more for the fight against youth unemployment, and we take human rights seriously. We are asking for a EUR 48 million European maritime rescue programme to put an end to the death in the Mediterranean. It is our duty not to look further away, but to take action.  In our view, the Council's proposals are unacceptable. We Greens are happy to be part of a constructive majority in this Parliament for the budget too – that is our objective: we want to change and shape Europe. But we must do this by implementing things and by investing together in our future. That is why I hope that we will come here in Parliament and that we will find majorities here on these issues and then, in the end, prevail against the Heads of State or Government – for Europe and for our common future.

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, last week President Erdogan again threatened the European Union to open the doors of emigration to Europe. Somewhat accustomed to the renunciation and submission of our European leaders, he once again points to the weapon of blackmail of migratory submersion. It should be remembered, however, that the European Commission has already paid Turkey 5.6 billion euros and is preparing to pay an additional 400 million euros in the coming weeks. When we know the paltry budget allocated to Frontex, namely 420 million euros in the 2020 budget, we are entitled to ask what is the common sense of these agreements and these budgetary choices. The European Union is once again demonstrating its inability to protect its borders. There is an urgent need to restore the territorial sovereignty of nations so that they can finally take back control of the protection of their national borders. As for Frontex, we could consider turning it into an agency of free cooperation between European nations accredited to defend our external borders and not, as is the case today, an uncontrolled reception of migrants.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Budget discussion is always difficult, but it should always be based on reality. Here in the European Parliament, we are responsible for a good budget for the people of Europe and for our constituents. Community solving of European problems is a noble and beautiful task, and therefore our conduct must be very real in this regard. If the European Union documents state that agriculture must be taken care of, we cannot agree with the Council's proposal to reduce the commitments and payments under heading two - 'Sustainable growth and natural resources'. We can't just do that. Good food produced in producer groups deserves support. The EKR has just tabled such an amendment. Our grandchildren can not eat plastic, they must eat natural healthy food. If we want to feel safe at train stations, airports and on the subway, we are protecting the borders of the European Union, which is why the ER has tabled an amendment to strengthen Frontex and Europol. It is disastrous that the Council is reducing funding for Horizon 2020 by EUR 413 million. Universities and researchers must have money for research and safe technologies to modernly educate and combat unemployment, including unemployment among young people. Let us therefore be realistic, we are solving real problems, let us propose very rational solutions that concern the European Union, which concern the people of the Community, and let us tackle these problems together.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, I am in full agreement with Commissioner Oettinger's very critical assessment of the Council's proposal and I am in full agreement with the indictment that has been made by all the political groups in your proposal.  You must see that there is unanimity in this Parliament against the Council's proposal, which is a proposal which mourns European ambitions. You said you don't want to talk about numbers. I can understand, but I want to talk to you about numbers, because your proposal is just unjustified cuts and cuts, incredible cuts for research, minus 413 million, cuts against young people, minus 11.67 million for the youth employment initiative, cuts also for the Asylum and Migration Fund, when we have to meet this challenge of the integration of refugees, and then also cuts to the Cosme programme, 36.5 million which will result in less aid for businesses.  So I tell you that with this budget, you are the one sacrificing Europe and, with this budget, it will be less Europe in 2020 and it is very sad.

name: Michael HEAVER
text: – Madam President, 17.4 million Brits who voted to leave the European Union in 2016 will be bewildered and angry to find out that they’re on the hook for billions of pounds towards the EU’s 2020 budget. We heard the word ‘continuity’ earlier. The British people did not vote for continuity, they voted for independence, and that is why the Brexit Party will now fight for a clean break from the European Union. As a House of Lords report has previously stated in my country, if agreement is not reached, all EU law, including provisions concerning ongoing financial contributions and machinery for adjudication, will cease to apply, and the UK would be subject to no enforceable obligation to make any financial contribution at all. In other words, no-deal means no UK money for the European Union. Sounds pretty good to me. It is no wonder, therefore, you’re so desperately trying to cling on to Theresa May’s surrender treaty, a treaty that has been rejected repeatedly in my country. And that is why the Brexit Party is putting Boris Johnson, our Prime Minister, on notice that he must not simply try to rebrand and resell that treaty, because we don’t want it, and the Brexit Party will fight him every step of the way. On behalf of the people of the East of England and Essex where I live, let me tell you what we think about the prospect of handing over GBP 30 billion plus through another European treaty: no thanks, no deal, you can do one.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, we are debating now the budget of the European Union for the year 2020. This has two particularities: firstly, it is the last year of the current MFF, and secondly, it is the first year after the European elections. Being the last year of the current MFF means that money is finally flowing to Member States. It means that we need to pay many bills, and this is why my kind request to the Council is we have to make sure that the Union is equipped with enough resources that we are able to pay our bills. There is no worse signal that we can give to the beneficiaries, to the people, to the cities, to the villages, to the SMEs of Europe, than being a union not capable of paying its bills. It’s not possible that, at the beginning of the MFF, we need to put pressure on you to finally absorb the money which you deserve. In the end, we need to put pressure on you to finally pay the bills. Secondly, being the first year after the European elections means that we need to hear the voice of the people who were voting. The participation rate was higher than it was five years ago and young people went to vote. We cannot tell young people that we have less money to tackle youth unemployment as the Council proposes to cut by EUR 116 million the amounts allocated to preventing youth unemployment. We cannot tell young people that there is less money for tackling climate change, because they care about the future of their planet. We cannot tell them that we cannot finance Erasmus properly. We cannot tell farmers who went out to vote that there is less money. Let’s work together, Members of Parliament, Commission and Council, to make sure that we identify the right priorities, allocate enough resources and make sure that the money is well spent.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: – Madam President, budget decisions are the core of political action. The allocation of financial resources is not a technical and bureaucratic exercise, but it is the way the European Union answers the needs and requirements of the 500 million EU citizens.  We, as the European Parliament, have to be very ambitious. We do not have to be afraid, in a period of crisis, of flying high – the more the economic crises throw us down, the more we have to be high-flyers. We do not only have to ask to restore the budget initially proposed by the Commission, but we have to increase it. The proposal made by the S&D Group of EUR 3.4 billion is absolutely acceptable. In particular, all the financial targets related to climate change have to be strongly defended and promoted in the 2020 budget. Secondly, the Youth Guarantee has to be strengthened and permanently included in the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+). Thirdly, neighbourhood policies, especially in the Mediterranean area, are fundamental and have to be reaffirmed in order to keep on with our values of solidarity and inclusion.  As shadow rapporteur, I have dealt with the European agencies, and it is important to increase both the funding and the staff of the agencies whose action positively affects environmental policies, labour policies and migration policies. We are facing a crossroads. Europe must be a green and social Europe, or nothing at all. Please do not let us miss this opportunity.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Madam President, Mr Secretary of State, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the year 2020 will close the current financial framework, and therefore the time for the balance sheet will come. At the end of 2013, the European institutions committed to allocate 20 per cent of spending on climate protection. However, this commitment is on the way to not being respected. This failure would be part of a context in which disasters are multiplying. Our fellow citizens themselves sent a clear message last May. They expect the Union to act, to protect it. Our duty is to address their concerns. Institutions must respect and honour their commitments. For our group, Renew Europe, it is essential to reach 20 per cent. It is about protecting the planet and the bond of trust between citizens and their institutions. Mr Secretary of State, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we take note of the Council's position and its annual quest for more savings, in total contradiction with the climate ambition displayed by the Finnish Presidency. Nevertheless, we expect all institutions to keep their promises. New commitments will accompany the next financial framework. Let us make sure that this 2020 budget is a coherent link.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Madam President, I support my Group’s initiative to honour the Barroso Commission’s promise of committing at least 20% of the budget to climate within the old multiannual financial framework (MFF). Let me remind you that this promise was given even before the Paris Agreement. As it stands, we are falling short of this promise by EUR 3.5 billion. I also strongly support the initiative for using the entire financial flexibility towards young Europeans in Erasmus and the Youth Unemployment Initiative.  But this discussion is also about something bigger. It’s about demonstrating Parliament’s ambition for the next budget. In the European elections EU citizens have shown us that they expect us to be more ambitious to provide European solutions to the challenges that affect their lives. We need a budget that increases, rather than decreases, the EU’s capacity to act when it comes to climate change, migration, asylum and youth unemployment. For that we need a budget that serves European people across all Member States. We should also increase the financial resources that the EU raises itself, which the Treaties demand we do.  We need to explain and convince European citizens and our friends in the Council that giving more money to the EU is worth it and that the additional investment is worth it. Let us be confident and ambitious, as the European people have demanded we be, within this budget and the next.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work A few comments. I understand that ambition is all important and money would like to be put everywhere more and more, but if I listened to Mr Oettinger's review earlier, the fact is that if Britain leaves the European Union without a treaty, there is a risk of an EUR 11 billion hole. This money needs to be found somewhere. Money comes from member states, if there is no consensus to put more in, then there is no money to channel. Secondly, I also have a question, above all, for Mr Oettinger, as the most competent person on this issue. We are talking about climate problems, we are talking about migration problems, we are talking about youth unemployment, but should we also talk about demographic problems? In the European Union, the average birth rate is 1.59 children, compared to the world we are in the back row. In order for Europe to be preserved and for us to build a climate and a sustainable Europe, we also need to ensure the future of our children. Does it take into account the budget?

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in this debate, I would like to express my concern about too little increase in payment appropriations. Although they are growing by 5.1 billion compared to this year, as the 2020 budget is the last year of implementation of the financial framework, it is likely to speed up the implementation of projects, both under cohesion policy and rural development. On the other hand, the draft budget was based on conservative assumptions, in particular as regards the pace of implementation of projects under both funds, all the more bizarre since the margin of free payment appropriations is as high as EUR 20 billion. This may lead to a repeat of the backlog of payments that we experienced in 2012-2015, with a peak in 2014, when the backlog amounted to EUR 30 billion. On the other hand, it is a good idea to support the draft budget with a draft agreement for the UK's exit from the Union. If there is a no-deal exit and the UK does not meet its financial obligations, then changes to the 2020 budget should be made through an amending budget.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, Mr Tiilikainen, so far no speaker has been found from any political group to support even indirectly the cuts proposed by the Council and your Presidency. They were rejected with documentation by Commissioner Oettinger and the representatives of all the political groups. It is impossible with the cuts you are proposing to achieve the objectives, not the objectives requested by the European Parliament, not those set by the Commission but the objectives set by the Council itself. And that is a very bad signal for the new Multiannual Financial Framework being prepared by the Council for the next seven years. Is this how we will implement the climate change targets, the fight against youth unemployment, cohesion, innovation, education? You need to change the wheel. With less money, no more things are done. That's all Jesus Christ did!

name: Mario FURORE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as every year, the Council has presented a series of budget cuts proposed by the Commission on a criterion that, frankly, we find difficult to understand. The cuts should not penalise programmes that bring added value to the Union in economic, social and environmental terms. On the contrary, the Council should support economically the policy choices it promotes, such as innovation and the fight against unemployment. Instead, as always, central programmes for the future of the European Union are being cut: I am referring, for example, to the cut you have proposed to the CAP, that is to say to the agricultural world, or to the reduction of the EUR 60 million in funds for the revision of the Dublin Regulation or the zero refinancing of the instrument to support youth unemployment. You see, more than just linear cuts, we need a real rationalisation of resources in order to concentrate spending in the crucial sectors and thus revive the real economy. That is why we welcomed the eur 55 million cut in administrative expenditure, also proposed by the Council, because that is where the waste lurks. This is the line we intend to take forward and through our amendments to the 2020 budget we have asked the Union to cut waste and huge salaries. We want a more efficient Europe, without waste and with more growth.

name: Angelika WINZIG
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Protecting the European Way of Life also means that we have catching up to do in large technical areas compared to other economic areas such as Asia or the USA. With Horizon 2020, we are investing in important future issues for our competitiveness, for our business location and thus also for our employment. As an entrepreneur, I am pleased that this programme also benefits SMEs, which are, after all, the backbone of our society and our economy. 24% of the total budget of the second and third pillars goes to this group of companies. Many European countries are characterised by very good cooperation between SMEs and industry – a win-win situation for both. Our industrial companies face major challenges. Only they can use research and development in the field of renewable energy to develop solutions against climate change that have a corresponding broad impact on the population. Against this background, I really do not understand that the Council wants to make cuts in this programme.

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner Gunther Oettinger, Minister, the Council- as has already been said - is planning significant cuts for 2020. More than 27 million. It's a budget, it would seem in French, cut to the serpe. That is why my colleague Olivier Chastel has proposed several amendments to reverse these cuts. The issues at LIBE - I will focus on this subject, as rapporteur for my group. The Council foresees a reduction of 20 million in the budget of the European External Action Service. We know how important the reality of its mission is and that, particularly on migration issues, the development of readmission agreements requires resources. We would also like to support the resources allocated to agencies such as Frontex, Europol and Eurojust. If Member States want to give an effective response, it is these agencies that can make a significant contribution to this enhanced cooperation.

name: Benoît BITEAU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Amazon is on fire, drought is affected in the countries of the European Union. Can climate finally become a priority in this European budget? In recent weeks, I have heard great statements for emergency measures, I have heard speeches in support of farmers in this difficult phase, I have heard promises to accompany them towards drought-resilient production systems. The amendments I tabled in the Committee on Agriculture to support agroecology and help farmers as early as 2020 were not accepted. We missed a first opportunity and I regret it. The citizens of Europe will not be satisfied with fine words. When we vote on the multi-year budget, Parliament will have to mobilise the funds so that the next common agricultural policy takes up the issue of climate change. And now, when you see amendments for agroecology, a tip: press the green button, you'll be sure you made the right choice.

name: Francesca DONATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, cohesion policy is one of the most important items in the General Budget of the European Union, together with the CAP. Cohesion policy is based directly on the Treaties and aims to reduce the gap between the different regions and the lag behind the less favoured regions. To date, together with the CAP, it is the only concrete instrument of the European Union capable of achieving real results in terms of increasing employment, growth and competitiveness. However, more and more often the Commission and the Council are proposing cuts in these parts of the budget, either to translate the funds to other jobs or, today, to the deficit in the event of Brexit with no deal. What Parliament has been calling for for a long time, however, is that there should be no cuts in this area and that work should be done to ensure and improve the efficiency, effectiveness and quality of programmes and projects. I personally hope that the introduction of ever more stringent cross-compliance instruments in this sector too will be brought to an end, as a mere pretext for undue pressure on the governments of the Member States and to impose on the same fiscal policies that are contrary to the will of the citizens, with results that are counterproductive to economic and social cohesion. I therefore call on everyone to work together to ensure a 2020 budget that is adequate to pursue the economic and social aims of this Union.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President, since everyone considers their area of interest to be the most essential, it is common practice to focus only on how much money is spent on what budgetary items. We are less eager to look back and assess what European projects were truly useful and which ones were just a waste of money. We must clearly define the specific objectives to be financed by the European budget and the outcomes expected. For example, the efficiency of the education projects should not be measured by the number of its participants, but by their success after it. Let us not be afraid to abolish ineffective programmes so that we have more resources for better programmes. Yesterday I exceeded the time limit, hopefully today I compensated for it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, this budget proposal is marked by an overall lack of resources, by wrong priorities, by a lack of resources in the social and environmental areas, in cohesion, by the increase in expenditure associated with an interventionist drift at the external level, by militaristic, security drift. Nevertheless, we do not give up intervening, as far as we can, with concrete proposals that could improve the proposal that we now have at hand. We have tabled more than 80 amendments to the Commission's proposal with clear objectives: to promote public investment, to support the productive and strategic sectors, public services, to promote employment with rights, to fight poverty and inequalities, to promote women's rights, to protect the environment and biodiversity, to make full use of the potential of each country and region. Some of these amendments have been adopted in the specialised committees, which we highly value. We will now be up against each other so that these proposals can be included in the final budget to be adopted here by Parliament. This will not erase its most negative aspects, but it will be important and we therefore ask for your support.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Madam President, when I look at the EU budget I see political flaws and the usual accounting chicanery. The political flaws are once again seen in the anti-democratic agenda and the creation of nebulous new departments that purport to promote the European way of life. The historic accounting flaws and wasteful spending are legendary, but my personal favourite is the Committee of the Regions, which spent EUR 725 000 on gifts, trophies and medals, presumably to reward mediocrities like the Chair of the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) for destroying the fishing industry.  I’m astonished that the EU arrogantly assumes the UK will still be contributing EUR 18 billion to the EU budget next year, but how on earth are you going to pay for budget increases when we leave? It cannot be out of assumed growth because a recession is now widely expected, and it cannot be from fiscal stimulus because such supply-side pro-growth policies are denied to euro area economies.  The purpose of the Stability and Growth Pact is not to allow economic stimulus. It is there purely for economic patronage so the Commission can grant leniency to countries which they see as EU favourites, which is why France can act with impunity and Italy cannot. Mario Draghi was right in his plea for fiscal stimulus, but it’s all in vain when the euro area remains in the suffocating straitjacket of the Stability and Growth Pact and locked into the euro, which was designed as an instrument of convergence but, as we saw in the last financial crisis, ruined the lives of Greeks, Italians and Spaniards at the altar of European integration. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: - Dear Chairman, Europe today faces challenges that no Member State can solve separately. We live in a time of great demographic, technological, but also climate change. That is why this last budget in the budget period with key budgetary policies is extremely important. Here in the European Parliament, we must continue to insist on policies towards young generations, policies that will bring quality education, a quality workplace closer and also facilitate family start-ups in all parts of Europe. We must also support investment in investment, innovation and research that enable global competitiveness, but at the same time we must continue our policies to reduce differences between Member States. Central and Eastern Europe, and in particular Croatia as the youngest Member State, still need to feel the full benefits of European membership. The priorities of each organisation, including the European Union, are best seen by how it uses its limited resources. Therefore, the 2020 budget should also justify the trust given to us by our citizens in the European elections. This means a future orientation, but also a reduction in geographical and generational differences.

name: Olivier CHASTEL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us say at the outset, the budget cuts made by the Council in the Union budget do not reflect the priorities of the Finnish Presidency, nor those of the new President of the Commission, let alone those expressed by our fellow citizens. We must realize the opportunity of this moment to turn the climate challenge into an economic opportunity and ensure sustainable and shared prosperity by investing in research and development and innovation. Furthermore, on behalf of the Renew Group, I have introduced various amendments reflecting our political priorities: social entrepreneurship and microfinance, for appropriate support for vulnerable people in their desire to create or energize their own micro-enterprise; promoting entrepreneurship and improving competitiveness through strong support for SMEs; Supporting innovation in SMEs and access to their financing; increased financial resources at the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training. These are all commitments for growth and for jobs.

name: Gina DOWDING
text: – Madam President, our societies and our communities are facing huge challenges. Climate change, social injustice, economic inequality – all require determined political and practical action. Today, as a Green, I welcome in particular the decision to top up the Horizon and Erasmus programmes. Today’s vote was one small step in the right direction, but we need an even greater commitment to research and development on climate-related activities in the future. I therefore call on Member States to commit to funding our future and to follow this Parliament’s proposal to increase the funding of the EU’s next research programme, Horizon Europe. Innovation will play a huge role in solving issues such as the climate crisis, although it cannot be our only answer. We must also commit to immediate and decisive climate action in other areas as well. But today, let’s celebrate investing in our future and ensure that we act decisively on climate change.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Honourable Members, you are pretending that this is about your money. In fact, it is primarily the interests of the European taxpayer, because he has generated the budget, with his work and with his taxes. The EU budget in 2020 is around EUR 160 billion, an increase of around EUR 10 billion compared to 2019, but here in plenary, the end of Europe is being proclaimed and the impoverishment of large sections of the population is forecast, all because the Council has reduced the increase marginally. One really wonders in which world some Members live in. In reality, the budget is far overrun. Everyone pretends that there is no Brexit and no recession, no looming trade war between China and the US, no oil crisis caused by the attack on Saudi Arabia. What we have is a stupid budget because it knows no risks. It is a deceitful budget because it sells the increases as cuts. And it is a bold budget because it continues the EU's self-service at the expense of European taxpayers.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, for me the European Union budget must be a strong development and social budget. A budget that meets the demands and expectations of European citizens. In order to achieve such a budget, we need to prioritise and strengthen the funds for our young people and employment, the funds for innovation and research, for our farmers, for small and medium-sized enterprises, for our defence and security, which is particularly important for the European Union and the Member States. We also need to strengthen the digital economy. At the same time, however, we must make it a budget linked to the rule of law, respect for human rights and the application of international and European principles and values. I do not believe that there is a European citizen who wants money to be given to countries that violate all these principles and values of the European Union. In particular, it is unacceptable to continue pre-accession aid to a country that fundamentally violates international and European law and the rule of law and does not respect human rights, such as Turkey. I believe that if we ask European citizens today whether they want Turkey to be financed with even one euro, no one will vote 'in favour'. It is inconceivable that Turkey would violate the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus, threaten and blackmail Famagusta, threaten and blackmail for migration, create a thousand problems in the region with the risk of instability and disruption of peace, and the European Union would continue to provide pre-accession aid. I believe, Commissioner, that it is time to freeze the funds for Turkey's pre-accession aid and give a clear signal that the European Union is a Union of principles and values that calls on those who receive aid and funds from the European Union to respect these principles and values.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our citizens are asking us for a europe that is closer to responding effectively to their demands, but the Council's positions on the 2020 budget proposal seem to want to move away from this objective, with significant backward steps in relation to the Commission's proposal which, as a Parliament, we considered to be uneth ambitious. Instead, we want to continue to invest in a sector, the agri-food sector, which is Europe's largest industry and whose strategic nature is all too often put into the background. The planned cuts for 2020 do not take into account the current geopolitical situation and the effects on our products already caused by the Russian embargo and which will manifest themselves in the event of a no-deal Brexit. What is at stake, Commissioner, is the future of our young people and of the entire agri-food sector. Let us rise to this challenge and avoid backward steps, which would be a negative signal in view of the negotiations on the next financial programming.

name: Nico SEMSROTT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Dear High Nobility! Your financial plan is timely for the Middle Ages. Our covenant of principalities is under threat, but not by strangers, but by you, for you, the treasurers, act in folly. Because your fear so seizes you, you build bulwarks around our lands, do not listen to the scholars, and be blind to the true dangers of our time. We are experiencing an eternal summer. Animals die out, fires devour the forests, and the sea robs the land. That is why, on the twentieth day of September, we are gathering with the insurgents of Fridays for tomorrow in the marketplaces to put a stop to your diabolical plan.
