Just out of defiance - we don't give up. We, the destitful, hopeless and hopeless, stand together against you, the unsuspecting.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider the programme allocations to support infrastructure, business, research and innovation to be strategic. However, I admit that I am surprised to see that the Commission's proposal for 2020 provides for numerous increases which would probably put the finances of net contributor countries, such as Italy, in further difficulties. We are almost at the end of the financial programming period and the performance of these instruments so far still raises too many question marks. The appropriations must not only be pharaonic, but must deal methodically with the problems facing our production situations.  We are talking about the procedures for access to Commission notices, out of reach of smaller entities, despite the fact that it is they that need them most. In Italy and Europe there are examples of excellence that run counter to requirements that are often impossible to meet, so I would like the Commission to take these critical issues into account, unless the intention is to exclude the smallest realities from the outset in order to allocate resources exclusively to the usual behemoths, as is all too often the case.

name: Niclas HERBST
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have just discussed the issue of the fight against cancer in the previous point, and we all agreed that the issue of Horizon plays a special role here. And now – an agenda item later – we see the opposite, at least cast in figures. We simply have a discrepancy here between what we are calling for in Sunday speeches and what we are implementing here. We must not allow this to happen. The Commissioner has made it very clear that we are actually talking about delay; They don't stop it. And this delay means time that we do not have – not in the fight against cancer, not in the fight against youth unemployment – the longer young people experience youth unemployment, the more likely they are to become radicalised – and we do not have it on the subject of research funding: the rest of the world does not sleep either. Of course, we are talking about taxpayers' money, but if you read some of the headings, you can see that you are almost deliberately attacking the programmes that are doing particularly well, which represent a particular European added value. That is not a good idea, dear advice. In this respect, we must get used to certain rituals here, even as almost two thirds of new Members. The ritual obviously involves the fact that you only proceed with the lawnmower in the Council. That, too, is not a good idea. This ritual requires us to contradict you. I would just imagine what would happen if we agreed with you here. Then you would probably not only be surprised, but also very frightened. In this sense, please demand this contradiction from Parliament, and in the interests of good cooperation, you will also get it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament is very ambitious in its policies and, as rapporteur for the budget for ENVI, I know that we will need many more financial resources that we do not yet have in the budget. Climate change is challenging us, which will require an additional three and a half billion euros. At the same time, we are facing challenges that will lead to the fulfilment of our citizens' expectations and improve their quality of life. Therefore, the transition to a sustainable economy, the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights and, as well as the European minimum wage, whether the fight against climate change mentioned above, must be adequately complemented by the creation of a system that sufficiently finances these ambitious policies. Such support systems could be, for example, a digital tax or progressive taxation of large corporations, which we have talked about many times in this room. At the same time, we should be looking for more effective instruments to prevent leakage from the European budget and from the budgets of the Member States of the European Union through various letterbox firms and letterbox schemes.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, I am working on this document on the REGI committee and will comment on next year's budget from a regional development perspective. Cohesion Policy is a major investment tool in many Member States. That is why it must remain one of the cornerstones of the budget, both this year and the next multiannual budgetary framework. There are many reasons for this, from the obligations laid down by the Lisbon Agreement by Article 174 that no region, island, mountainous territory or remote territory of the Union should be left behind, to the fact that each euro invested in cohesion policy repays €2.74 of added value for development and job creation. I am sorry that the council's proposed budget omits or reduces funding for areas crucial to Europe's future, such as climate change, migration, youth employment initiatives, neighbourhood instruments. This is not a proposal that responds well to these challenges or provides a good basis for the new Commission, as it does not largely follow the priorities presented in its announced programme.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I rise in this debate to speak as shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Foreign Affairs and to express my concern on the Council’s proposals that foresee a decrease of over EUR 1 billion in the commitment appropriations for heading 4, which could result in budget for external actions at the lowest amount of the preceding three years. Does the Council really believe that, in this current international context where human rights, democracy and the rule of law are facing roll-backs across different continents, this is what we should be doing? Is this really responsible: to reduce the EU’s capacity to act, and to abandon people in the greatest need? What really concerns me is that the EU seems to be following in the footsteps of the USA, while China is out there and is offering easy money – with heavy penalties, though, strings attached! I’d really like to see the EU taking responsibility and doing more human rights and more democracy, so I call on the Council and the Commission to review their proposals and to make sure they put their money where their mouth is.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, Minister, Mr Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. This is the eleventh budgetary procedure I am following now, and I see it as highly institutionalised, ritualised and, if I may say so, deadly boring. We always have the same situation on the Council side: the far from original explanation for your cuts is the prudent and realistic financial planning and sufficient margins. If I then look closely at the figures, we will be going down in expenditure in an inflation-adjusted manner, with all the consequences that colleagues have already outlined here. I take up the idea of Mr Herbst – I find it charming. What would you do if we accepted your proposal? Would you, Minister, be able to explain to your constituents why the Finnish Presidency wants to spend more money on digital change, in research, in climate policy, in all areas, including transport infrastructure, and on your own draft budget? I don't think you can do that. My request is: accept the rapporteur's proposals!

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, there has been a great lot of debate on the report and it is normal to do so. From the outset, I would like to appreciate the Commissioner's clarification. He explained very well why it is not good to operate these cuts. We know as well. I am the shadow rapporteur at TRAN, at the Committee on Transport and Tourism, and I find that almost everything is cut: from research, from connectivity, from everything.  Minister, I have a question: in your speech you said that the budget is an important tool for the policies of the European Union. The budget that you present, with cuts to all chapters, how will it come as support for the policies of the European Union? Because we are talking about cohesion, we are talking about start-ups, we are talking about research, we are talking about health, we are talking about the safety of citizens. That's what citizens expect: welfare, rising living standards and safety. Or you disagree in what you say. You are saying that the budget has to go in the direction of European policies and, by what you cut, it goes the other way.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her "Greiz is horny" – that was not only the slogan of one of the most successful and controversial advertising campaigns in Germany, no, that seems to be the attitude of the Council when it comes to the budget for the coming year. It's like always: less money, you cut. Less money for culture, less money for civic engagement, and even the best-known and most successful programme, Erasmus+, is being cut. Time and again, the importance of culture and education for social cohesion within the Union and the personal development of each other is stressed. But investing in it doesn't seem to be a dream come true. The cuts proposed by the Council in these areas are simply unacceptable. Creative Europe, Europe for citizens has always suffered from chronic underfunding. For the Committee on Culture and Education, the matter is clear: we need more money! We are calling for ten per cent more for Erasmus+, Creative Europe and the Europe of Citizens. We need to invest more in youth, culture and education, not less. I believe that we owe it to our citizens.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the debate on the 2020 budget is an opportunity to reiterate the need for employment support measures. That is why, as a member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I have tabled amendments with my colleagues in the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) aimed at strengthening this aspect in the text, in particular the youth employment initiative, which is a key instrument in this challenge. Unemployment levels among young people remain too high in many Member States, and that is why we are calling, with our amendments, for a further EUR 600 million to be allocated to this initiative. We have also expressed the need to bring our employment policies ever more into line with the Sustainable Development Goals and the European Pillar of Social Rights by creating synergies to reduce inequalities and promote social dialogue, to improve the productivity and conditions of workers, including by increasing the funds allocated to lifelong learning and vocational training. Work is one of those areas where Europe must make its action felt with extraordinary strength for its citizens, especially by intervening in the most problematic contexts.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The world is burning, the gaps are large and human rights are under threat in many places. I am proud of my Social Democratic-led government in Sweden, which is sticking to its 1% target in the area of aid. But it is high time that all EU countries followed what they promised, 0.7%. As shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Development, there are a few points that I hope can be given more priority in the field of foreign affairs, within the framework of a modern ly responsible and balanced budget. We must cooperate more on human rights and tackle the shrinking democratic space to which civil society is exposed. We must invest more in women's rights and on sexual and reproductive health and these rights. There needs to be more focus on the climate, which is the common cause of destiny of our time, and we cannot back down as a humanitarian player as the world's crises increase and can force even more people to flee. Finally, there are only 10 years left until we must all have achieved the UN's sustainability objectives. What we do and prioritise here, now, during our term of office, can be crucial.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, two of the priorities for the 2020 budget on this side of the House are the climate emergency and the future of Europe’s young people. I firmly believe that it’s not politicians, but scientists and engineers who will enable the shift to a low—carbon economy. If they are to deliver these advances, it is essential that we give them the tools to do the job. Our investments in science and research are our tools and we should be sharpening them through this budget. And at a time when the changes to the economy affect young people acutely, it is folly to reduce our programmes to mitigate youth unemployment. These structural problems remain a serious issue in many parts of the Union. Yet the Council’s approach thus far is woefully incoherent: indiscriminate flat-rate reductions that fly in the face of its own priorities. The Union budget represents a small fraction of public spending overall, but the big numbers it adds up to enable Europe to respond to the big challenges, and that’s not limited by any border.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, this morning at the European Court of Human Rights, the Human Rights Commissioner of the Council of Europe presented in her findings the following for Turkey: a systematic failure for an independent and impartial administration of justice, which has now become a tool of the ruling Erdogan regime. Yesterday, here in this European Parliament, we were talking about external interventions. The same regime, to which the Council of Europe's Commissioner for Human Rights refers, therefore conceals his interventions in Member States of the European Union under the cloak of religious freedom, as in Bulgaria, but also with the systematic Islamisation of northern occupied Cyprus. This scheme is financed with many millions from the Budget of the European Union. And I am sure that, if European citizens were able to express their opinion, they would refuse this funding with absolute certainty.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, in pre-tax times it is important to be very careful with public spending and use taxpayers' money to prepare for the period of crisis that is inevitably ahead, as evidenced by the slowdown in economic growth across the continent. The spill-in, the allocation of 21% of the overall proposed 2020 budget to tackle climate change, which will predominantly finance costly public policies, is an indication that we have learned nothing from the previous crisis that devastated Europe and created a huge gap between north and south of the continent. The planet must be preserved, it is undeniable, but primarily in partnership with the private sector and creating a positive climate for entrepreneurship and innovation, rather than expensive publicly funded programmes with questionable effects.

name: Ben HABIB
text: – Madam President, this continent has a great debt of gratitude to the United States and NATO in particular, and I’ve heard a lot about the budget allocations for 2020 and, indeed, 2021 to 2027. Within those budget allocations, there is a figure of EUR 21 billion to create a new 10 000-strong border force for the European Union. I find this unfathomable at a time when virtually every country in the European Union – with the notable exceptions of the United Kingdom, Greece, and perhaps one or two others – is not meeting their NATO budget commitments. Something has to be done within this institution to make sure that we uphold our NATO contributions ahead of creating an independent fighting force in the European Union, which is, frankly, something we should not be doing anyway.

name: Kimmo Tiilikainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the House for this interesting and fruitful exchange of views. I made several pages of notes on the honourable Members’ comments, and today’s debate has shown that we have some different views on specific points but most of us share the common goal of establishing a robust budget for 2020. I will now await Parliament’s position on the budget for 2020, as the basis for developing the position on which we will negotiate to reach a final agreement in November. We know that we can count on the Commission to act as an honest broker to bridge the gap between our positions and to propose balanced compromise solutions for us to consider. Europe as a whole requires a budget which meets the needs of its citizens. This means providing for expenditure that is necessary and, at the same time, taking into account that the burden for taxpayers should be as low as possible. I am confident that, with the full dedication of Parliament and the Commission, as well as our own, we will be able to reach an agreement in due time. Thank you for your attention and comments.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – I have proposed an increase of EUR 6 billion in the European Union budget for 2020, supported by my group, the European People's Party. In the last year of the current seven-year budget cycle, it is particularly important that an adequate amount is available in regional and rural development to pay member states' accounts to cover the costs of projects already implemented. My country is at the forefront of the implementation of development programmes, the drawdown of resources, their efficient use for economic growth and job creation, for the benefit of the Hungarian people. In connection with the last year of the current cycle, it is important to point out that the proposal for the next financial framework for 2021-2027 is unacceptable in its current form.  The European Commission's draft sets double standards and would also significantly reduce regional development and agricultural resources. This Hungary unacceptable to the public. EU development funds are not compassionate donations. The Hungarian regions are entitled to these resources on the basis of objective criteria. We reject the linking of Community funds to so-called rule of law conditions and the penality of regions that perform economically well in terms of job creation on trumped-up charges. There is no normative, no proposal for a rule of law in this regard, it is a political instrument by which the European Commission penalises Member States which do not like the policies of the Member States, the decisions of their governments, the expression of the will of the citizens of that country. Such a proposal, which does not respect the minimum rule of law, is inconceivable Hungary support.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the importance of remembering the European past for the future of Europe (2019/2819(RSP)).

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the topic of today’s discussion induces reflection on how we can learn from history. The authoritarian and totalitarian regimes across Europe in the last century remain a dark chapter in our continent’s history. Remembrance is not just remembering. Remembrance is about keeping a memory alive so as not to allow ourselves to overlook horrors that have happened in the past. If we are fully to understand the present and shape a better future, an awareness and understanding of the past is crucial. To quote the Spanish philosopher George Santayana, ‘Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.’ The European Union is based on our common values: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. These values are the cornerstone of democratic societies and the very foundation of our European project. Our common value base has enabled the longest period of peace in Europe. Fortunately, younger generations have not suffered under totalitarian regimes, yet there is now a risk that we are taking these common values and principles for granted. As you know, nurturing and strengthening our common values, and the rule of law in particular, is among the top priorities of our Presidency. The respect for democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law has a strong symbolic value. It is also crucial for the proper functioning of our societies and the policies of the Union. These common values belong to everybody and benefit us all.  My feeling is that we should better involve citizens and civil society to create a union of values for all. Here I think of a garden: beautiful flowers and trees in perfect shape. As an American historian, Robert Kagan writes, ‘an organized society, based on rule of law, is like a garden’. The natural order, according to him, is the jungle. And, like a garden, the rule of law needs constant care and protection, otherwise the jungle grows back. A lack of knowledge about the origins of the Union and about its core principles increases the risk of disinformation and manipulation. It also prevents citizens from developing informed opinions on the actions that the Union takes. On the other hand, knowledge about the diversity, heritage and traditions within the Union and its Member States promotes respect, understanding and cooperation, which in turn strengthens the common sense of belonging.  Last week the Presidency organised in Helsinki a conference on how to ensure the resilience of our societies in a changing European landscape – the interaction between democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. And there was a broad consensus among the participants that shortcomings in respecting our common values make our societies and the Union more vulnerable, both internally and externally. Today we face a number of challenges that put our open societies at risk, be it through xenophobia, nationalism, disinformation or violent radicalisation, to name just a few. We must remember – in order not to get caught in the catchy and attractive-sounding populist voices which promise simple solutions for complex issues. Not only can these promises not be fulfilled, they also discredit our democratic institutions and authorities. The damage of populism to our societies can grow when populists follow the ‘divide and rule’ strategy. They divide our societies into good and bad citizens, us and them, friends and enemies. This undermines a democratic and open political debate, and radicalisation and extremism gain ground. We all need to step up our efforts in preventing intolerance, racism and xenophobia. Europe has already paid a heavy price for this phenomenon in the past. The experience of the two World Wars taught us not to focus on differences but to create a common space in which to live, study and work.  Our societies have now been learning over several generations the value of inclusiveness and tolerance. And of course we should not forget the important role of education and the need to teach our children democratic resilience, media literacy, tolerance, critical thinking and conflict-resolution skills.  I’d like to conclude by stressing that Europeans need to remember their own history in order to learn from the past and not repeat our mistakes when shaping tomorrow’s Europe. By playing our part in a joint effort of protecting the common value base, we are protecting the foundations of our societies and of European integration, peace, security, stability, democracy and prosperity. At the same time we are contributing to a more resilient and sustainable Union. As our Presidency motto puts it, ‘Sustainable Europe – Sustainable Future’. This is the kind of Union that we want to leave for future generations.  Thank you very much for this topical discussion and for your attention.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I’m very glad that this debate has been scheduled because there is no better time to discuss the importance of our collective history in order to build our shared future. In the run-up to, and in the aftermath of, the European elections there has been a lot of debate about what the European Union is and what this concept means to our citizens. The thing is, the European Union is not just a concept. It is the largest and most tangible political, legal, economic and social project that defines our lives on a daily basis. If you can travel freely today across borders, if you can call abroad for the same price as at home, if you study at a university in another Member State and have those credentials recognised, that is because the European Union makes this happen. In order truly to appreciate these freedoms and these opportunities, we need to understand where they come from. We need to keep remembering. You see, these accomplishments did not fall from the sky. They were hard fought and hard earned. This year, we commemorate 30 years since the fall of the Berlin Wall and more than 60 years since the establishment of the very foundations of our Common Market and Union. This Union was built on the ashes that fell over our continent in the aftermath of what happened 80 years ago, and which opened a dark chapter in European history: the signature of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union on 23 August 1939, dividing our continent and creating suffering for so many Europeans under totalitarian regimes. Today we enjoy many different freedoms: to travel without barriers, to speak, to write, to protest, to follow any profession and to live or visit wherever we desire. These rights and freedoms were earned and imparted to us by the huge endeavours of a generation that witnessed at first hand the ravages of two catastrophic wars and suffered their dreadful consequences. We should not forget that we, living and growing up in the European Union as we know it today, are the only generation that has not experienced a war. We need to continue paying tribute to the struggles of our predecessors. It is vital to appreciate fully the meaning of the fundamental values on which the European Union and European democracy are built, and never to take these for granted. In recent years, several challenges have cast a shadow over Europe: the financial crisis, migration, terrorism, disinformation campaigns against our elections, Brexit, to name just a few. Our citizens are rightly worried. Unfortunately, these challenges become a pretext for populists and nationalists to gain more ground, claiming that it is by closing ourselves off that we can overcome them. What a naive, irresponsible, dangerous approach! If we have learned one thing from the past – both the distant and the near past – it is that we can only face them together, in trust. The European Union was not built on adulation, on us against them or on the idea of the survival of the fittest. It was built on the basis of solidarity, of working together, of sharing responsibilities and of caring for and protecting the more vulnerable and weaker. More than ever, we need to remember these lessons from the past because if we ignore history we are at risk of repeating past mistakes. This is why we need to stimulate activities that keep the memories of the past alive as a means of moving beyond the past and towards building the future together. This should never come at the cost of one’s own country or community: we can be both the Europeans and patriots at the same time. That is why we should always strive to reach out to others and make diversity an asset. It is only through collective European actions that we can address citizens’ concerns and meet current challenges and, most importantly, maintain, uphold and strengthen our common European house. This should not necessarily always come from the governments: we want to empower our citizens and civil society too to get involved. The Commission has been in the vanguard with its Europe for Citizens programme, which promotes peace, EU values and the well—being of all. It was set up in the year 2004 with the aim of bringing citizens closer to the European Union. It offers funding for projects on the ground, in which the citizens can reflect on the past, participate in shaping the future and engage. Remembrance, as one of the strands of the programme, supports initiatives to reflect on the causes of totalitarian regimes and to commemorate reference points in Europe’s modern history. Raising awareness of remembrance, the common history and our own EU values is critical. Projects encourage tolerance, mutual understanding, intercultural dialogue and reconciliation as a means of moving beyond the past and building the future. Around 100 000 citizens are directly involved every year in European remembrance projects. In the year 2019, 45 European remembrance projects were selected for financial support for a total amount of EUR 3 million. The selected projects will address priorities such as civil society and civic participation under totalitarian regimes, anti—Semitism, anti—Gypsyism, xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance, as well as democratic transition and accession to the European Union. They will also commemorate major historical turning points in recent European history, such as the 1919 Peace Treaties, bringing the First World War to an end. An example is the Mémorial de la Shoah, a project from 2018. Thanks to a Europe for Citizens grant it has evolved into a truly European reference network on the Holocaust and other genocides. The Mémorial receives more than 250 000 visitors per year. The essence of our programme is to connect citizens. For instance, in early April this year we held, under my auspices, the high—level event ‘Europe for Citizens – History Defines our Future’. More than 300 participants from both the general public and the programme attended. Together with my colleagues Commissioners Jourová and Crețu, we debated with them a range of topics that are crucial for citizens in engaging with Europe. One of them was the diversity of memories in the European Union. Some countries have gone through specific experiences with colonialism or totalitarian regimes: while there are the facts, there is no single truth in the experience of an individual or a community. The question is: how can we reconcile differing memories, how can we build on this diversity and make it an asset for strengthening the European Union? I have trust that supporting remembrance will remain a priority for the new Commission. In May 2018, the Commission proposed a new instrument – the Justice, Rights and Values Fund. This fund will include the Justice programme and a new Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values programme whereby funding is made available to continue supporting work on remembrance. The new programme will guarantee the continuation of the activities of the current Europe for Citizens programme. I will also increase the European Union’s potential to promote and protect rights in the European Union and the European values by encouraging the engagement of all citizens in all aspects of their lives, enabling them to participate in the construction and consolidation of an even closer Europe and union. We, the Commission and I personally, remain consistently committed to a policy of values and historical responsibility. This is the only way for all Europeans, leaders, political parties and citizens, in the future for our common future. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to what promises to be a very interesting discussion.

name: Rasa JUKNEVIČIENĖ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Dear President, the Molotov-Ribentrop Pact and its secret protocols, by which the Nazis and communists shared Europe, led to the Second World War. The war brought an unprecedented amount of suffering – holocaust tragedy, occupations, gulags, exiles – which has been experienced by countless people. Born in occupied Lithuania, I would not have believed that I would ever stand in this Chamber as a Member of the European Parliament. I am a living example of the fact that the enlargement of the European Union and NATO best erases the dividing lines drawn by tyrants. However, even 80 years after the Pact, we still feel its consequences because: – dividing lines remain in the east of Europe. The Kremlin continues to seek to maintain its influence over countries that want to join us – Ukraine, Moldova and Sakartwell; – because Russia is the biggest victim of the Pact. The Kremlin, who lives in the Molotov spirit, promotes Stalinism worship and spreads lies. – because Europe has become the target of information wars. History is also used as a tool of lies. The European Union was born in response to the tragedy of humanity caused by tyrants. Therefore, the resolution we are proposing tomorrow is not just about the past. It is for the future, for the younger generation, so that this story never happens again, and the lines of division of the surviving Europe will disappear definitively. Never again.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Dear President, honourable Minister, honourable Commissioner, dear colleague, historical memory is at the heart of our common strong Europe. Although we all have our own unique history, we are connected as Europeans in a common history. In history, marked by the greatest wars of mankind, millions of victims, brutal Fascist, communist and fascist regimes. The occupiers of all times from the occupied peoples sought to erase historical memory, national self-consciousness, nationality. I myself come from a country, from Lithuania, whose history is painfully marked by forced occupation, mass deportations, Siberian gulags and broken human destinies. Today's debate is another opportunity to remind us that we must not leave history out of bounds. We must resist attempts to glorify the actions of communist, fascist and totalitarian regimes and any attempts to downplay the crimes of these extremely brutal regimes. We must combat growing propaganda and all manifestations of hatred and intolerance. The European Day of Memory, which we commemorate every year, must be more visible and audible so that we will never forget the price we have had to pay for freedom, peace and democracy. Dear colleagues, we are strong only by being united. Preserving historical memory and transferring it to future generations is our duty.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here. There is, indeed, no future for Europe without remembering and being aware of our darkest hours. The Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact with its secret protocols is definitely one of those darkest hours. It may indeed have been the single most brutal and cynical act that Europe has ever witnessed, concluded by two of the most repressive totalitarian regimes in our history. Obviously, we must never forget the victims and we must never forget the heroes who fought and stood up to tyranny. But we must also never forget that the Europe of today came about as a response to the Europe of 1939, and that this union of peace, democracy and shared sovereignty was built as a direct counterpoint to totalitarian atrocities and the partitioning of countries by the raw power of tyrants. This very contrast speaks to the core of our identity and who we are as citizens of the EU, because the EU is perhaps the only political body that defines itself not in opposition to other countries, cultures or organisations but in opposition to its own tragic past. What is crucial here is that this is a common history, because the painful experiences of totalitarianism are shared by both Western and Eastern Europeans and by both new and old Member States, and this provides a crucial common reference despite the 40 years of division in the Cold War. So this is why the European Day of Remembrance on 23 August is so important for pan—European solidarity. Obviously, the main message of that declaration and the resolution we will adopt tomorrow is one of solemn remembrance, but it’s also a message of vigilance against the return of past demons, because what we see today is a dangerous rise in xenophobia and extremism in our societies and Member States. This includes anti-Semitism and the scapegoating of sexual and other minorities as well as migrants, and the silencing of journalists and critics. It is obviously our responsibility to protect the values of tolerance, openness and democracy. If not for anything else, we owe it to the victims whom we honour today.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Dear President, Commissioner, Minister, colleagues. Never again – these words are to be uttered in memory of the Molotov-Ribentrop Pact signed by Communist Russia and Nazi Germany on the twenty-third day of August 80 years ago. The representatives of the two criminal ideologies then decided what the future of sovereign states would be and opened the way for mass murder, genocide, deportation. Finally, for some European countries, this meant a decades-long occupation. It is not just memory that needs to prevent the story from happening again. It is necessary to actively act and denounce the efforts to dominate, to win over the free will of others, to restrict freedoms. The European Union has long been a guarantor of stability. I hope that's what it's like. Peace has been achieved through close cooperation and the possibility of participation in the decision-making process on an equivalent basis for each Member State. The Molotov-Ribentrop Pact will not be repeated if we continue to take decisions by everyone, not in closed offices, in secret meetings, trying to achieve benefits only to a particular group or one country. The pact will not be repeated if we are not forgiving when there is aggression, inciting separatism and terrorism, or spreading disinformation in order to cause mass unrest. Thanks.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Madam President, 80 years ago, the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany signed the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact on 23 August 1939, which paved the way for the outbreak of the Second World War. We must never forget the atrocities committed by these two totalitarian systems of communism and Nazism. This duty of remembrance weighs particularly heavily on Europe, the continent that gave birth to them. The memory of past horrors must be passed on to prevent them from happening again. However, I caution the European Parliament against the temptation to use them to attack Russia today. Russia has cut ties with the Soviet Union since 1991 and has become a respectable state, which deserves to be treated as a partner rather than an enemy. Finally, I warn the European Parliament against another temptation to make an abhorrent amalgam between the Nazis of yesterday and the populists of today. MEPs at the National Rally forcefully denounce this miserable ploy, probably inspired by powerful lobbies, one of whose aims is to demonise the fight against migratory submersion. But we will not falter, we will continue to fight against immigration propaganda, especially when it is embodied, as in France, in a 32-page booklet distributed to school children.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The idea of today's debate and resolution was precisely on the 80th anniversary of the crazy pact, the terrible Ribbentrop-Molotov pact between Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia. It was established in Vilnius during a conference organized under the auspices of former Lithuanian President Valdas Adamkus. Today, after two hours of difficult negotiations, we have been able to agree on a joint motion for a resolution over political divisions. This is a light of hope, that the European Parliament, that Europe is capable of remembrance together, of describing historical events, of drawing conclusions, of honouring all the victims of great totalitarianism and other dictatorships, but also of special honouring those heroes who have fought against terrible regimes, including those who, in our part of the world, in Central and Eastern Europe, have fought against two regimes, and in the light of these facts we would like to call for the establishment of a holy feast on 25 May. , on the anniversary of the execution of one of such heroes, rotmaster Witold Pilecki.

name: Giorgos GEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, after what is being said, I wonder 'whether the whole thing is really wrong or whether we are wrong'. Because even from the honourable Commissioner, a Greek of origin, I would expect to hear that it was the Greek communists who contributed to the country being free today. Others, some other political factions cooperated with the enemies. Do you want me to tell you the truth? The first truth is that it was the Soviet army that liberated the European peoples so that we could be here today. The second truth is that twenty million communists gave their lives to be free today. The third truth is that those who today are trying in various ways to incriminate the communists or to outlaw the communist parties are doing so out of self-interest for certain reasons. That is, to eliminate any resistance to the authoritarianism of the establishment. An establishment that is washed away by children – like Aylan – from the frozen cemeteries of the Mediterranean. An incumbent like that of Europe that produces armies of unemployed people, who kneels against the markets, who constantly sells off to the big industries the funds to produce weapons. Yes, we need to talk about the truth. The truth is that in the face of fascism we stand up precisely for people to hope for the people to have a future.

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, historical awareness for the future of Europe is very important. However, it must be evaluated objectively, impartially. Several mentioned the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact of 23 November 1939. We kind of forget that 29th to 30th 1938 was the Munich Agreement, where France, Great Britain, Germany, Italy made a deal with Hitler and sold my homeland, the original, Czechoslovakia. As a result of this agreement, which was the cause of the war and the cause of the treaty, Czechoslovakia was occupied from the north by Polish troops, from the south by Hungarian troops and in the west by German troops, all of them Poles, Hungarians and others, it was after this agreement with Hitler. But we're not angry about it, we're not going to mention the past, because that's the way to hell. We, as Slovaks and a proud Slovak nation, will not succumb to disinformation either. I am proud that a single nation such as the Slovaks does not need any fight against disinformation, because my nation is so wise, so smart and so intelligent that it will not succumb to disinformation either from the East, from the West, from America, nor from China. Let us make an objective history, let us not distort it, let us not provoke hostility, let us not provoke hostility between Russia and the rest of the world, because this hostility can, precisely such a stance of the European Union and some of my colleagues from Slovakia, lead to another 6 million dead Jews, 25 million Slavs and a bunch of dead poor Germans in demolished Dresden and so on. Let's be respectful to each other. You'll best defeat the enemy when you become friends with him. That's all I had to say.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which What our ancestors had to experience on 23 August 1939 was the political low point in recent European history, where two dictators with actually opposite ideologies united with a dash on the map at the expense of all the other peoples in Europe. We know the immediate consequence: eight days later, the German Empire invaded Poland, and yesterday, 80 years ago, the Soviet Union did the same. What followed is well known. The will "Never again" could develop in peace and freedom with democracy and reconciliation only in the western part of Europe. I am grateful, as a member of one of the two Contracting States of that time, that the other European peoples have welcomed us back into their community – which is why I think we have credibly reversed. No one needs to be afraid of this Germany, embedded in the EU and NATO. The people of Russia, who were victims of their own dictatorship and of the German attack, deserved that the other peoples of Europe today should no longer be afraid of today's Russia. Unfortunately, current Russian politics and its leaders do not give any reason to hope that we can expect this soon. That is why we, as democracies in Europe, must stand together, also in remembrance of what happened and how it came about.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Madam President, earlier this month, we commemorated the 80th anniversary of the beginning of the Second World War. It is important not to forget the millions who perished in that great tragedy, and to honour those who fought to defeat the evil of Nazism. It is also important to remember that it was the pact signed just a week earlier by Nazi Germany and Communist Soviet Union that allowed Hitler to invade Poland and Stalin to occupy and annex the three Baltic countries. It is important to remember that by the time arms fell silent in Europe, almost six years later, a big part of our continent had not been liberated at all, but continued to suffer under authoritarian regimes and external domination for another half century.  If we forget about the darkest chapters of our history, or allow our memory to become selective, we risk being again vulnerable to threats to our democracy that arise from authoritarianism and illiberalism. These threats may come from the outside, in the form of illegal attempts to interfere in our democratic processes, but they may also come from the inside in the form of extremist political movements preaching homophobic, xenophobic and illiberal ideas and ideologies. Only if we remember are we able to avoid repeating the tragic mistakes of the past and protect the European ideas and ideals.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, memory is important for the future of Europe. The authors of this resolution, which we are discussing, were right to point that out. It is a question of learning from the tragedies that shook our continent during the 20th century. The best way to do this is to act so that we can have historically established facts, irrefutable facts that may have been inscribed in history. History is important, the duty of remembrance will have to be gradually replaced by the duty of history. This leads me to renew a request that I have had the opportunity to express many times, including in this Parliament: when will the Nuremberg actions finally be translated into all the working languages of the European Union? This will help fuel history and civics courses in our schools, thereby enabling young people to access the atrocities that may have occurred in the past.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: – Madam President, how can we build a common future if we don’t remember our common past? Nobody is immune to amnesia; in my country of Germany, every second German does not want to deal with the history of the totalitarian GDR. We must continue commemorating the victims of the Holocaust – the Jews, the Sinti and Roma, and the homosexuals – but coming from Berlin, I also insist we also must talk about the fate of our Eastern European friends, of the Balts and of the Poles. This is something we owe to those countries as someone who was on the other side in the war. This is something that we need to bring to life, talking to the young people sitting over there, bringing it to their schools, bringing it to the internet and awakening the history. But we need to do more; we need to start listening and hearing the concerns of our Eastern European friends. Yes, their security concerns and their energy concerns are all rooted in their tragic past, and we have to start hearing them in order to build a common, a truly common, European foreign policy. This will be the answer to the tragic past and to the future.  (Applause)

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The problem with these memorabid cultural papers is always that they relate to the negative aspects of European history. This is necessary, but it is too one-sided if the reference to Greek philosophy, Roman law, Christian Middle Ages, Renaissance and Enlightenment is lacking. We must not just convey a negative image of what shapes our identity. But even if we devote ourselves to what went wrong, which caused crime, the question arises as to why we do not devote ourselves to the spiritual foundations. It is absurd for those who helped to put it into the works, particularly with regard to communist terror, and their current successors, who still refer to this line-up, to think that they must dictate a culture of remembrance. What constitutes the identity of a region and a continent is the positive and these are the lessons of the past. Either we look at it as a whole and without ideology, or it will be nothing more than a set-up teaching project that we can conceive here in Strasbourg and Brussels, but that misses the hearts and minds of the people – and this paper deserves nothing else.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Our Lady of the Presidency, the respected presiding father, I wanted to talk about communism, fascism and Nazism, but I could not get over it, Mrs. Tuppurainen and Mr. Avramopoulos, when you claim that we are the only generation that has not experienced war. Gentlemen, Croatia was not a member of the European Union in 1991, but it was also a part of Europe. It offends me that you forget the Serb-Chetnik aggression against Croatia, with the help of Jugovaska, then the third military power in Europe. Gentlemen, defending their freedom and independence, 8257 Croatian defenders, 5657 civilians, among them many children, died in Croatia. We are still searching somewhere for about 1,200 missing persons, not to mention billions and billions of euros in damages committed in the war. For one small Croatia of 4.3 million inhabitants, this is a great tragedy for which the inertia of the European Union is partly to blame, so I expected you to mention this war imposed on Croatia in 1991, even by the way.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, I come from the south, from the second country in the world with the most mass graves as a result of a fascist dictatorship. I come from the country full of squares and streets with names of Franco murderers. From the unmoired country that has erased from its public life what happened in its recent history. It is striking that this Parliament, through this resolution, instrumentalizes history and does not make a single mention of what is happening in Spain yet. We're not just talking about the past, we're talking about the present too. It would be very desirable if, when we debated memory, we also talked about the role that Spanish Republican fighters played in s stop fascism in Europe. Or the example of solidarity of the International Brigades. That is why we take this opportunity to demand a memory and repair directive that values the anti-phase fight, as well as the appropriate funds for the exhumation of pits from Francoism in Spain. The essential memory in today's Europe, plagued by new fascism, is that we recognise the role of those who left their lives to combat it.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, today's sitting, it is obvious, is not about the debate on either memory or the future. It's a real debut of vulgar anti-communism. That's it, that's it! The anti-communist resolutions tabled are despicable, provocatively unspeakable. They need to be withdrawn. They must be voted down because the people will then judge very harshly those who give them a vote. The objective behind these feasibility constructs that legitimise the prohibition of the action of communist parties, communist symbols, communist ideology, which generalise persecution against communists and the popular forces that are fighting are precisely the peoples of Europe and the struggles they are waging. These resolutions are pioneered by reactionary scottish forces in the Visegrad and Baltic countries, countries that heroise Nazism by washing it away, which sow racist poison. The Soviet Union's decisive contribution to the crushing of fascism and Nazism and to the eternal condemnation of their crimes is watered with the blood of millions of dead, millions injured, incalculable sacrifices of the anti-fascist struggle of the peoples of Europe. Those who fought against fascism and Nazism boldly call them Hitler's collaborators. But no matter how dirty ink is spilled, the historical truth will shine. Capitalism causes enormous suffering to the people. Socialism, a world without exploitation, wars, poverty and unemployment is the way out, it is the future. The history was written by the people and is not rewritten by resolutions. Anti-communism won't pass!

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This debate proves why we need this resolution. Colleagues on the far left say that the Red Army defeated Hitler, and that's true. But they do not want to remember that the Soviet Union for two years was an ally of fascist Germany, and they do not want to remember that communist regimes are responsible for the deaths of about one hundred million of their own citizens. In turn, a colleague from the French far right says that modern Russia has cut off from the legacy of the Soviet Union. Unfortunately, this is not true. Literally in recent days we have had official statements by the Russian authorities, ministries, embassies denying the facts of the pact with Hitler and the invasion Polish. So we need this day of remembrance. And I would like to agree with my predecessor Minister Anna Fotyga that a very good patron of such Polish day would be Witold Pilecki, an officer who volunteered for Auschwitz. Think about it. He would be a very good patron of such a day, because instead of rewarding his unsuching heroism, he was murdered by the communist authorities in a ffing trial. So, Madam President, I would like to support this resolution.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In order to be able to explain to the younger generation how today came about and to give them the tools to shape the tomorrow, we must remember yesterday. Without knowledge of the cruel world wars that have brought death, misery and destruction upon all of us, of the division of Europe by the Iron Curtain, but also without an understanding of the similarities between the peoples of Europe that we find in culture, it is impossible to understand the meaning of our international community. But remembering is only possible if we protect our cultural heritage, if there are exhibitions that allow for remembrance, and if we offer high-quality history, culture, and music and art classes in our schools. Remembering cannot work without the necessary efforts in cultural and educational policy. The cuts that the Council has unfortunately made in these areas speak a different language. It is also unacceptable to me that the President-designate of the Commission does not mention the terms culture and education in any of the titles of the future Commissioners – for the first time in 20 years, incidentally. This needs to be changed as a matter of urgency. I expect the new Commission to give more, not less, importance to these policy areas. Culture and education must no longer lead a shadowy existence, because without them, it is not possible to remember in the end.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On September 1, 1939, the most terrible and inhumane time in Europe began, culminating in the atrocities of the Holocaust, in which millions of innocent people – Sinti, Jews, Roma, disabled people, Jehovah's Witnesses, homosexuals – were bestially murdered by the Nazis. A date at this time when Nazi beasts bestially murdered our people is especially remembered by the victims and their bereaved families: 16 May 1944. On this day, the last Sinti and Roma were to be murdered in Auschwitz. But the women and children fought back desperately against the Nazis and armed themselves with shovels and sticks and defended their lives. With their rebellion, they won a short postponement of their assassination, which took place on August 2. May 16th is intended to commemorate this uprising against racial delusion and National Socialism, so that such a thing never happens again.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the theme of a shared European memory – especially today, 80 years after the signing of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact and 30 years after the fall of the 'Iron Curtain' – is a fundamental value so that young people never forget the tragic consequences of the totalitarianism of the twentieth century and are able to shape the present, day after day, with a full awareness of our freedoms. However, the right commitment to transmitting common values and perspectives cannot and must not become the instrument of propaganda aimed at creating a grey globalised and standardised humanity. The true greatness of Europe lies in its identities, in its bell towers and in full respect between institutions, local authorities and families. "Duty of remembrance" is first and foremost to defend our Christian roots and to affirm that they constitute the main foundation of our tolerance and certainly not an obstacle to it. The 'duty of remembrance' is above all to defend the borders of our Europe from unholy immigrationist policies aimed at exploiting individuals and not protecting them. "Duty of remembrance" is also, for my country, to finally do full justice to the fallen of the foibe.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to point out that we are meeting one day after the 80th anniversary of the day when the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact entered into force. It was then that the Soviet Union attacked Poland, which had previously been attacked by Nazi Germany. The Soviet Union said it was protecting the Belarusian and Ukrainian populations. This protection consisted of millions of exports to concentration camps in Siberia, this protection consisted of terror. Dear. Nazism is over. The Soviet Union was over, but these practices remained. Look at Georgia. Take a look at Crimea. Look at the east of Ukraine. There today, bullets are still whizzing.  We must learn from these events for the future of Europe.

name: Alexis GEORGOULIS
text: Madam President, memory is one of the most important goods of human society and that is why it is in the interest and appropriate to create spaces, museums and monuments that keep memory alive and keep unity and human values high. But we must be careful what passes through eternity and what world we create for generations to come. Historically, building collective memory has proven to be particularly difficult. This is because the pseudoscientific charge of history, for the purpose of emotional blackmail of memory, nourishes hatred instead of nurturing culture. After all, the recovery of memory can only be redeeming when it is transmitted through the works of art and culture. It is therefore regrettable to see the word 'culture' deleted from the Commissioners' portfolios. What message does this send to our cultural industry and to our citizens who stand united in diversity? If we want to keep our culture alive, we have to create it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I note with regret that some people would like to use this debate to turn it into an unnecessary wetting of which authoritarian regime has been fiercer or more totalitarian. The day of remembrance cannot and must not be used, ladies and gentlemen, to divide us on the condemnation of the past: it must always united us in protecting the future. Remembering the memory of millions of victims of totalitarianism is an antidote to the new generations who have not imprinted the horrors of the last century on their minds or engraved on their skin. Getting lost in a sterile clash over which regime has been most atrocious is not only not useful but is absolutely harmful and harmful to young people, who are only confused and distracted by the real danger: indifference or worse condescension towards authoritarian characters who, in order to obtain cheap popular consent, exploit the path of hatred, anger, ignorance, prejudice and intolerance. With a single purpose: to obtain absolute power, whatever it costs, even to eliminate those who do not want to conform to their idea of society. What prepares modern humans so well for totalitarian rule is estrangement, said the philosopher Hannah Arendt, who has never mentioned enough. In order to save the new generations of Europeans from violence, war and injustice, we must preserve at all costs the memory of those who survived. But it is not enough to remember: we need concrete actions and political choices that are truly respectful of our values, if we want to prevent despair and alienation, without inconsistencies and without hesitation. Because on the day we hesitate, ladies and gentlemen, we will have already lost.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – (the beginning of the intervention was not done at the microphone) ... The Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact is one of the most wicked political acts of the last few centuries that have had effects on the territory of Europe.  A lot of people say, "It's been 80 years." I can tell you that today Romania still lives by the will of Hitler and Stalin. The Romanian people were divided into two parts: one part in Romania and the other in the Republic of Moldova. I can also tell you that the consequences of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact were the spheres of influence, which for the countries of Eastern Europe meant the establishment of communism. These things we must remember and understand that the European Union is today's answer that guarantees democracy for all of Europe to the ticaness of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate on the value of memory is essential in order to strengthen the European project and to bet on the future of Europe, especially at a time like this, marked today by new neo-nationalist pressures and also by attempts – as was discussed yesterday in this House – to call into question European democracy through actions and interference from outside forces. To discuss memory, in fact, in a forum which is extraordinarily relevant to world democracy, such as this one, is to reflect on its topicality. That is why I want the words of an extraordinary woman, Liliana Segre, holocaust survivor, auschwitz survivor and now italian senator, who is obstinently committed to combating racism and neo-nationalist drift, to be spoken here and to defend our common home: "Cultivating memory – says Segre – is still today a precious vaccine against indifference and helps us, in a world so full of injustice and suffering , to remember that each of us has a conscience and can use it"."

name: Christophe GRUDLER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the duty of remembrance is, as the name suggests, a duty for us MEPs. It gives meaning to the work we do, and it helps us understand where we want to go. Roots are what allows a tree to grow loud and clear. To do that, we have to give ourselves the financial means. The previous programme, 'Europe for Citizens', demonstrated its effectiveness and added value, with EUR 200 million spent on memory-related field actions. If the European Commission really wants to promote the duty of remembrance, Commissioner, it must give itself the financial means to do so. In the next multi-year budget framework, the Commission must support the amounts proposed by Parliament for the new "Rights and Values" memorial programme. To date, the account is not there. The Commission has halved the "memory" budget proposed by Parliament. We have to react!

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European culture of remembrance is an important issue, even if we do not notice this in the presence of Members today. But without a true account of what was, no proper memory is possible. That is why the motion is important, and it also contains a great deal of correct, albeit some questionable, claims. Above all, however, the 22 recommendations on European culture of remembrance do not even include the word Jew. As if the Jews were not part of European history and as if they were not the main victims of the Nazi mass murder. Even Auschwitz is mentioned only in connection with a Polish resistance fighter. One understands the intention behind it, because the mention of the unique suffering of the Jews would immediately raise the question of Europe's responsibility for the existence of Israel and also about the eu's policy and its scandalous support for the deeply corrupt Palestinian Relief Fund of the UN. You want a day of remembrance to counteract, as you write, the distortion of facts. You yourself distort the facts in your almost compulsive refusal to mention the Jews even once. The motion as it is is wrong, because it once again injures the Jewish victims by hiding them, concealing them and forgetting them.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab "False history is a master of erroneous politics" – this well-known saying of a prominent Polish historian of the nineteenth century can also be applied to the history of World War II. How it was and is presented had political consequences (we are also convinced in this debate) and vice versa – it was the political motives that led to the distorted picture of the past. Why has the Hitler-Stalin system been displaced for so long? Or not because we would not admit that there would not have been World War II if it had not been for the alliance of these two hideous, bloody regimes. In order not to have to translate from the later alliance of the Western Allies with Stalin, despite the knowledge of crimes such as the Katyn massacre, in order to uphold the ongoing myth of the Red Army as the liberator of Europe, not to translate from Yat, etc. The fact that we are starting to talk about this pact today raises the hope that maybe we will learn the right lessons from history.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, historical remembrance matters. It is too important therefore to be manipulated for political ends. This motion and the amendments seem less concerned with genuine commemoration, and more with a cynical abuse of the Second World War to fight factional battles and push contemporary agendas. We’ve got the EPP shamefully using remembrance to push an EU expansionist agenda today. We’ve got Renew promoting national educational curricula to propagandise EU federalism to young people in the here and now. Then there’s the S&D piggy backing on a historic fight for freedom against authoritarianism, to propose illiberal, authoritarian and censorious regulations to silence opponents and delegitimise them with the label ‘extremist’. What a gross insult to the memories of real anti-Fascists, the French and Jewish resistance, the heroes of the Warsaw ghetto, the leftists who fought Franco in Spain, and the soldiers on the Russian front and on D-Day. I salute my fellow Europeans for that historic fight and note that cross-European acts of bravery are proof that cross-national solidarity existed before and is not dependent on institutionalised EU unity. Meanwhile, the EU’s revisionist history seems highly selective in what is remembered. Lest we forget, World War II was partly a fight against expansionist empire building trampling over national borders. Let’s remember it was a World War in which millions of non-Europeans fought for freedom and democracy and went on to fight for their own self-determination and national sovereignty – two Enlightenment principles that this Parliament seems to want us to forget, and contemptuously write out of history.  While I’m forced to be here, not on my watch, I’ll remind you every time, national sovereignty it is.  (Applause)

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, 80 years ago, two dictators signed the documentary beginning of The Second World War and began to share a villainous Europe. Although they have their ideological differences, the national socialist and communist regimes are two faces of the same evil – totalitarianism.  In the 20th century, this evil brought disproportionate suffering, destruction and millions of innocent victims to our continent. Towards the end of The Second World War brought the defeat of one of the regimes, but the other was left by the world's democracies then enslaved for decades half of Europe. We are in a duty to the younger generations to give them the memory of the horrors our continent has gone through.  I want to congratulate the Bulgarian government and the Ministry of Education on the adoption of the new curricula in Bulgaria, which finally objectively reflect the events of the 20th century. I call on the Commission to provide adequate funding for projects related to the preservation of the memory of the victims of all totalitarian regimes and the study of archives. Let us protect memory and never again allow national socialism, communism, fascism or any other totalitarian ideology to poison the hearts and souls of Europeans. And to the colleague from Spain, who rightly worries that there are street names of dictators in her country. But did you know that in Bulgaria almost every second name is of a dictator or one of their supporters, which has resulted in hundreds, tens of thousands of casualties. Let us together honor the memory of all, not just the one – both the communist victims, the national socialist victims, and the fascist victims, all – and the communist victims. You forget about this very often – both from the extreme left and from the extreme right.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Thank you, President-in-Office. I agree that it is important to remember the past in order to improve the future. However, more importantly, we do not repeat these mistakes in the present, because we are repeating our history. None of this and similar resolutions, which have already been adopted by the European Parliament very much, can be really useful if, at the same time, we tolerate the actions that this resolution condemns, and that is the suppression of democracy, the failure to respect the rule of law, the denial of rights to minorities and the other, autocracy, nationalism. In English, we have a saying: sweep before your doorstep. Warning of the mistakes of others is only sensible and effective if we do not make these same mistakes ourselves.  In the European Union, it has long been not just lapsuse or ignorant error: no, failure to comply with the agreed rules is clearly becoming an acceptable practice that goes unpunished. I expect a thorough debate on the content, naming and bearers of the commission during the hearings in October – because our work and the future of our citizens will depend on it.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, I strongly believe that the European Union is a project of the future. It brings democratic European nations together. However, while looking into the future, we need to draw comprehensive conclusions from our common past. Our past was often about wars, destruction, totalitarianism and atrocities which destroyed lives irreversibly. Post—war reconciliation enabled us to achieve stability, confidence and cooperation. But let’s be sincere. The process is not over yet. Such examples as the recent statement by Russian senior official, Sergei Ivanov, denying Soviet occupation of the Baltic States is a great reminder of the surviving approach of denial and unacceptable attempts to rewrite history. Grounds for the future cooperation of European nations are laid today in the history classes of our schools and cross—border cooperation initiatives. That’s why I am calling for greater investment in European remembrance based on mutual understanding, studying, teaching our joint history and nurturing our European way of life.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are behind the 80th anniversary of the outbreak of the Second World War, when Poland was attacked by Germany and the Soviet Union, and which many people do not want to remember, also betrayed by the countries with which it had a signed agreement. Poles for being honorable and not collaborating with Hitler, like many countries, suffered terrible losses. Destroyed cities, burned capital, the slaughter of Will, which I will recall many more times here in this House. About 50% of cultural goods were destroyed and looted. We have destroyed 75% of railway resources, 65% of energy resources, 70% of the chemical, printing and other industries. The wealth losses of the Polish people amounted to almost 38% of the resources from 1939. By comparison, France or the United Kingdom were losses of 1%, not almost 40%. We were murdered 35% of doctors, scientists, lawyers, our elite was murdered in Katyn, in Miednoje. We have lost almost 6 million citizens, including 3 million citizens of Jewish origin. In return, Poland was betrayed and given to the Soviet Union for a long time. Such a fate, which met Poland for being preserved honorably, will still be a long time of remorse for many who today want to draw Poland's attention, this is special when it comes to historical proceedings.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Today's debate commemorates the victims of communist and national socialist dictatorships. We Hungarians and the nations of Central and Eastern Europe are well aware of the misaddoctangling committed by both shameful dictatorships. Nevertheless, we regret that in a united Europe there is disproportionately little talk of the actions of communism. Yet the Communists destroyed the entire life of my grandparents' generation, and their present was stolen. But they couldn't take away one thing from them: the support, the all-surviving faith in the future. This is what makes the nations of Central and Eastern Europe really strong. It is necessary to know this period of central and eastern European history and to keep its memory alive in order to understand the present reality of post-communist nations. For Europe's unity to truly be achieved, the reality of the crimes of communism must be recognised and condemned at the same level. This empathy is still lacking in the luckier half of Europe, where the tyranny of communism did not have to be suffered. It is disappointing that the condemnation of communism can still be smeared and divisive, here in Parliament, and that the emphasis is being diverted from the substance of the problem. Yet Europe cannot be united until there is a consensus on this issue.

name: Laurence FARRENG
text: Madam President, this resolution on European memory raises the question of European Heritage and places of remembrance. We want to celebrate the European memory, and for that we need places. Museums, memorials and memorials are all sites that make the geography of our memory. Our Union has a duty to maintain them, to protect them, to value them, so that citizens can refer to concrete places and sites, so that they also continue to inspire our action and be transmitted to the younger generations, through appropriate, modern and integrated means of communication in our national educational programmes. Initiatives exist, such as the European Heritage Label or the European Heritage Days, which take place this weekend. But we need more voluntarism in the protection of these monuments which, by recalling the tragedies of the past, are the foundation of our rights and values. At a time when there is a worrying resurgence of extremist movements, European memories must inspire the future of Europe, in a visible and lively way.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This resolution will, in my opinion, be one call: "No more Ribbentrop-Molotov pacts, no more Katyn, no more death camps, no more death camps, no more millions of people! In a word: no more war!" And that is what we should have in our hearts, and today also in this debate: respect, partnership and understanding.  My country is in the European Union today, but then it was a bloody victim of two of the most ancesiest totalitarianism in the history of the world. Countries like Poland are still feeling the effects of war and half-century-old Soviet domination. We have not reformed everything yet, but unfortunately our attempts are not always accepted. Therefore, today the values that were once lacking, these values caused unnecessary and dangerous conflicts.  But Europe is not just a Union. And it must be made clear today that the armed conflict in Ukraine should be our concern. Poland hosted children, orphans. In the 21st century, there are orphans of war in Europe! Such situations should never happen, and we should also talk about it.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work. Ribentrop - Molotov Pact for millions of Europeans, too, is a deeply personal story for me. For after the bloody Second World War, the nations that were imprisoned behind the Iron Curtain, death and repression continued for decades. Three of my grandparents are buried in the Soviet gulga. My mother in Siberia has been plagued for seventeen years, but father of eight, and I was born there. There are many such fates in the Baltic States. However, the peoples of the Baltic States have been able to turn their suffering and losses into victory. Thirty years ago, on 23 August, 2 million Baltics were in their hands and formed a 650-kilometre Baltic road. So we reminded the world of our right to regain our deprived countries and freedom. So the Baltic Way became the way back of our peoples to Europe. History must therefore be known in order not to give up and believe in the future and justice. I therefore firmly believe that Ukraine will one day recover the illegally annexed Crimea. Thank you!

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Dear Chairman, 80 years have passed since the two totalitarian ideologies agreed in the common secret Molotov-Riebbentrop pact dividing Europe into spheres of interest, thus clearing the way for the start of one of the bloodiest wars Europe has experienced. This year again on August 23rd we marked by burying the victims of previously unexplored tombs.
