Sixty years after the war, they remain as a caution to what an eclipse of consciousness and single-mindedness can bring to Europe. The collapse of fascism, Nazism and communism brought freedom and democracy that today some in Europe take for granted. Working on the truth and shedding light on all that remains behind these single-minded animals is the only way we can come to reconciliation, individually and consequently collectively. The horror and violence these dark ideologies left behind by beginning an alliance under the cover of darkness and secret agreements must be shed light on all generations to know the consequences of tyranny and single-mindedness.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is our duty to remember sad events precisely so that they are not forgotten, so that human tragedies of entire nations cannot be repeated in the future. On September 1, World War II was launched by infestation of Poland. Subsequently, Poland was invaded by the Soviet Union. And it took a long six years to end World War II. But then another dictatorship began, and other countries suffered for 45 years under the Communist dictatorship. We carry a great legacy of hatred, suffering, death, lost lives to this day. And so, as the foremen said here, it needs to be remembered where they have not experienced this form of dictatorship.... (the President interrupted the speaker)

name: Nicola BEER
text: Just a second, we have no interpretation for the moment, we will try to arrange this. Maybe you can carry on a little bit and we will see if it works?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I will therefore repeat that both dictatorships were equally terrible. In order to maintain our unity and diversity, we must recall what events have led to this, and we must also remind ourselves that there is a Ukraine that is occupied, suffering from disinformation on the part of Moscow and occupation, and therefore it is our moral duty to support and bring the European Union closer to Ukraine, precisely in view of the terrible history that we are commemorating today.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a Europe divided in two, where, on one side of the wall, people were free and, on the other, people were prevented from expressing themselves and moving freely, that was my youth. It was not history, but a daily reality that, on both sides of the Iron Curtain, marked the spirits. I remember the sense of injustice felt in the face of the arbitrary nature of this dividing line, which emerged from the Second World War, and the chance I had to be on the side of freedom. I have been told about the Second World War and its atrocities. I remember the horror felt by the teenager I was when I discovered, during a visit to a concentration camp, the atrocities committed during that war.  Today, however, it seems that, as the years pass, the reality of exterminations, the inhuman use of human beings, as if they were any material, is covered with a kind of mitigating veil, even going so far as to allow the denial of the existence of these realities. This is unacceptable! The memory of our history is not only a duty of respect to those who have perished and suffered, but also a way of combating extremism of all stripes that today is growing.  Our history imposes on us Europeans a duty of remembrance. We need to educate our young people about what happened, and we must remain vigilant if we are to protect ourselves from a future that could repeat the crimes of the past.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The resolution that I hope we will adopt tomorrow, and of which I am a co-author, is, of course, rooted in history, but we must learn lessons for the future from these dramatic events that cost the lives of millions of victims. The Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact, which is a symbol of an alliance of two totalitarians, must not be forgotten and must be a science for the future, because all those who ignore radicalism, nationalism, actually allow what happened in Europe of the twentieth century to repeat itself in the future. This must not be allowed, there is no permission to do so.  That is why I appeal to everyone to respond to the extreme movements that were born in some societies (we also see this in Poland yesterday, which yesterday celebrated the 80th anniversary of the onslurged of Russian communism, which tried to deprive Poles of their freedom and identity), which, using the symbolism of totalitarian systems, falsifying history, using propaganda, sometimes also do so by populist politicians, well, in short, they are tearing down this historic duty of Europeans to build a safe Europe. , free from totalitarianism, free from these threats, which may constitute a new pact of selfishness and nationalism. We must defend this freedom in Europe by reacting fiercely to radicalism.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Then we move on to requests outside the list of speeches and there are now so many of them that I can perhaps award less than half of them, five copies. In fact, there are 15 and the sitting is behind.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, of course it is important that European society does not forget its past. It is necessary to remember, know and learn from our history, with its lights and its shadows. Remember and honor the victims. And the importance of remembering what we fought for, which is for the freedom we all enjoy. But, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to alert you to something I observe with great concern. And it's warning them that it's not up to us to write the story. Politicians must not impose a single account of history. You can't use history as a political weapon. I know what I am talking about, because this is what the Spanish left has been trying to do for a few years, with the Historical Memory Law, in Spain. A single account of history cannot be imposed by law. The mission of writing history is the work of historians, ladies and gentlemen, historians. Our job, yours and mine, is to ensure that historians can work within a framework of freedom. And, on the other hand, education. Humanities education of the new generations. It is the humanities that form the judgment and critical capacity that give people the tools to reason and seek the truth.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, the Commissioner asked the question: how do you remember and honour the past, a past filled with war and conflict and borders? Well, in my opinion as a human-rights lawyer for over 25 years, I would suggest that we respect human rights and human dignity. How do we do that? We respect the rule of law, we respect human life, we respect freedom of association and speech, and we respect living a life in dignity, for older people, for children, for individuals in all their diversity, not excluding anyone. It means enabling human dignity through economic prosperity and a freedom to live the way we wish to. How do we do this? It is enshrined in our human rights instruments that came on line after the Second World War: the European Convention on Human Rights, the UN Charter, all of the international conventions that we have at the moment, and our European Charter of Human Rights. And, of course, finally, for Britain to stay in the EU.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Yesterday in Poland we celebrated the 80th anniversary of Soviet aggression, and ten years ago, on the 70th anniversary of Westerplatte, on the 70th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II, the Prime Minister of the Russian Federation relativised the reasons for the outbreak of World War II, referring to the injustice of the Treaty of Versailles. Foreign Minister Molotov, after Russia's Soviet aggression against Poland, used this term at Polish in Russian ypoдливoе детище, which translates to mean a sneak bastard.  Yesterday, the day before yesterday, we could hear from the mouths of Russian politicians another attempt to relativise history. We are talking about Europe's past in the context of its future, but this future must be based on truth, and the truth is that there would be no modern Europe if it were not for Greek philosophy, Roman law and values learned from the Old and New Testaments, namely Christianity. John Paul II left us the patron saint of Europe, a nun of Jewish origin murdered in Auschwitz-Birkenau. At that time, the world did not take into account the voice of Rotmistrz Pilecki, did not take into account the voice of Jan Karski, Jan Nowak-Jeziorański.  Let us not allow, as part of another totalitarianism, no longer Soviet, not Nazi, to allow totalitarianism of political correctness based on... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – The deplorable attempt to equate fascism and communism absolves and silences the crimes of Nazi-fascism and the conniving responsibilities of the great capitalist powers which, with the Munich Treaty, among others, paved the way for the beginning of World War II and the invasion of the Soviet Union. A complicity that persists today. They want to erase the decisive contribution of the Communists to the defeat of Nazi-fascism. His contribution to the liberation of peoples, as in my country, Portugal, with the Carnation Revolution that ended the fascist regime. They want to erase their role in advancing the living conditions of workers, but they want more, they want to pave the way to legitimise and generalise the persecution and prohibition of communist parties, as is already the case in several Member States or in Ukraine, with the complicity of the European Union. At the same time they tolerate the rehabilitation and historical praise of fascism. This historical review obviously aims to divert attention from the European Union's ongoing confrontation with the aspirations of peoples and the development of repressive tendencies and practices to limit rights and freedoms.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, with primitive anti-communism and unspeakable rape of the truth, the European Union and the European Parliament are trying to exonerate fascism. You coincide with those in the Visegrad and Baltic countries who pay tribute to nazi collaborators and have the audacity to call "criminals" and "Hitler's collaborators" the communists, the Soviet Union, who pioneered the struggle of the peoples to root out the monster of fascism in Europe. History wrote that Nazi collaborators were the monopolies that the European Union supports and paved the way for Hitler. They were urban governments like Vichy's in France, the Quislings in Greece. The provocative equation of communism with the abomination-birth of capitalism, fascism, will not pass! You are in a state of shock if you think that with historical misery and fat funds you will legitimise prohibitions, persecutions against communists and prevent socialism from being the future of the world. Withdraw it now! Every Member of the European Parliament must vote against this insult in history etched with the blood of the people.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, dear colleagues, let me start by expressing my thanks for this lively and very interesting debate, which proved to be very timely. As you know, every year the Commission marks 23 August as the day when we honour the memory of the millions of victims of all totalitarian regimes. Totalitarianism is not about ideology or colour – it is about authoritarian mentality, practice and methodology. Totalitarianism is an enemy of democracy, freedom and human dignity. Our duty is to keep those memories alive to inspire and guide new generations in defending fundamental rights, the rule of law and democracy. We firmly stand together against whatever threatens the values of our European democracy. I see here in this House a collective and democratic commitment to defend, uphold and safeguard the European project.  This European project was started in the aftermath of the Second World War, when wise and determined leaders – although it was very fresh in their memories what they had experienced just some years ago – took the historical decision to lay the foundations and to create a wider space of liberty, peace, democracy and stability. It is exactly what we Europeans are enjoying today.  However, we should never take this for granted. It is our duty to take this project forward. Today we know that certain challenges are putting the European Union into question. Now is the moment to show leadership towards our citizens. We must never forget both the privilege and the responsibility that we have inherited from our founding fathers and the previous generations. This is why it is paramount not only to remember, but also to ensure that history is not repeated.  If we ignore, or fail to understand or read history, we cannot draw lessons from the past. This is the biggest threat to our future that we are facing. This was the consequence in the past, when history was indeed ignored.  Today’s debate gives me hope, because I know how committed this institution is, together with the European Commission. Together we must uphold our duties towards our citizens. While some may try to make us believe that our citizens are losing faith or the connection with the European Union, we know that the opposite is true. In fact, we have data telling us that, on average, more than 70% of the citizens of Europe feel that they are EU citizens, while at the same time being attached to their homelands, to their nations. This figure has been steadily increasing, even since 2012, when it was at the level of 61%. We need to continue working together towards making all citizens of this Union feel like European citizens. By working together, I mean involving the whole society from all corners and strata.  Cooperation is in our European spirit, and synthesis is at the core of our democracy, because being European is not just a nice pleasant motto, it is the essence of tolerance, pluralism and solidarity. It is the recognition of our common values and humanity, as well as our common will and determination to live in a fair, free and peaceful world.  It is the embracement of diversity, multilingualism and respect for different cultures, identities and traditions. It is to care for each other, to love our own nation, to respect our neighbours, to share the feelings of belonging in our European family.  I hope that these efforts will be sustained with your support for a Union that remembers its past, draws lessons from it and does not revert to it – a Union that shatters silence, empowers unity and shines as a global beacon and as a unique paradigm of solidarity among citizens, communities and nations.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, we need to learn a lot from our history in these times where our common values are fragile and need to be upheld. Together, we must now tackle the rise of extreme ideas and, for instance, the rise of anti—Semitism across Europe. This is a common challenge to all of us. Raising awareness and ensuring appropriate information are key elements for fighting against extremism and disinformation. Education can be a powerful tool in this respect, and we need to continuously make efforts to safeguard our free societies. Our youth, the generations to come, need to remember and learn from the mistakes made in our common history. The future of Europe should be based on common values, mutual understanding of our diverse traditions, and shared awareness of the history of Europe, including totalitarianism. Let’s keep our garden of rule of law maintained. Thank you very much, once again, for your engagement in this highly important topic. Thank you, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I have received four motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 19 March 2008. The rapporteur was Mr S.A. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. The most serious crimes against humanity in the 20th century were committed by the Nazi and Communist totalitarian regimes. Millions of people have lost their lives or suffered during deportations and incarceration. These sins of the past must be talked about, taught in history class, and reminded never to happen again. Most of the Nazi crimes came to light, the impeachment took place, the victims were compensated, but there is little talk of the victims of communism. For example, the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia, whose male d'18-50 years of age was deported in 1944 to forced labour camps by the occupying Soviet power, the so-called "Manic robot", on the basis of the principle of collective guilt, was deported to forced labour camps, from which very few returned alive. In the time of the Soviet Union, this was a taboo subject! As far as we know, between 27,000 and 30,000 people have been killed and have not been rehabilitated, compensated or even apologized to. I therefore welcome the text of the decision and hope that European integration and reconciliation will also be part of the rehabilitation of these victims.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on the state of implementation of anti-money laundering legislation (2019/2820(RSP)). Now I'm asking you to listen carefully. Before opening the debate, I can inform you that this part-session will test a new system that allows Members to register requests for on-request speeches and blue card questions. You have been provided with e-mail information on how this system works and you have been provided with instructions for use on your tables. Members may therefore make a request to speak by using the buttons on their voting computer in accordance with the instructions given. In addition to requests made by voting machine, you can also ask for the floor in the traditional way. You can request the floor on request by withdrawing the white paper or by registering in person at the beginning of the debate to colleagues in the plenary here and the blue card question can be asked by further raising the blue card. This electronic system will be tested for several debates and I would like to remind you that keep your voting card with you, because this is a prerequisite for us to be able to test this system. I hope that you will also use it.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, dear Commissioner, honourable Members, thank you for inviting the Presidency to contribute to this debate. The fight against money laundering and terrorist financing is a key topic during the Finnish Presidency and is an area to which the Council is strongly committed. Over the last years, we have – the Parliament, the Council and the Commission – worked closely with the aim of establishing an effective regime to counter money laundering and the financing of terrorism. We particularly strengthened the EU rules in 2019 with the adoption of the latest amendments to the Anti—Money Laundering Directive. The Member States are due to transpose it into national law by January 2020. Once in effect, the fifth Anti—Money Laundering Directive will improve the powers of financial intelligence units, increase the transparency around beneficial ownership information, and regulate virtual currencies and prepaid cards to better prevent terrorism financing. As you know, on the previous fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, the Member States transposition is facing some delays. On this, the Commission will be better placed to update you, but I understand that some of the infringement procedures have already been closed. Through the review of the European System of Financial Supervision, on which we agreed just before the parliamentary recess, we progressed further and reinforced the role of the European Banking Authority as regards risks posed to the financial sector by money laundering. Lawyer linguists are now finalising the legal texts in order for it to enter into force in January. They have also included strengthened rules on anti—money laundering in the banking package, namely with the revision of the Capital Requirements Directive. With the fifth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, we streamlined the cooperation between prudential supervisors and anti—money laundering authorities. The prudential supervisors should now have better abilities to intervene in cases where activities endanger financial stability. These rules already entered into force, and Member States are currently transposing them into national law. This is due to be completed by December 2020. On anti—money laundering, we also have the EU list of high—risk third countries, with strategic deficiencies. As you know, in March the Council objected to the Commission’s related delegated act. This decision does not mean that the listing is not an important element of the ongoing work – on the contrary – but in order to achieve the full impact of this instrument and to ensure its quality, we need to introduce the list in an orderly process. We believe that in order to establish a strong and effective instrument, the Commission proposal needs to be established in a transparent manner and needs to incentivise affected countries to take action. I know the Commission has been working intensively on the new methodology, which it will present to ministers in October. The criminal law framework in the area of money laundering has also recently been strengthened through the adoption of a directive on combating money laundering by criminal law. This directive is currently being implemented in Member States, and the transposition deadline is December 2020. Honourable Members, the Council is advancing on other fronts as well. It agreed, in December 2018, on a dedicated anti—money laundering action plan to further improve the current system, and the Council is regularly monitoring the delivery of the various actions. We have also asked the Commission to deliver a post—mortem review of recent alleged money laundering cases involving EU banks, with a view to better informing possible additional actions in the medium to long term. The Commission published its report in July and will present it to the Council in October. On the basis of this important input and other recent reports we are inviting the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN) to adopt the Council conclusions by December on an anti—money laundering strategic agenda that will guide the Commission going forward. Ladies and gentlemen, much is being done to tackle this important problem and, overall, our joint work in the area of anti—money laundering stands as a very good example of good cooperation. It is our priority as the Presidency to fight tax fraud, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. I look forward to hearing your views on the matter. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, money laundering hit the headlines in recent years and is at the centre of several key challenges Europe is facing today. The Commission is fully committed to safeguarding the EU financial system and its citizens from the harmful effects of the laundering of proceeds from criminal activities. Protecting citizens from terrorism also requires a robust system to counter the financing of terrorism. It is vital that our anti-money laundering policy retains the trust of citizens and also the trust of our international partners. In the past five years, together with the European Parliament, we worked hard to strengthen EU rules in this area. The revision of the anti-money laundering rules, the directive on criminal sanctions for money laundering, the directive on cooperation between financial intelligence units and law-enforcement authorities, as well as the strengthening of the role of the European Banking Authority, are all very important steps. But what matters now is the effective implementation of these rules, and Parliament is right to highlight this subject at the beginning of this term. I would insist on the importance of Member States’ implementing both the Fourth and Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directives. The latter will become applicable as of January 2020. And the Commission has watched Member States closely on effective implementation of the rules. Infringement proceedings have been opened against Member States for incomplete transposition of the Fourth Directive and some of them are still ongoing. We are closely checking both the conformity of the legislation and the way these rules are implemented in practice. While many shortcomings could be remedied through the implementation of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, it seems that some structural issues will remain. We addressed some of them in the report that the Commission adopted on 24 July on the state of implementation of the EU’s anti-money laundering framework. I believe these reports are a good basis for assessing what needs to be done in the future. The way in which anti-money laundering rules are applied in practice by all economic operators is of critical importance to the good functioning of the whole system. For instance, national banking supervisors must act decisively. Weak supervision was an issue in some of the large-scale money-laundering scandals we saw. Here a harmonised, directly applicable Union regulatory anti-money laundering framework could help. In addition, we could consider conferring specific anti-money laundering supervisory tasks on a Union body. We also found cases where supervisors were critically understaffed, failing to carry out on-site inspections as frequently as they should have done, or not taking appropriate measures when they found violations. Group supervision was also largely deficient. Prudential supervisors did not sufficiently take into account money-laundering concerns in their supervision of banks or in their suitability assessment of managers. We are aware that such programme problems are not limited to the banking sector only. They exist also in other parts of the financial sector, as well as the non-financial sector. This is another area that should not be overlooked. With regard to the report on financial intelligence units, the assessment confirmed that cooperation between financial intelligence units needs to be improved further, including through a stronger mechanism at EU level, to coordinate and support national financial intelligence units. It will be for the next Commission to decide on the next steps, but the policy guidelines of the President-designate are clear on this matter. We have to strengthen supervision and close loopholes. Finally, allow me to update you on the list of high-risk third countries. The Commission remains committed to delivering an updated list, in line with the requirement of the directive. Following the rejection of the delegated regulation by the Council, and the Parliament resolution in March, we have made strong efforts to take into account the views expressed by both Parliament and the Council. Our aim is to ensure consensus between all institutions on the process in order to avoid either Parliament or the Council rejecting the list. I would like to reiterate that the Commission will continue to carry out an autonomous assessment. We will, in principle, list countries which are listed by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF). At the same time, the listing criteria of the directive also go beyond the FATF criteria, in particular on transparency of beneficial ownership. This means that we will also list third countries with strategic deficiencies, even if they are not on the FATF list. Within this framework, we are working to refine the methodology of June 2018. Firstly, we aim at clarifying the interaction between the EU list and the one at international level by the FATF. Secondly, we proposed to detail further the engagement with third countries prior to a listing. Here we proposed to engage with third countries on the basis of our preliminary assessments and to seek commitments from third countries to implement mitigating measures within one year. This will help ensure that deficiencies are effectively addressed. We will also consider listing immediately those countries which present an overriding level of risks. We hope that this new approach will allow both co-legislators to reach a common understanding with a view to adopting the EU list on high-risk third countries. The Commission will maintain a regular political dialogue with Parliament and the Council in implementing the methodology. I intend to address the matter with finance ministers at the October ECOFIN Council. I would like to assure you that we will continue sharing the same goal of protecting the EU financial system from risks of money laundering posed by third countries.  I also want to thank the European Parliament for its continued support for this challenging but necessary process in the interest of our citizens.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If you listen to you like that, you really get the impression that everything is wonderful. Everything under control; the Council is committed and fighting money laundering day after day, hour after hour, and the Commission is examining all countries – all wonderfully. The truth is: nothing is wonderful. If we look closely at the Commission's audit report, two things have become obvious. Firstly, in 28 Member States, the Money Laundering Directive is implemented 28 times differently. We do not have uniform implementation in Europe. Secondly, cooperation between the judicial authorities and financial supervision does not work with the national authorities, and nothing works at all in cross-border cases. When I look at these two problems, there are actually two solutions. The number one solution is no longer a directive, but a regulation. If we want uniform law in Europe, we must go down the path of regulation. Secondly, if cooperation does not work and – do not be nasty to me – even though we have just negotiated that the European Banking Authority, as the supervisory supervisor, has to check whether everything is being done right: you are not fighting money laundering, but you are only creating forms between supervisory authorities. We need a structure that can be energised. We have OLAF in the Commission, we have the European Public Prosecutor in cases against the financial interests of the European Union, and we should really consider, Commissioner for Justice, whether we are not proposing that we also give the European Public Prosecutor or a similar structure the right to intervene, so that it can also be reacted to criminally quickly and it does not remain in the hands of the Member States. We need to act urgently here – the figures have been mentioned. We must not talk to ourselves about the world, but we must work out solutions. This Parliament is ready to do so, which is why this clear message is being delivered today in the debate, tomorrow in the vote – please deliver accordingly.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to start with the previous speaker. We have strict rules against money laundering in the European Union. But what are the point of the strictest laws if they are not implemented, if they are not properly implemented, if they are not subject to strict supervision? The supervision of the Money Laundering Directive is strongly national. This must stop! We are in agreement on this. We must also recognise that, in the long term, the problem can be solved with a European anti-money laundering authority. Until then, a European anti-money laundering unit must take on this task. Every new money laundering scandal is bigger than the previous one. We cannot wait for the next scandal to burst. And the second point is the problem of golden visas – a lucrative source of income for some states. Rich people can buy citizenship or a residence permit like a luxury goods, such as a car, like a villa, like a yacht, like an expensive handbag, without questioning the origin of the funds. This is scandalous! Because we know that money laundering goes hand in hand with corruption, with tax evasion, with criminal activities. The problem must be tackled holistically. And as such, the Commission must also start with golden visas and make practical proposals on how we can solve the problem in the future.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I want to say to the Commissioner and the Council representative: let’s be honest, the reason we are here is because the anti-money laundering system is not fit for purpose. It just doesn’t work. We hear about a lack of resources. We had a hearing with the Commission and with the European Banking Authority and we hear about a lack of resources, legislation that cannot be implemented, legislation that is different in every country, lack of personnel, three to eight people. It is really, really not fit for purpose and we all agree, and citizens have to agree. They are worried because combating money laundering is basic to fighting against every possible crime, from drug trafficking to people trafficking. Fighting against money laundering is fighting those terrible crimes. Why does the system not work? The system doesn’t work because states don’t have the incentive to have a system that works: states have an incentive to get capital when they need capital. So, at the end of the day, if the capital includes proceeds from places which are not very clear, we turn a blind eye. And the problem is that the system is as strong as the weakest link. If only one state has a bad system, we’re going to have a problem in all the other states. We heard about the Danske Bank scandal – EUR 200 billion of money laundering! What is really scandalous about this problem is not just that no action was taken, and not just that the Estonian and Danish regulators let it happen, because for each it was the problem of the other: it is that, when it came to the EBA, the states said that, because there was no European legislation involved, there was nothing to be done. We believe that this Parliament is united. I’m proud to have worked with my colleagues to have a resolution together. Parliament believes that the Commission needs to do its work, the Council needs to do its work and Parliament needs to do its work so that these agencies are well resourced, so that we have the resources to fight against money laundering, so that we have legislation that can be applicable everywhere in the European Union, and so that we have a system that is European and that works for all.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There is a security risk in Europe that governments are notoriously neglected, and that is the issue of money laundering. We have billions of dollars in money laundering every year. Criminals, with the worst forms of economic efficiency, earn billions and billions, so to speak. This money is laundered and then reinvested in criminal economics – in terrorism, but increasingly it is also buying houses, and in the real estate centers, prices are being pushed up accordingly. And as we talk about it, we see that we actually have the legal options. Europe offers the legal means for Member States to take action against it. However, we still have a widespread failure on the part of the Member States in the prosecution of money laundering. The ten biggest money laundering scandals that the European Commission has dealt with clearly demonstrate this failure. We do not have to go to some notorious tax havens such as Cyprus, Malta and so on, but let us start in Germany, the largest Member State. About 100 billion euros are made each year in money laundering in Germany. The Financial Intelligence Unit has 20,000 suspected money laundering charges largely unprocessed. The Authority is not working, although it has been a European requirement to equip it properly since the third money laundering directive, which has been in need of implementation for more than ten years. For months, I have been arguing with the services of the European Commission as to whether infringement proceedings are finally being initiated here. And it is precisely such infringement procedures that would be appropriate not only for Germany, but for a whole range of Member States, which simply have to implement the draft law accordingly, but also finally have to implement this bill in reality. That is why I am calling on you in the European Commission to open a new chapter here. Do not, above all, see whether the letter of the law is the same, but whether European money laundering law is actually being implemented! And for all those who do not, you are finally launching infringement proceedings that really relate to implementation! Ultimately, we must resolve this through European common institutions – as several speakers have said here – which can actually act and take action throughout Europe. And you in the Council can do a lot to ensure that implementation finally works and support us in creating such European institutions.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her With the fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, the EU obliges Member States to pass on personal data to the European Banking Authority in many areas – decisions against which investors and savers have little legal remit. The citizen will be glassy. The role of NGOs, on the other hand, has so far excluded the EU from the fight against money launderers. Last year, Maltese NGO Commissioner Professor Kenneth Wain warned of the vulnerability of NGOs to money laundering offences and the financing of terrorist organisations. Professor Wain therefore called for the extension of EU money laundering legislation to NGOs. He had to resign due to massive political pressure. MONEYVAL, the Council of Europe's anti-money laundering authority, shares Professor Wain's concern that there is clear evidence that NGOs are being used as money laundering vehicles. In committee, therefore, I asked why the Commission ignores NGOs. The lapidary answer was: because the Commission did not want NGOs to be considered criminal. We demand that NGOs are no longer exempted from the law.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, it is true that this is a complex, technical subject, but I believe that it is very important for the credibility of the European Union. During the previous mandate, we had already discussed a lot of these texts on money laundering. I would remind you that our emotion was due to a number of scandals, including the Panama Papers. And we are still talking about money laundering activities related to corruption, arms trafficking, human trafficking, drug trafficking and tax evasion. It involves hundreds of billions of euros, so it is really a very important subject. What do the text we are discussing today and the Commission's assessments show us? It is that today there are inadequacies, unbearable failures. Firstly, the transposition of the directives has not really been followed up, and this is the case in the majority of Member States. So, at some point, we're still going to have to look at the offences. On the other hand, we have not talked about it since the beginning, but the European Banking Authority's capacity for impetus and decision-making seems to have reached certain limits - limits set out by the President himself. Finally, we parliamentarians remember the Council's refusal to approve the list of 23 countries whose actions are notoriously lacking in the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism. You remember the debate and the fatal decision to absolve proven accomplices of terrorism, such as Saudi Arabia, or tax havens, such as the Virgin Islands or Panama.  So now it's really time to act. And, indeed, the problem we face today, the question that arises, is it not time to move on to the regulations? Because we really have an impotence which is very worrying, for us parliamentarians, but especially for the citizens of Europe.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the placing of proceeds from illegal activities in the legal economy is a crime of high social danger, it takes on cross-border characteristics, it creates distorting effects in the internal market and competition, and it ends up harming companies that respect the rules. It also allows criminal individuals and organisations, including terrorist organisations, to obtain sources of funding to further fuel their activities. As a delegation of the 5 Star Movement we have considered the fight against this phenomenon to be a priority in our national and European programme. We have made an important contribution in this direction with the directive on combating money laundering through criminal law, for example by prohibiting those convicted of this crime from concluding contracts with the public administration, accessing public funding or applying for elected office. Furthermore, in the own-initiative report on combating corruption and organised crime, for which I was rapporteur, another step was taken towards the extension at European level of effective anti-Mafia legislation through common minimum standards, stronger police and judicial cooperation and better exchange of information. Those involved in money laundering are exploiting all legislative loopholes to ensure impunity, and it is therefore essential to have a European law enforcement framework that requires not only continuous updates, in order to keep pace with new developments in this phenomenon, but also transposition and rapid, coordinated and uniform implementation among the Member States, which is still lacking.

name: David CASA
text: – Sinjura President, il-ħasil ta' flus, kif nafu, huwa konsegwenza ta' atti crimes – għandna diversi eżempji ta' political, non-zika, frodists, li kollha jaraw kif jagħmlu biex jaħbu dawn il-flejjes illi jkunu ġabu b'mod illegali. Il-verità hi mhux faèli tinduna b'dan kollu – strutturi kumplessi f'diversi ġurisdizzjonijiet in ħafna drabi jkun hemm ukoll l-involviment ta' numru kbir ta' entitajiet finanzjarji. Ħafna mill-istituzzjonijiet jagħmlu l-investigazzjonijiet tagħhom imma ħafna jfallu wkoll, in meta dawn ifall in ma jinvestigawx, jew ma jipproèedux, fuq każijiet ta' ħasil ta' flus, ikollhom ikunu l-whistleblowers in l-ġurnalisti investigattivi li jirriskjaw ħajjithom biex jikxfu dan kollu. Kollha nafu x'ġara mill-ġurnalisti bħal Daphne Caruana Galizia in bħal Jan Kuciak! Ix-xahar li ġej, irrid infakkar hawn, illi huwa t-tieni anniversarju mill-qtil brutali ta' Daphne Caruana Galizia. Illi jiena nemmen, illi kieku l-istituzzjonijiet kienu aktar effettivi fil-ġlieda contra l-ħasil ta' flus, daphne Caruana Galizia kieku forsi, illum, għadha magħna. In allura naqbel illi l-affarijiet hemm bżonn li jinbidlu. Ma jistax ikun illi non-seams tajbin in whether huma fil-maġġoranza jimxu skont ir-regoli waqt li dawk li huma fil-poter in the corrotti jibqgħu jagħmlu whether jridu b'detriment għaċ-äittadini Ewropej.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against money laundering is a priority to combat the most serious forms of transnational crime and to protect the European economy from dangerous distortions, which can undermine citizens' confidence in banking and financial institutions. The most recent money laundering scandals in the banking system still highlight the need for an effective supervision and enforcement system to prevent, identify and sanction violations by economic operators. A system requiring information exchange, close interdisciplinary cooperation between the regulatory authorities of the banking system and police and judicial authorities and, again, transnational coordination between all law enforcement actors. The European Union has recently adopted important legislative instruments: the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive; the Directive on the exchange of information between FIUs and law enforcement authorities for the prevention of serious crime; the particularly significant directive harmonizing the criminal definition of money laundering; as well as the regulation strengthening the competence of the European Banking Authority in anti-money laundering supervision. However, we must ensure that these instruments are properly and promptly implemented, and we must continue to work to promote closer cooperation between banking regulators, at European and national level, and the judicial authorities of the Member States.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, around EUR 188 billion, meaning 1% of the European Union's gross domestic product, is money involved in suspicious financial activities each year. The Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive was to be implemented by June 2017. The creativity of some Member States in transposing this directive exceeded all expectations: from excessive measures imposed on non-governmental organisations to famous transposition tables such as former Minister Toader, which had on one column whole paragraphs of the directive and on the other column the phrase 'Not applicable'. The reality is that none of the 28 Member States has fully and correctly transposed the fourth directive.  The Fifth Directive must be transposed by January 2020. Only eight Member States have so far transposed this directive. I think the answer is simple. We need regulations. If the transposition of the directives does not work, we need regulations and we have no more time to lose. We need both regulations in this area, which are essential for the functioning of the Union and for combating great crime, and firm sanctions for those Member States that do not comply with and implement the regulations.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, we have a very serious problem of thousands and billions of euros circulating in the European financial system, bleached, from criminal activities, and the scandals in recent years I think are palpable. From Latvian bank ABLV, Danske Bank, Deutsche Bank, Pilatus Bank, we could make a very long list of scandals that you well know. And, in the assessments you have made yourself, we find faults of all kinds: since the lack, for example, of anti-laundering obligations within banks, the lack of staff in supervisory bodies, the lack of inspections, zero cooperation between countries. This is a very very serious problem and we must therefore have more action, be much braver in the application — at the outst of it – of European legislation. It cannot be that we are so late in the implementation of the fourth Directive. We have to be very diligent with the application of the fifth. As we have asked this Parliament and we will ask you in this resolution, with the monitoring of third countries which are a real problem, with that grey list which we have long proposed that you establish, as well as, when these directives are not implemented correctly, to be much more diligent with the opening of infringement proceedings. We have real states that do not comply in any way with the legislation that we have adopted in this house. And, therefore, you must be much more diligent. And finally, as we have also repeatedly asked them, we must move progressively towards the creation of a genuine European authority, in order to tackle this phenomenon. So that must be an absolute priority of this mandate.

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Madam President, it is difficult to refuse a sense of hypocrisy to companies facing almost daily on the pointillist and sometimes excessive side of the fight against money laundering.  For us, the real cause of this leprosy, money laundering, is simply the principle of the free movement of capital around the world. It is difficult to conceive of large-scale money laundering operations without complicit banking networks, without complicit electronic financing platforms, without the ease that trusts and trusts, which conceal the identity of the final beneficiaries of financial transactions, ensure money laundering operations.  It is also difficult to deny the role that NGOs, foundations that sometimes hide tax optimisation and tax evasion operations, finance corruption and engage in large-scale money laundering in this dramatic landscape.  In this regard, we can only encourage the Commission to assess its action, formalism in relation to the real results of the fight against money laundering and to put an end to a hypocrisy that a number of tax havens, business domiciles without real activity, are at the very heart of the Union.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Respected chairman, corruption and money laundering are two extremely related concepts. Nowadays, the biggest corruption and the biggest disappearance of money that needs to be laundered afterwards is not from trade and cigarette smuggling, it is not from blackmail, but it comes from public procurement procedures and insolvency proceedings. And what is worse, what happened in the Republic of Croatia, it is possible to legalize this corruption with newly adopted laws. In Croatia, the Law on Pre-Bankruptcy Settlements and extraordinary administration was adopted, weighing 10 billion euros. And the courts, which were supposed to oversee the legality of these proceedings and prevent corruption and money laundering, were turned into the most regular notaries. Huge money disappeared that way. Many have become owners of large companies in the Republic of Croatia without us knowing who they are. All this takes place through funds based in third countries.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The debate, and above all the speeches, show one thing across party lines: how important and right it is that we, as the European Chamber of Citizens, should once again speak out in the fight against money laundering and the fight against terrorism. Why? Eu 110 billion euros of black money are still laundered in the EU each year; Ten major European banks are still far-reachingly affected by money laundering scandals; there is still a clear contradiction between the commitments we have agreed and the implementation; There is still a lack of control, a lack of sanctions, a lack of supervisory staff, a lack of money for the European Banking Authority in the implementation of the Money Laundering Directive. The fourth money laundering directive has still not been implemented, although the fifth directive would have to be implemented by January 2020, and we still have a situation where this shortcoming leads to a patchwork of implementation and thus to new loopholes that weaken the internal market, hinder the banking union and our common regulation and supervision. It is therefore the order of the day that we must do everything we can to move from the directive to the mandatory regulation; that we can strengthen Europe; that it is controlled and sanctioned; that we implement the common commitments and that we cooperate rather than isolate ourselves from each other. Only then will we be credible. We will not take our finger off this wound until all that we have committed ourselves to has been done.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, the scandals that have been exposed in recent years – and we’ve heard about them, we’ve seen millions and in some cases billions of euros being laundered – have left the people we represent fed up. They are fed up with always being the ones to bear the burden of the consequences when there are economic downturns, and fed up that the richest in our society and criminals are able to find ways to stash their cash away from regulatory oversight and tax collection. Just one example: as we heard earlier, Danske Bank facilitated EUR 200 billion of suspicious transactions over eight years in Estonia. Despite executives facing criminal prosecution in several countries, the European Banking Authority this year rejected proposals that there had been breaches of Union law. Are they serious? The Commission is still prevaricating. A few weeks ago it said it was still examining the matter. There are many, many more examples. We cannot simply wait for another big scandal. There are too many loopholes in our legislation that give opportunities to criminals and those who want to bend the rules. If we don’t fight this kind of cross-border criminality here, where will it be done? How is the Commission going to ensure we get tougher on this issue? We have to go further with the tools available to us, and the legislation has to be implemented with vigour in all 28 Member States. Just one quick question to the Commission: what are we doing to investigate the thousands of shell companies registered in offshore tax havens, who else is linked to them and what are their purposes?

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, it was my honour to come to this Parliament after 16 years as an advocate in criminal law, including some time as a Crown prosecutor in the UK. And what I saw in my work was that money laundering is to crime what the circulation of blood is to our bodies. Money can be obtained in a fraud, then reinvested, say, in a drugs factory, reinvested in human trafficking, and then maybe reinvested in weapons – and someone loses their life. Each time, it can move between different countries. Or it can be used to buy luxury cars, luxury houses, private education, anything of high value – lifestyles which motivate more crime. In my country, the police estimate money laundering at GBP 100 billion every year and we have 25 different organisations meant to have some responsibility in addressing it. It is too divided. It’s outrageous and unacceptable that some Member States have not implemented this legislation, though we also need partnership that goes beyond the European Union. Money laundering can go into Africa, into America, into Asia, and we need a framework for partnerships that trace money and trace the criminals. We need to change a culture where some law-enforcement officers, be they police or prosecutors or something else, think that money laundering is second-division crime and not important. Brexit, of course, puts my country at much greater risk. I hope very much the new Commission will attack this issue with vigour.

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: – Madam President, preventing money laundering is a key issue in combating organised crime. However, it is also a question of maintaining citizens' trust and promoting the principle of transparency. I appreciate the shift brought about by the Fourth and Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directives. However, the problem is that a number of countries have not been able to implement the Fourth Directive sufficiently.  So what's the next steps going to look like? Citizens trust the European Commission and rely on it to enforce the law. It is not possible to throw away their trust, Commissioner Jourová. Public registers of final business owners are a major shift. However, if we want effective public control, it is necessary that this data can be used effectively, it must be machine-readable. As we have seen for ourselves in the Czech Republic, transparency must also be introduced into trust funds. The register of beneficial trust owners is a good step forward so far. However, the Commission must already ensure that Member States do not restrict access to these registers, for example, to journalists or non-profit organisations. We should not repeat the mistakes that have happened in the past.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, with this resolution, we call on the Member States to effectively implement the European legislation adopted in the field of anti-money laundering in the European Union, namely the Fourth and Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directives.  Our criticisms are well founded, given that a large number of Member States have not yet correctly transposed the rules of the Fourth Directive, and within a few months they must also implement the provisions of the Fifth Directive. This is extremely important, given that the interruption of financial sources of terrorism aims to prevent attacks on the territory of the European Union.  The fact is that the current European Union anti-money laundering framework suffers from shortcomings in implementation. It is therefore important to build a comprehensive European approach that maximises money laundering and terrorist financing. The European Union must be able to tackle money laundering and fight terrorist financing in a way that is effective and autonomous, especially as regards the blacklisting of third countries.

name: Niels FUGLSANG
text: – Madam President, in the years 2007 to 2015 the Danish bank, Danske Bank, had a department in Estonia that worked as a money-laundering central with suspicious transactions for up to EUR 200 billion. The Estonian authorities warned the Danish authorities several times but the Danish authorities did nothing. As was mentioned in April, however, the European Banking Authority came with a report saying that there was no breach in Union law and that the Danish authorities had done nothing wrong.  For me, this shows that there’s something wrong, completely wrong, with the system and that we need to change. The main problem seems to be that the national authorities, which the European Banking Authority scrutinises, sit on the very board that can accept or reject the report that is critical of the Member States. It is an obvious conflict of interest. I think something should be done, and I hope the Commissioner agrees and I would like to know what the Commission proposes and how to reform the governance of the European Banking Authority.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: – Madam President, it is clear that tackling money laundering is a major policy issue and cross—border challenge. Fragmentation in national implementation and supervisory practices in relation to anti—money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism is aggravating the problems we face. We must find a way for better enforcement of EU rules. In the framework of the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Directive, a number of corrective measures have been taken to address the existing shortcomings. It is important that, in transposing the directive into national legislation, Member States work together on critical points which have been identified, including poor information sharing at both supervisory level and the level of financial institutions themselves. Information sharing is key and we should make better use of new technologies in this regard, with the aim of improving the interconnectivity of relevant databases so as to increase access to data and facilitate cross—border cooperation. Also, as new challenges arise, such as broader use of crypto-assets, we need to adapt our approach to make sure these are covered by our AML framework. Time is of the essence, so we all need to take responsibility and act together swiftly to stem the flow of illegal money in Europe.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Honour, President, thank you very much for your word. It is good that we have the best possible legislation, but it does nothing to have people who intend to abuse this legislation. They have money and have lawyers advising them on how to evade the rules. They write laws in their own way and even influence proceedings before the courts. Even here, in this House, we discussed the laundering of Iranian money in the Slovenian New Ljubljana Bank before the PANA Investigative Committee. 30 000 transactions, a billion euros of money washed, which was also likely to be spent for terrorist purposes. And what happened? Nothing.  The case in Slovenia now also resonates when eur 29 million has been written off to companies closely associated with the Mayor of Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia, to the detriment of creditors. As reported by the media, the debtors have previously safely hid the property in Malta, and the business is done through mailboxes and trusts of unknown origin. What does the law do us use in preventing money and the rules on beneficial owners. We have the legal basis of what we need, it is a fair system and honest people who will be able to investigate and condemn such abuses.  Dear Commissioner, what can you or the Institutions of the European Union do when it comes to such anomalies? They should have the power to act in cases where national authorities are failing.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, Madam Representative of the Finnish Presidency, the fight against corruption and organised crime matters greatly to the European Union, and not only economically, because it is an attack on its values. That is why the instrument of criminal law against money laundering and the financing of terrorism has been needed. That is why the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs was thoroughly employed and some of its members, myself in particular, participated in the work of the Committee of Inquiry on Panama's papers. And the lessons were clear. There is the fifth Directive to improve transparency, the exchange of information, financial intelligence units, the prevention of the level of involvement of certain third countries and the prevention of the use of prepaid instruments in the service of corruption, money laundering and the financing of terrorism. But as important as this legislative commitment is to ensure its proper implementation and implementation in the Member States. That is why we urge the Commission, and this is the meaning of this debate, to also make a thorough use of the correct implementation, ensuring the fulfilment of the objective at the times indicated by the Commission and, where appropriate, infringement files against the failing countries.

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Madam President, various money laundering scandals in the banking sector, be it Danske Bank, Deutsche Bank, ING, Pilatus or ABLV, have shocked Europeans and provided proof of many weaknesses in EU cooperation. Let me remind you – let me remind ourselves – that we even needed the US authorities to shore up our own weaknesses.  I see the following main problems: national Financial Intelligence Units do not exchange the information needed, Member States do not fully implement the necessary legislation and undermine the cooperation required, while many banks do not equally apply EU rules. The problem is real. As was already mentioned, according to Europol about one percent of the EU’s GDP is detected as being involved in suspect financial activities. The lack of coordinated actions on anti-money laundering (AML) legislation deepens the already fragmented capital markets, which we want to integrate. Let me add one more thing: the ball is on the Council’s side. Any new legislative proposals are meaningless without the will for greater cooperation by the countries.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the debate clearly shows that this will remain the priority for this term of office, and I heard the contribution by those of you who went through the saga of all the action against money laundering in the term that is now finishing. We did a lot of useful things both in legislation and in supervision and we pushed on implementation, but I would never say that the situation is ideal, or that there is nothing to improve. It will be a priority in this term of office for this Commission and this Parliament to take further action, and I agree that it should be, or could be, the regulation so that Member States will not be able to deviate from the purpose of why we are doing all this legislation against money laundering. We are not talking here about money, we are talking about serious organised crime. We are talking about the money which enables the serious organised crime, and we are also talking about people’s trust – trust that we will do something together which will change the situation and which will finally be efficient. We want to have a healthy financial system in Europe, which is the important element of European prosperity, so we have to filter out the risks and address them through properly functioning rules to be implemented by all. And to those of you who said that our system is only as strong as the weakest element of the system – exactly! This system must be taken seriously by all the Member States. I heard here that the Member States should be motivated. Well, the motivation should be the same everywhere – that the laws must be implemented – and that is the crucial task of the Member States. But we have negative motivation, we have infringements. I can give you a picture of what we are doing to enforce the Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Directive. The process of supervision led to the opening of infringement proceedings against all – all – Member States, and at this moment the proceedings have been closed for five Member States only. For all the other Member States, the Commission has issued letters of formal notice and reasoned opinions and the procedure is ongoing. On the Fifth AML Directive, to be transposed in January next year, up to now we have received the following notifications: three Member States notified complete transposition, and another five notified transposition measures. For the rest, we are monitoring the situation, and we will act very soon after the implementation date. I shared with you my view that the regulation will be needed: it will be the right step forward. Of course, I am leaving this sector, so it is just my personal view after working on this topic. As to why we adopted the Fourth and Fifth AML Directives: well, the Fifth Directive, which was adopted in my term of office, was a clear and very quick reaction to the Panama Papers scandal and to terrorist attacks, which it was not easy to predict or uncover early enough because there were anonymous payments involved. We had to react to that. We also had to react to a very clear request for full transparency of beneficial ownership, and here I want to respond to Mr Kolakušić, or Mr Peksa. It was my personal very strong desire to make the beneficial ownership register fully open, fully transparent for the public, without differentiation between who has a legally proven interest and who does not, including journalists. And that will be the case. We will have fully public registers. For trust funds, the situation was more difficult, because some trust funds have a purely private foundation. So we are addressing, especially, commercial trusts, but for other trusts too there will be the possibility of getting information about the owners. Other steps forward could include full implementation of the regulation on financial intelligence units’ cooperation. Mr Radev has left, and I had wanted to thank him for his efforts because he was the rapporteur on this piece of legislation. He could give me his confirmation that it was a very tough exercise to convince the Member States to take the necessary measures so that financial intelligence units cooperate and share information with the law-enforcement authorities within their country, and even more difficult to convince them that there should be an exchange of information cross-border. So, to those who mentioned cross-border cooperation: it’s very weak, you are right, and we tried to improve it through this new piece of legislation, but it was not tough enough and we had to make compromises. Here too I expect some progress in this parliamentary term. On the question of having one Union body for better supervision, while we have taken the first step, the European Banking Authority should have strengthened competences, and it is in the legislation that there should be better data collection and the possibility to act when a Member State seems to be failing to act – which was, by the way, the case of the Danske Estonian bank. I still cannot imagine how it is possible, over five or seven years, for the laundering of up to EUR 200 billion to go unnoticed. Who failed? The investigations are still ongoing and we will know for sure who is failing, or who was the failure in the system. Denmark, in the meantime, has changed its legislation. So there are reactions, but I certainly agree that there should be one strong Union body which should supervise this. There was also a question from Ms Tomc: who will act at European level when the Member States fail in the field of criminal law? Well, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) will start functioning from November next year, and this will be the body having specialised prosecutors on financial crime. It would be worth considering whether the EPPO could not be the body which takes cases over if Member States fail. I know I am speaking for too long, but there were many questions. Just to conclude, Mr Casa mentioned the Whistle-blowers Directive, and this might also bring some benefits. Thank you very much for your patience. I felt the need and obligation to react to your comments and questions because this is a priority topic, which needs to be well mastered on a political level, at European Union level, in the next term of office.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, Commissioner. It is very good to see that you always respond and answer the questions from MEPs. Not every Commissioner does the same, so thank you very much for your engagement and involvement in this very important topic.

name: Tytti Tuppurainen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you very much for this debate. I have followed your valuable contributions with great interest. I’ve also heard the input from the Commission, which I highly value. I hope also that the Commission-to-come is aiming high here.  I was asked in particular asked about the actions taken by the Council with regard to money laundering and the recent scandals in our banks, and I agree that this is a problem. We need to get to the bottom of the issue and address it further if we conclude that the measures taken recently are not enough. We are starting to analyse the Commission’s post-mortem review of the recent alleged money laundering cases involving EU banks, and the Council will discuss this in October, that is, next month. We plan to arrive at conclusions by December this year, so actions will follow.  I also take this opportunity to reaffirm the importance which the Presidency attaches to the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing and I look forward to working together on these matters. The message from this discussion has been very clear: there needs to be more done for anti-money laundering and the subject was widely supported by all the different political groups. I personally can promise you that I will convey your message to my colleague, the Minister of Finance, as your contribution on this very important issue. The Presidency will remain available for exchanges on the subject as needed, so I would like to thank you all very much again for your commitment to this issue.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2). The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 19 September 2019. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: in writing. – Europol data: about one per cent of Europe's annual GDP is involved in money laundering. For Europol, corruption, arms and human trafficking, tax crimes and terrorism have access to this money. Increasingly elaborate, sophisticated practices. And cross-border.  The EU, the Council, the Commission and the EP together have a force that they would not have a part of. It is fair to acknowledge the Commission's attempts to implement the rules that exist. S&D, with concrete proposals, has been hit by stronger supervision, tougher sanctions on suspicious banks and companies in Member States that do not apply or misapply EU rules.  It is essential legislation that gives instruments of exchange, exchange of information and financial intelligence that put us at the same level of sophistication of criminals, going beyond the current minimum standards. We support the creation of a support and coordination mechanism and a continuous analysis of the flow of information between financial intelligence units, adopting common legal standards, without neglecting the protection and security of personal data. To fight money laundering and money laundering is to fight terrorism, it is to defend citizens. It's a battle for us to fight. Together.
